Also sadly disappearing from the original was the terribly eerie greenness of that film--the green color of the entire film gave it an edge of otherworldliness and sickness that was quite missing in Nakata's more standard blue-tinted film. That green color is to me the signature of "The Ring" and perhaps its single strongest element, and its loss is similarly terrible.

This time, Naomi Watts is ironically given a bit less to work with as an actor, but succeeds in what she has. However, David Dorfman was a huge shock to me, performing a depth and range in his portrayal of Aidan Keller that is quite simply beyond the capabilities of an average child actor or even many good ones. Dorfman's character moves beyond the rather simplistic kid who was forced to grow up too fast of "The Ring" into a far more complex and more damaged child, and he seems more than up to the challenge. We may have a star in the making here. Perhaps equally surprising is the small performance of Sissy Spacek, who was unrecognizable and whose performance was as believable as any in the film. Gary Cole's appearance is also noteworthy because it is simply so different from his niche--one of the world's greatest creeps plays an affable if a bit slippery real estate agent with a charm and energy that I would never have expected.

In short, "The Ring Two" is an uneven disappointment, but in that disappointment still surpasses average horror fare. David Dorfman stands out as an actor for all the right reasons and Hideo Nakata stands out as a director for mostly the wrong reasons (if "Ringu" looked like this, too, I'm quite certain I'm glad I saw "The Ring" instead). Still, it has its share of cheap thrills if that's what you're looking for and some truly interesting drama, so it's not a complete loss.

The only reason i went and saw this movie was cause my husband liked the first one. I saw the first one by myself at my home in the dark because everyone said it was the scariest movie ever, which it wasn't i thought the first one was awful. But no i was wrong, the second one is horrible. Its SO fake and i hate movies like that. Its so unbelievably BORING that i was falling asleep in the theater and just wanted to leave. Paying 8$ to see this movie is ridiculous and if you absolutely "must" see it i suggest going to a $2 movie theater, even though its barely worth that. Or maybe you can just wait till it comes out on DVD. I'm not gonna tell you what happens in the movie cause i don't wanna spoil it for ya, lets just say a good explanation of how horrible it was is, not one person in the theater stopped laughing throughout the whole movie cause of how stupid it was. Sequels are 98% of the time NEVER better than the first and this movie is a good example of that, even though the first one sucked just as bad.

When "The Ring" was remade and released in the U.S. a couple years ago, I saw it at my local theater and was amazed. Hands down the best thriller/horror movie I had seen in some time. Since then, I sought out and rented the Original, Japanese version of the film, which was even more creepier than its United States counterpart. I was left with a satisfying feeling after watching that film, however, when I learned "The Ring Two" was going to be released, I was incredibly skeptical. I have little faith in sequels, especially in the horror genre, and this movie only cements my opinion.

I found myself yawning and struggling to stay awake due to the slow paced plot (very welcome in the first film, in that it was well-developed) and never felt the sheer creepiness I was smothered with in the first film. Definitely tarnished the good name of the Ring/Ringu movies, I won't even bother to import the Japanese version of Ring 2, because I want to retain as many pleasant thoughts about the first movie as possible. Don't waste any money or time with this film.

review_title: A good sequel with some decent scares

review_detailed_main:
I feel like I have to resign myself to the fact that horror movies are a dying breed. Although sequels are generally bad, this one takes the cake. The Ring was a brilliant mystery with a truly unexpected ending. Although I did not find it scary, it was well written, innovative and unique.

This movie does not have a real plot. The writer is confused and has no idea where the story is going. The director seems to be rather confused and unable to decide what he wants to do. Many of the shots are cut off too quickly, and the only jumps are at the first ten minutes. The actors seem equally confused and the only decent performance is from the amazing Sissy Spacek.

I can't advise someone to not see this movie. Even though you may be disappointed, there are a few good parts at the beginning. Also, the real reason to see it is to simply satisfy your curiosity. But don't expect much, because this movie does not deliver.

With everything that happened, one would expect the ending to have been as inspiring as the first movie. Absolutely not. The 'solution' is so stupid that it leaves you actually hoping for the 'final comeback' from the bad guy. I won't say whether or not that comes, but all in all it was very poor and in line with The Grudge and Boogeyman as some of the lamest horror films of all time.

Sad to say, it actually seems like Rob Zombie is the only horror director left with any guts. And although I don't care for his films, at least he understands his genre. All the horror masters (except for George Romero) have lost touch with what truly makes a film scary. It's sad.

This movie, unfortunately, did not live up to the stellar nature of its predecessor. However, it was still decently successful in it's own right.

If you really break it down and look at it, its play by play and chain of events really are not all that different from the original. When really examined, it's almost kind of like the same movie just a bit different... and not as good lol.

It had a shockingly star-studded cast that I found very surprising but cool to see all together in something I didn't know. I just wasn't expecting to recognize so many faces.

It was fine as a whole and worth a watch but nothing spectacular. 5.5 rounding up to a 6, would recommend.

review_title: a movie for people who like corny-scary
review_detailed_main: This movie was as bad as the first one. When I saw the first one, I was in my house alone, in my room and it was dark. I was not scared at all. Rather I was disgusted by the plot. It really didn't tie in at all and I'm afraid that does not interest me then. As I saw the second movie with a few friends of mine who liked the first one, I went into the movie thinking I'm going to hate this. And I know going into the movie with a bad mood would result in a bad opinion. But as the movie started and eventually built up, things just seemed to be so cliché. For a moment, at the beginning I thought I was watching Scream and when the phone rang I turned to my friend and said, "What's your favorite scary movie?" This movie is also DRENCHED in foreshadowing. Even when the child psychiatrist came on, it was a foreshadowing of who the next big actor to come on the screen was. He just so happened to be Mr. Lumbar from Office Space. I thought that was terribly funny, mainly cause I was the only one that got it out of the theater but as soon as I told my friends, we had a riot. But what I got from the movie was that if there was no foreshadowing, there would be no movie. And that is not what a movie is about. Foreshadowing is great...especially for the Duh, Duh, Duuuh. But as the plot, no. I also didn't think the plot made sense. Like I understood the plot and everything made sense but as a critic, it didn't make sense as to why the plot existed. There should have been something in the movie that says there are reasons why you should watch this, not just for the thrill (which there was only one). Camera angles and shots were interesting though. At the very beginning, there were different camera shots of water that of course foreshadowed how to get rid of Samara. But there were so many of those shots, I started to get sick of seeing like bright sun on wavy water. There was also one shot of Naomi Watts with like a wavy water over it. I had to look away from the screen because it was making me nauseous. Acting wise, the actors were amazing. The new male lead was quite attractive and he had his moments where he shined bright. So this is my opinion of the The Ring 2, which I hope will help with people who are seeking an honest opinion of the movie.

Though this movie isn't as good as the first ring or the Japanese version, this is still not bad viewing. there were a few alright scares and scenes that kept my eyes on the screen. though there was some plot holes that didn't make complete sense, though the plotting wasn't the only downfall. though it was good that the got Hideo Nakata from the Japanese versions to direct, like they did with the grudge remake, i felt it would have been better if they kept Gore Verbinski as the director, as he added his own touch which separated the English remake from the Japanese version. i was also hoping that they would have kept the blue wash in the first ring which added a 'air' of despair and dread which raised the experience and helped heighten the impact of the disturbing images of the distorted faces. That said this is still worth seeing, especially is you like the first one.

review_title: A big disappointment, one of the worst sequels ever made
review_detailed_main:
The sequel to the 2002 big hit 'The Ring' which was an unique and very good movie, is in two words: "a disappointment". Everything everyone loved about the first one is not here.

Originally this was going to be a prequel/sequel of the first, but the Dreamworks studio decided that they should save the prequel for a possible THIRD Ring, this decision did not pleased the first choice of director, Noam Murro, so he leaved the project, meanwhile Dreamworks ordered a NEW script from Ehren Kruger, they also decided to bring Hideo Nakata, the director of both Ringu and Ringu 2, to direct the sequel.

Naomi Watts contractually obligated returns, as well as David Dorfman, Daveigh Chase doesn't, because Dreamworks decided to use a stand-in for the Samara scenes.

The result is a mess, horrible and unneeded visual effects, flat characters and bad direction.

Who is the responsible? we'll never know, because Hideo Nakata did changed some things of the script, but Dreamworks made some very stupid decisions.

This movie could have been a very good one, but it was not made to satisfy audiences, it was made to make quick cash, which sadly it'll do.

Not even the excellent Naomi Watts could save this sequel, which is destined to be the worst horror sequel, since The Exorcist: The Heretic.

4/10

Having seen only the original Ringu, I have just experienced the double feature of Ring one and two, which was absolutely fantastic. Not being a fan of horror movies, cold sweat broke out at the previews but I went anyway. And I don't regret it! After seen the American version, which was different in subtle details, Ring two begins where Ring one ends. The mother and her son had just copied the tape and flied to a different place. But soon, far too soon, kids start to die having the same distorted faces. But this time it is not only that Samara wants to be heart, she wants to LIVE, and had chosen the boy to do so. The only way to prevent this is also the only thing she is not prepared to do.

The speed of this movie is thrilling, and before you recover from the last shock, the next one is waiting. In contrary to the first Ring, which was scary, but had not much of a story, this one is more mysterious, and it unfolds before your very eyes. Of course there are some shock moments but try to look anyway, or else you miss the beautiful details of the movie. Especially the scene with the reindeer was mind-boggling. Go, see, and enjoy!

review_title: Ring Three I Hope to God There Isn't!
review_detailed_main: The Ring Two wasn't even sub par compared to the first one. The plot was all over the place, suspense was obvious, and the whole water symbolism was ridiculously overdone. I didn't understand why the deer were incorporated, because they just looked fake. This movie only made me aggravated not frightened. I waited nearly an hour in a half outside of the show waiting to get in to see this movie hoping that it lived up to its expectations, but after seeing it i would have rather waited an hour in half to go see the Pacifier. I would recommend anyone who liked the first Ring to not go and see the second because you will look down at this film in shame.

Short and to the point comment.

PRO's- i cant think of any pro's about this movie.

CON's- its not scary, story is no good, the kid tries to scare but fails... just painful to watch a bad movie.

This movie is an example of many sequels that was riding the popularity of the first movie.

This made my brother not scared of the Ring 1.

My niece who is 8 years old thought it was a comedy at first.

Then she said it was a mystery.

She is correct. Its a mystery why this movie is even called a horror movie. Its a mystery why this actually passed the board of reviewers and made it into the theaters.

Rachel and Aidan Keller (again played by Naomi Watts and David Dorfiman) are starting to make a new life for themselves. They have left Seattle behind and all the painful memories created by their battle with Samara. They move to a new, small town where Rachel becomes editor and nothing much ever happens. But when a teen winds up dead and Samara's old M.O. seems to be behind it, Rachel must find a way to stop Samara and uncover her origins to save Aidan's life.

Hideo Nakata takes the reigns this time around. You think that with as good as his direction on the original Ringu was that it would at least be on par with that. Sadly it's not the case. There were a few cool sequences (the deer attack, the bath scene and a sequence in the well toward the end) but sadly the suspense is sorely lacking and the overall photography is a bit bland. The script is probably the weakest problem. They should have waited until they fully cooked up an interesting plot but what you get is a lot of derivative rehash and even the bits of Samara's origin just seems tired and not very well thought out. Watts goes through the paces as a mommy in peril and Dorfiman can play creepy kid like nobody else's business. I am very fond of the first one but the second one seemed cursed from the get-go. 6/10

When it comes to horror films, sequels are usually very dangerous propositions (just look at the Halloween or Saw franchises). Fortunately, director Hideo Nakata follows the original "Ring" tale with another frightening, mind-bending tale.

For a basic plot summary, "The Ring 2" sees Rachel (Naomi Watts) and Aidan (David Dorfman) on the run from the ghost of Samara. Of course, just when they think they are in the clear, the spirit of the long-haired little girl returns to wreak more havoc. While trying to put an end to Samara once and for all, Rachel must delve even deeper into her past to find the key to her destruction.

This movie is really a tale of two halves. The first half falls a bit flat because it is basically an extension of the original (visits from Samara, exposition about the haunted videotape, etc.). However, the second hour of the movie redeems itself by delving into more original material, that being the origins of Samara. By that time, the sheer creepiness of Samara was starting to get a little thin, so an origins tale was a good idea.

Overall, "Ring 2" is a very satisfying sequel that breaks new ground while still managing to provide some genuine new scares. If not for a bit of a repetitive first hour, this part two would have eclipsed the original.

When this movie came out to theater, my friend and her friends were deciding on a movie to watch since we were at the theater anyways. I didn't want to watch this, not because I was scared but because I knew I wouldn't like it. I nearly fell asleep during The Ring 1. Since I was around people that I hardly knew, except for one person I didn't feel like it was my place to object so I decided, what the hell, I'll tag along.

Now can someone explain to me how a scary movie can make you laugh? The cheesy dialogs, the bad acting, the cheesy dialogs, those stupid deers, and did I mention the cheesy dialogs? I'm not much of a scary movie fanatic, the only scary movies that managed to scare me were The Exorcist and the Shining. I've seen a fair amount of scary movies and most of them pretty much, how you say, blow. But this one...(and the first one)...they pretty much take the cake. OK, no scratch that, Darkness was worst. But Ring 2 didn't do the concept of scary movies any justice.

I will never be a scary movie fanatic and this movie will still blow.

It wasn't as good as the first one, but it was still great. It was, of course, very scary and horrifying. The deer scene completely through me off and I still don't understand it. It was really random. I liked the bathroom effect with the water coming from above. The beginning was great because it picked up right where it left off. Towards the end, it all cuts off and the screen goes black. Do not fear, that was not the end. That would really suck if it was. The ending was pretty good and I don't expect a third. I think it will be way overdone if there is. There is still some great twists and turns to be figured out. It was worth my time and my money. I wouldn't watch it again but I was satisfied with it.

I would really like to know who the reviewer is that wrote it is "scarier then the first," because this movie was no where near suspenseful or frightening, let alone, scary. It has to be the worst movie I have ever had the displeasure of sitting through. First the dialogue. The lines Naomi had to utter were so inane. It was pure formula. I can not imagine the pitch session for this turkey. The whole premise of calling her "Mom" vs. "Rachel," was so obvious and blatant that a first grader would've gotten it after the first 2 seconds. The scares were not. There were no surprises in this film other then the cameo work of familiar actors who have all been in better films with much better dialogue and acting. Why Elizabeth Perkins stooped to appear in this bomb is beyond me. Sissy Spacek, in the worst wig since Elvira, is out right laughable. I would highly recommend anyone who wants to see this because the first one scared them, as it did me, to pass or wait until the DVD comes out and rent it and then utilize the fast forward button on their machine to bypass a really forgettable waste of celluloid.

If I could have given this movie zero stars I would not have hesitated to do so. Renting this movie might be the thing I regret most in my life.

The Ring is a good movie. The story is interesting, you care about the characters, and in turn feel invested in the story.

The Ring Two is a terrible movie. It has nearly nothing to do with the first one. I did not care at all what was happening on the screen, mostly because NOTHING OF CONSEQUENCE EVER HAPPENED. It did not help that I watched the unrated version, which includes 18 extra minutes of mind numbing film. My brother, who was watching the movie with me, fell asleep halfway through the film not because he was tired, but because he was that bored.

I have never endured a longer 2 hours in my relatively short life. The worst $5 I have ever spent.

For some reason I thought this film was terrible when I was a kid and saw it. My opinion now as an adult has COMPLETELY reversed. This film for me has improved with age.

As a kid of the 90s, I was obsessed with the American remake of the Ring. I remember as a kid, not enjoying this sequel much at all. I found it was too different of a formula than the original would set you up for to expect. I didn't care for it.

Now as an adult, my interest in this series has been rekindled entirely over the last several months. I found myself re-watching the American remake with a renewed interest, following it up by re-watching the Japanese versions of Ringu.

I even did research on the book and the differences in the lore. Which led me to re-watch the Ring Two for the first time since release and give it a second opinion.

I have to say I enjoyed this film far, far more now as an adult, that I can appreciate it so much more than I did as a kid. I think learning context behind the books and Japanese films really helped me appreciate Hideo Nakata's return to this series with this film.

The cgi has it's weaknesses, but the story for me was so much fun. Gripping, and unexpected. It's a different formula than the original film and I appreciate it so much more now that I could watch it with a refreshed eye.

The originals are so good and well paced that it's just difficult to live up to that formula in a story that progresses indefinitely.

Now the parts I was not crazy about: The setting is not as aesthetic this time around, and neither is the editing, particularly towards the end, things could have used more set design and editing. The editing was lacking a bit of polish, but overall, this exceeded my expectations a second time around far more than I expected.

I completely understand why this film won't live up to the expectations of the first one, but I find it has improved with age. The actors are creepy enough to give it life, and the plot somehow vile enough to disturb. Samara is even more sinister in this one, and sneakier.

There were chunks of the plot that went completely over my head when I saw this as a kid, and I only appreciate Hideo Nakata's efforts here even more now.

I'm obsessed with this series and the Japanese ones and am glad I could revisit this one. The unrated version.

After surviving their encounter with vengeful Samara and her cursed video tape, Rachel and her son move to a new town, but Samara isn't finished terrorizing them and wants to possess her son.

Bringing back the original Japanese director for this sequel sounds like a great idea, but The Ring Two ends up being the most misguided and least frightening sequel since Exorcist II. None of the scares work, the plot is convoluted, and many of the scare sequences are ruined by cheesy CGI like a sequence involving computer animated deer that ram into Rachel's car.

In most cases sequels aren't better than the first film. This is the case for this film. It's still good though but it doesn't compare to the first. However, if you weren't comparing films this was a great film and the plot was great. You'd definitely need to watch the first film first but then again I like to watch films in chronological order so you probably could watch it out of order but you'd miss key facts but it'd still be manageable.

review_title: The first one didn't deserve a sequel.
review_detailed_main: Although it was decent, the first one was overrated. This one just sucked. It wasn't scary at all, it had no story, the acting was bad, the deer part was ridiculous, it had nothing new to offer, the ending was laughable, it was just all around terrible. I have to wite 10 lines so ill just say go see Hostage instead, it was a million times better, if that doesn't fill your shock needs then check out Saw, Exorcist the Beginning, and of course the original, you cant beat that, Sphere, and anything from M. Night. I give this a 0 out of a 10, they shouldve let Gore come back if he wanted to, which i doubt, he is too good a director to waste is time on this, thank god he is sticking with Pirates instead of freaky little TV chicks.

review_title: Not as good as the first movie
review_detailed_main:
To put it simply, The Ring 2 is not as good as The Ring. This is for a variety of reasons, but most of all it's because the plot was nowhere near as good. There were several events within the film that weren't convincing because it just wouldn't have happened. I guess you could argue that the situation with Samara would never have happened anyway because the paranormal isn't real, but even if that situation WAS real, then there are several events that just wouldn't have happened, such as the deer crowding around the car, and the kid standing in front of the mirror and taking loads of photos instead of just running away from the figure like any normal kid would.

Anyway, despite it being somewhat unconvincing, I rated it 7/10 because it was still quite scary, and overall I would recommend it to people who have seen the first movie, simply because it is nice to continue the story.

review_title: (6 out of 10?) It's as good as the first one
review_detailed_main:
It's a shame how blind people can be when they judge a sequel - they say it's nothing new, nothing original, but it just shows how little they saw in the first movie to begin with. If someone says there's nothing new in The Ring Two, it means he just saw Samara Morgan's scary posture and nothing more in "The Ring", because that's the only thing the two films have in common. The truth is, The Ring Two is one of the most original sequels ever, and it offers a whole new, and most importantly, an unexpected story to the viewer. Certainly not what he'd expect if he'd seen the Japanese sequels (Ring 0, Rasen, Spiral, etc.), which were all incredible flops. The Ring Two is simply

As good as the first one...

and certainly no flop. It's about all that can be said. This movie is about as good as The Ring and (sorry), better than Ringu. The Ring Two is certainly not as innovative as the first one, but then, does it need to be? It's simply a good movie that deserves to be seen, no matter what you've heard about it. Well, it's true that this film includes one of the worst movie lines ever said, but, oh well... Just see it.

This movie was OK. There wasn't much of a plot and it seemed like the writer had a bunch of different ideas for the second movie and tried to fit them all together.It kept jumping from one idea to another and it didn't really make sense. I thought the movie was pretty boring and i didn't find it scary.There was only one gross part.There wasn't any suspense like the first movie. You could kind of guess whats going to happen. The first movie was better, and i think that they should not have added a sequel.Nothing really interesting happened in this movie and at the theater i was at some people left and the rest just started talking half way through the movie. I wouldn't say this was a bad movie, but I wouldn't recommend it.

I seriously thought i would never watch another film again after watching this utter trash... it has to be the weakest plot since The Smokers.

I enjoyed the first film (The Ring) which had a cult feel to it, although the original Japanese version had far more atmosphere. The Ring Two had zero atmosphere. They didn't even bother changing any of the scenery or costumes. Its almost like the filmed both at the same time.

I wish i had something positive to say about this film and I am racking my brains trying to think of something...but i can't! It just reaffirms the general belief that sequels do not work.

Please, if you have any sense avoid at all costs 0/10

It seems to be popular by Hollywood now-days to do re-makes of foreign classic films. This time ring two has been re-made and I must say even if it doesn't really live up to the first one it's still far more better than the grudge (with I think they just totally blew into the pan with the American version) oh well this is about ring two and not the grudge.

the effects ain't that bad that some ppl might say. they are creep and just looking at the audience sitting in their chairs go "aw.. oh.. iih" it doesn't take a master brain to understand that this film goes under the skin on most people. story wise its a bit mediocre comparing to the first one.. though I believe its kinda hard to really make a film like the ring to have a good follow-up anyway, they deal with a subject I kinda of like. supernatural in a weird TV way =)

The Ring 2 was so bad it made u think number one was bad like the part with the deer that was awkward. The Ring was awesome and really scary the scariest thing was Samara in number 2 shes not scary at all I don't know how but they managed to turn the sequel for the ring which was awesome to crap. The Ring 2 was bad in lots of ways I really wanted to see number 2 but now I wish I didn't because its a waste of time and money even if you get it for free its a big waste of time! But the good thing is that its not to predictable. I didn't expect what happened at the end would happen but there was a couple of creepy parts like the part where Samara was crawling up the well chasing Rachelle and when the boy looked in the mirror and saw Samara and started taking pictures of the mirror. So I give the Ring 2 a 1 because its so bad

review_title: I love Horror films but much prefer the contents of my baby's diaper to this poo-poo!
review_detailed_main: The original RING in 2002 was genuinely creepy and one of the scariest films Hollywood has put out in years. I cannot comment on RINGU or RINGU 2 cause I didn't see them but WOW...this film was bad, not the slightest bit creepy and it looked like a bad, low-budget 80's b-movie. I am an official movie addict with my favorite genre being HORROR so I rarely, almost never walk out of a movie but I had to leave this one. I could feel the minutes slipping away that I could be enjoying with my wife and one year old, so I left. I gave it a solid hour to bore me out of my mind, that's a fair chance...isn't it? Sometimes Hollywood feels if they put enough money into fire F/X and water dripping upwards F/X then a movie will be instantly creepy, well it doesn't always work. My hint to the filmmakers...try a good script and maybe a good director, like Gore Verbinski. For true scares and creepy chills rent the classic ghost story from 1979 starring George C Scott named THE CHANGELING. And so you don't feel so sorry for me, I did get money back...I said I had an important call and it worked. Thank you AMC theaters!

review_title: The Ring 2 is an interesting film and very, very scary.
review_detailed_main: I have seen the movie and I liked it very much. I've written a comment on it in Dutch (movie2movie.nl)and I gave it four points out of five. To my surprise there seem to be many viewers hating it. At first I couldn't understand why. But slowly I'm beginning to see the reason. The Ring Two is a very scary and a very gloomy movie. The atmosphere is not really uplifting. The greatest goal of a Japanese director is not to make everyone walk out of a theater feeling happy. That's for Hollywood directors. This is not a stupid teen-movie, this is more or less a work of art. It is not made to make you feel good. It is meant to leave you scared en bewildered. And if it does so and you don't like that, you are missing the whole point of movie-making at all.

After moving to a new city to get away from the curse, a reporter and her son finds that a series of deaths similar to the earlier rampage by the evil spirit they encountered is returning to target her son to try to get out in the world, leading to a desperate battle to save him before it's too late.

Even though this film wasn't really needed, it did have a few redeeming factors. One of the better factors here is the fact that this one puts a nicer emphasis on the physical threat that was barely hinted at before. With the targets having survived from before and are well aware of what can happen, the sense of her looming over them from the start with the nightmares he keeps having or the hallucinations of the girl around the apartment trying to get at them which results in the appearance of the different portals to the alternate world she inhabits. That brings the other attacks she has, from the dream scare of appearing in the TV set to the chilling appearance in the bathroom as the manipulation of the water trinkets around the room for a strong chilling sequence and, into a rather strong and somewhat enjoyable series of scenes to highlight the supernatural threat present here. The other instances of supernatural activity here work nicely, as the deer attack on the car was pretty suspenseful, and while it was set up beforehand, it was still a shock to see it staged as well as the scene in the hospital that is pretty cool to watch. It's only other positive element is the ending twist was really surprising, and it comes off as one of the best scenes in the film, giving this enough to really hold itself up over it's few main flaws. The biggest factor against this is that the movie just doesn't scare at all. The few attempts at scares were telegraphed so far in advance that they missed the point entirely or the shock just wasn't effective to really register. That is perhaps the worst thing to happen to a film, which is that the scares it's attempting don't register. The film also had a whole heartlessness to it all that makes it feel like it was just made for no real reason. It wasn't that emotionally connected with anything, and that left the film feeling bland. Coupled that with no scares and only a couple weak action scenes along the way, this was just a dull movie. Abandoning the concept of the connection to the cursed videotape and turning into a dull, weak investigation makes for a wholly slow-going effort that rarely contains the wholesale ingredients of the series with that type of setup. With the added fact that the film is rated so low also being a weak sign, meaning that the scares, what little there are, and the violence being so tone-downed that any steam is effectively neutered by having to be scaled back in their intensity. This was all around a disappointment.

Rated PG-13: Violence, Language and children-in-danger.

review_title: Mocks Original 'The Ring' More Brutally Than Scary Movie 3!
review_detailed_main: Here it comes, the long-awaited sequel to the one of the most overrated, but still watchable & pretty scary though, Japanese-gone-Hollywood horror 'The Ring'... But, oops! Something doesn't fit, something hasn't worked out... Something? Hmm... Everything in the movie fails! Let's admit it, the story of 'The Ring' was very very questionable! Huge plot holes were here & there. But compared to this masterpiece of human brain disorder - the first Ring's story was as well put together as it gets, since 'The Ring Two' hasn't got any kind of combination of logical thoughts on which the movie is based, which I could force myself to call with such a word as 'story'. 'The Ring Two' is just one huge gaping plot hole, featuring a bunch of stale clichés & pitiful dialogs. Most of the parts, which were supposed to be horrifying were welcomed with viewers ironic laughter. Idiotic scenes in abundance here (just remember the sequence with the deers). OK, the direction is awful too! As you remember 'The Ring', despite above-mentioned plot holes was scary. As I think not only due to the writing, but mainly direction. The atmosphere of the film was heavy, dark, gloomy. Here we see quite the opposite: a lovely small town, optimistic view of the loony bin, even the house, where Samara used to live looks like a wonderful country home & not like a scary place it was in 'The Ring'. Seriously, even minors won't find a flick like this scary! The visuals... Well, to say that they are bad is to say nothing. The visuals are awful, truly primitive & not scary! Seriously the visuals in 'Charmed' look good compared to this one. Acting is as poor as it gets. Not believable: it is rather overacting we see or no acting at all. No acting at all is better I gotta say. Had this movie come out earlier, the Scary Movie 3 would've been totally unsuitable as a parody for 'The Ring'... Disgusting attempt to make more money by the studio bosses. Wait until the flick is on TV. It won't take long, trust me.

review_title: One of the worst films I've saw.
review_detailed_main:
This film was just another reason why films shouldn't be remade. Especially Asian Horror movies. Granted the first remake was decent but this was just awful. The plot was shallow, there was no scare factor and they drained the TV thing. It's just not scary any more. This was a major let down and when it boils down to it was one of the worse movies I've saw in a long time. It just plain bored me to the very end. The acting wasn't great especially during the deer scene which in it's self was a farce. To anyone who is a fan of the original 3 and even the first remake your going to be very very disappointed.

The ending was rather predictable and the film as a whole helps to discard of that x factor the previous ring films had. In my opinion they give far too much of the background away, taking away from the mystery surrounding the whole story. I'd recommend not going to see this film as you'll only end up disappointed.

review_title: Excellent follow-up for those who liked "The Ring."
Well thought out movie different then #1 /

review_detailed_main:
When I loaded the IMDb page for The Ring Two, the headlining comment at the time stated that it lacks everything that made the first American adaptation good. I agree with this sentiment. What makes it ironic is that Hideo Nakata, the esteemed director of Ringu, was brought in to direct this mess. The presence of one name in the credits, however, brings me to believe that the overall mess has to do with the screenplay. You guessed it, Ehren Kruger, the man who first came into prominence with Scream 3, wrote The Ring Two. Granted, he also wrote the first American adaptation of the Japanese Ringu films, but director Gore Verbinski was able to wrestle a decent final product out of his raw material. It appears that Hideo Nakata thought he was up to the task of wrestling a decent end product out of Ehren Kruger's writing. He proved himself quite wrong. The actors do the best they can, and David Dorfman does a lot less sleepwalking in this episode, but I believe this film can be credited with killing off any chance of further Ringu adaptations.

Of course, the acting is good enough to pass muster, as was the case in the previous Ring. Naomi Watts is a surprisingly competent actor, given that her credits include a stint on the Australian soapie I like to call Please Go Away. Once again, she goes through the standard motions expected of a Scream Queen with championship pride. All the clichés are present and accounted for, but she shrugs them off like she is right at home in her environment. Then again, when one has worked for David Lynch, I suppose even creepy scenes such as the emergences of Samara from the TV set seem routine. However, when you get right down to it, Watts is the only real star in the film. Much was made of Sissy Spacek's role in the film, but it has turned out to be one of the most overstated walk-ons in the history of the genre. It was not until I viewed the IMDb credits for the film that I was even aware of her appearance in the film. David Dorfman, as previously intimated, has been given less of a zombie-like appearance in this film, but in so doing, his character also becomes a lot less interesting.

The visual effects of the previous Ring were mainly limited to one instance of a girl crawling out of the television set, combined with some practical effects or trick editing. In this sequel, there are endless shots of water flowing in unnatural directions, people being sucked in and out of televisions, or people polymorphing. The plot feels like a blur, and I was only able to catch fragments relating to some lost relative of Samara's or how she is able to torment the family in spite of all the conditions being met in the first film for her to leave them be. In short, I was given little reason to care about the machinations that the central characters go through this time. Without a decent character to hang our cares upon, the film's sense of horror or terror literally falls apart. It does not help that we have no idea what the framework of rules regarding what Samara can or cannot do is meant to be.

As I said, a previous commentator has stated that The Ring Two lacks everything that made The Ring good. Suspense? It is on the cutting room floor. Terror? The framework for it was never there to begin with. Horror? It appears the director would not know it if they were formally introduced. New lead Simon Baker tries his best, but Martin Henderson, his equivalent in the first American film, was able to make us care about his character. Partly because the screenplay seemed to be coherent, but also because he is able to act the part without resorting to cliché. Simon Baker is swimming uphill against a director who does not seem to care about building a structured plot, and a screenplay that has him speaking so unnaturally it is a wonder he did not cough up a boot during his scenes with David Dorfman. No matter how I try, I cannot think up a simple cause and effect pattern to the events in the film. It is literally a collage of scenes that are meant to be horrifying, but have no framework on which to hang.

It is for this reason that I am giving The Ring Two a two out of ten. It is bad. Not bad enough to be good, but not good enough to be entertaining, either. It literally winds up in no man's land. See it if you can get it for free, but if there is something better on, such as a collection of You Can't Do That On Television repeats, watch that instead.

The Ring 2 isn't as bad as some people say it is. It is almost same as first one. The concept and plot was almost same.

The plot is a little more simple than the first one and there are a few places in the movie that could've been better, but it's still a good movie. The movie starts off in a similar way to the first film. After that there are some things that are a little to much like the first. The story starts out really well as I said the plot is kind of simple but its set out so that it takes a while to see the whole picture. There are some parts with CGI effects that aren't needed. Half way through it gets really good, you don't know whats happening and you don't know how they're going to stop it. After that it gets a bit obvious and kinda hurried.

Overall, see this film for your self. Yes movie doesn't offer you anything new as it seems copy of first part only but you will not regret watching it.

review_title: Effective, but suffers from sequel syndrome
Lame Sequel, no attempt at anything new
review_detailed_main:
In order to have a good sequel you can't just rehash old material. The audience has seen it already and wants to see something better, or at least different.

I can think of so many ways in which this movie could have been good. My friend and I discussed so many different changes that this movie needed, and how we could have made them better, and we are not scriptwriters. How can movie makers just say OK to lame attempts like this. They know we liked the first one or we would never have gone back for seconds. Take some time, get a second or third rewrite and get back to us. Don't just rush to put anything out. JEES!

Rachel and Aiden have relocated to a sleepy town in the Pacific Northwest, but unfortunately another tape resurfaces. Why Rachel is surprised, after the brilliant pre-apocalyptic final scene in the first film, is way beyond me. In fact, the main problem with "The Ring Two" seems to be that Nakata never sat down and watched the US remake of his "Ringu." Still, it isn't nearly as bad of a film as many have suggested. It has a unique directorial style and features a great performance by Naomi Watts, which doesn't seem rushed even though she didn't want to make the film due to a busy schedule. Unfortunately, the other bigger names in the film (Sissy Spacek, Simon Baker, Elizabeth Perkins) are nothing more than glorified cameos. The short film "Rings," which is included on the DVD, is required viewing before watching this sequel.

STAR RATING:*****Unmissable****Very Good***Okay**You Could Go Out For A Meal Instead*Avoid At All Costs

Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts) and her young son Aidan (David Dorfman) relocate six months after the horrific events of the first film.When a local teen dies after seeing the tape,however,she destroys it,little knowing of the horrific events that will now transpire.

I was a bit of a late bloomer to the original Ring movie,but I could appreciate what a fine piece of horror movie-making it was.So,in essence,I really should have guessed before-hand that a sequel would be a sad and desperate attempt to cash in on the original's success,and that the law of diminishing sequels would have returned.

This is yet another one of those sequels that blatantly re-hashes the first film.The plot this film does have is boring,pointless and full of bone-head implausibilities.The script and the dialogue are very weak,episodic,mundane,by-the-numbers stuff all the way.Whereas the original skillfully orchestrated some clever shocks and jump scenes,the shocks that this film seems to think are 'scary' actually end up coming across as very funny and you can't help but giggle at them.Not one scene scared me or made me jump out my skin in any way.

In the lead role,Watts appears irritated and bored by her role,and is clearly only as in it for the cash as everyone else is.Or maybe she's just getting fed up with the irritatingly bratty Dorfman,like a Macaulay Culkin in Home Alone on re-play.

Ultimately,The Ring Two is yet another inferior sequel to a brilliant original film.It is about the quality of a video sequel,in fact and,had the Ring franchise not been so popular,one could only guess that is where it would be heading.*

review_title: Lacks the mystery of the original, but makes up for it with the horror.

review_detailed_main:
Our protagonists Rachel and Aidan Keller are back. I needn't explain the plot of this sequel because if you saw this one, then you probably had to have already seen the original (or the Japanese version "Ringu"). This horror film occasionally cheats with its plot-contrivances and rules set firmly in the previous 'Ring' movie... for instance, once you burn the videotape, isn't that ugly and wet ghost-girl supposed to have been gone for good?

The Open House Sequence: Even though I firmly realized that I was only watching a work of outlandish fiction, I still find it extremely difficult to believe a complete stranger would allow me to rummage in the basement, left unattended for an uncomfortable amount of time, and given plenty of time to steal incriminating evidence--regardless of the fact that the person showing the home was innocent. I mean, who in their right mind has this much faith in complete strangers... who cares how beautiful or innocent some country-folk look.

I want to continue by saying "I really liked this film." That may be hard to believe after you read what I'm about to say about it in this review...

American filmmakers--Horror filmmakers particularly--have always had the habit of adopting foreign film techniques and stories, and recycling them for the American market... This is nothing new, and it's not been a secret... Filmmakers copy from the French, the Japanese, et al. and we gleefully empty our pockets to get a gander at foreign product recycled, repackaged (and re-cast) for American eyes.

Which is to say that, to my understanding, the original Japanese "Ringu" DVD (or Video)can be found at your neighborhood Blockbuster and (to my understanding) was not released in American-soil theaters in its original Japanese version.

Soon, we will truly and completely know who Naomi Watts actually is (if we haven't already met her in previous American-movie outings such as that 'Mullholland' movie directed by David Lynch) when she graces the big-screen in Peter Jackson's "King Kong" remake this December 2005. If we didn't hear her scream loud enough in "The Ring" or "The Ring 2", then we'll definitely hear her fictional-cries for help when a 40-foot-tall gorilla wraps its horny fingers around her lithe and winsome frame.

OK, like I thought it would be with any sequel, this one is less good than the 1st movie.

Th good things about it ( at least, what I found good) : 1. The story do continues from where it left in the first movie. As I saw the Ring last night, the Ring 2 was really natural in its line of story. 2. Good that they had the chance to work with the same kid and Rachel 3. The story of Samara girl is kinda explained further which is good, but then...

I found it not so good that they did not explain the background story more. Also, I think the whole thing about coming into the house of your colleague from work and do feel like you're at your own was a bit ... unrealistic. Even more, that she did not do a single thing when he died! Also, the kid walks out of the hospital just like that and no one from there tries to find him?! I mean, there are several other minor things which were kinda off ... But, all in all, it is not that it makes this sequel less interesting and good. There were no suspense like there was in the original / first movie. That lowers the rating for this one ( I gave an eight for The Ring).

It is not bad, but it is not as good as the first one for sure. So, I'm gonna go with rating five!

review_title: Definitely Scary & Unpredictable. Your phone may ring as soon as you watch it... ;)
review_detailed_main:
Plot Outline: Six months after the experience with the cursed videotape that kills people within a week of watching it, Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts) and her son Aidan (David Dorfman) move to the small town to start afresh. However, the soul of Samara is back with a bigger and scarier challenge for Rachel and Aidan who battle for their lives yet again.

Comment: Hideo Nakata, who made his American Debut with the "The Ring" based on Japanese "Ringu" has proved his scare value yet again. The Japanese scary flicks have provided inspiration for many other horror/thrillers across the world and this is no exception. Performances of Naomi Watts and David Dorfman carry you well through the movie. I think Dorfman was a notch better than the once-Oscar-nominated Watts. SFX are done seamlessly.

Although the Screenplay is well written and is unpredictable, it could have been bettered upon to match the levels of the first Ring. Nevertheless, it's quite usual that sequels don't usually match up to the original. But this shouldn't deter you from watching the movie. The best executed scene is the bathtub one seen in the trailer. The unpredictability of the sequences can give real creeps!

Rating: 3/5

The Ring is one of my two favorite horror movies of all time. A true classic, one everyone should see who likes the genre should see. The Ring Two, however, is one of the worst movies I've seen in a long time. The movie has a very thin plot, what little bit of plot their is doesn't really make sense and is scatterbrained, there's no flow to the movie and the editing was poor, there's very little interesting that happens, virtually everything is derivative of the first movie, the dialog is week, and even the acting is poor. No characters are developed in the movie at all; the mother and son were both developed in the first movie, and nothing new is added to what we know about them or their relationship. Even the son, who did a fine job of acting in the first movie, seems like he's all too conscious of how deadpan and serious he was in the first movie and is trying too hard to "act" a certain way in this movie; it shows. The only bright spots in the movie are Naomi Watts, who continues to be one of the best actresses around, and a few surprise moments (but they are very few). I really feel like I wasted my money. I found myself looking for the fast forward button. My closest comparison of how I feel is how I felt after seeing Highlander and then Highlander 2: forget Highlander 2 ever existed, which is exactly what the later Highlander movies and the TV show did. Forget about The Ring Two.

I thought they did a very good job with this movie. The fact that it was a different director may throw a lot of people off of this one. The style was a little different and a little cheesy at times but overall I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone that likes the typical horror genre. I also thought that David Dorfman did a wonderful job in this one. He was more believable in the second one then he was in the first one I thought. He is getting kinda old and in this one he was almost to old but he still pulled it off for me. I just wish they would have came out with the second one a little faster. In this one they never had to introduce anything or anyone so they got right down to the action right away. The end keeps you going and was done very good. Overall I really liked it, maybe not quite as good as the first one but sequels are never as good as the original.

Laughably bad. it's kind of crazy how hard of a turn this second movie took. they got the director of the original japanese version and he does a terrible job in this movie. the biggest offense is the fact that the scary moments are not scary at all. they are so poorly done. the story is straight madness and it's really boring. they try to make up a new mystery but it feels forced and half-assed. es el terrible. and i didn't even realize i watched it when it first came out, probably in theaters, until i got to the bath tub scene, which was the only cool part of the movie, even though it was madness. speaking of which, i think the director was so excited to have a larger budget than his normal japanese movies (i'm guessing), that he went crazy with the amount of CGI he used. some of it is decent, some is terrible. but there was really no need for a lot of it. i think the first one barely had any (2 viewings)

I never expected this movie to blow me away. In fact, i was ready to be very disappointed. But (gasp) i wasn't. I really quite enjoyed The Ring 2, and even though it was in a totally different league to the original remake, i was entertained.

Why? Well, in The Ring, we got too little Samara for my liking, as she only really came into play in the last 10 or 15 minutes. But in the sequel, she comes back in good form and we see things from her perspective. The bit at the start (if you've seen it, you'll know what i'm talking about)after the opening scene made everyone in the room jump right out of their seats, an that impressed me, because i didn't see it coming. Sissy Spacek's cameo was a great treat at that point in the movie and she fits in well with the character.

But as with any movie, it has its flaws. For one, those ridiculous deer. They had the whole cinema in ructions of laughter, which really destroyed the atmosphere. Another qualm would be the fact that sometimes there can be a lapse in dialogue, where the actors struggle to deliver a badly written line, and its glaringly obvious when it occurs. But my main complaint is the general lack of fear. It doesn't take a lot to get me scared, but Samara failed to deliver the scares she rightly deserved, and for this, i felt a little ripped off.

All in all, like many sequels, The Ring Two is inferior to the original, but its by no means a bad film. The reason i think that its been getting such low marks is because its being compared to its predecessors. In comparison, its not so good, but as a stand alone, i think its an okay movie.

As useless and unnecessary sequels go, The Ring Two isn't half bad. It has some interesting and surprising twists and a few visual highlights which keep you on your toes. Unfortunately, as a horror film, it isn't particularly scary. You can only show the dark-haired girl with the water-logged complexion so many times before the fright effect wears off.

The story picks up a few months after the events of the first film as Rachel (Naomi Watts) and her young son Aidan (David Dorfman) have moved to a small town in order to distance themselves from the horrors they experienced in Seattle. Unfortunately, as luck would have it (or sequels would), trouble has followed them there. A copy of the infamous videotape has shown up accompanied by the usual mayhem that results 7 days after viewing it. Of course, Rachel and her son are the only remaining experts on the phenomenon, and she is determined to bring the curse to an end.

Unfortunately, Rachel's efforts only serve to further anger woman-child Samara Morgan, that plucky young ghost determined to punish everyone for her untimely death. It appears that Samara has now decided to return to the world of the living, using young Aiden as the destination vessel. This presents real problems for his mother who must alternately love and fear her only child.

Additional details of Samara's childhood are revealed as Rachel is determined to find out what motivates her. Rachel discovers that Samara's birth mother is still alive. A bit of stunt casting is involved here but I won't tell you who. However, the effect isn't quite as cool as the filmmakers probably intended.

Despite the lack of genuine scariness, the film does have it's chilling moments. In particular, there is a scene involving an attack by wild animals that is both surprising and visually stunning. And, on occasion, Samara's grim form can evoke some real chills, especially a scene in which we see her scale the wall of the circular well in which she was originally entombed.

Naomi Watts does a fine job portraying the plucky young mother determined to do anything to save her son. David Dorfman, as the beleaguered young Aiden, is called upon to do a bit more acting than the first film required, and I think he is well on his way to being a worthy second tier successor to Haley Joel Osment in the kid acting department. Simon Baker, from the TV series The Guardian, is on hand as Rachel's new boss. I find it interesting that two of the leading players are Australians pretending to be American, while the film's director is Japanese. Hideo Nakata was responsible for directing the original Japanese versions of The Ring and its sequel, known as Ringu and Ringu 2.

Although not as scary as the original, this is still a pretty solid film, especially for a sequel. My grade: B-
This is lifeless and stale follow up compared to original and it doesnt live up to it in slitless

Director: Hideo Nakata, Novel: Koji Suzuki, Script: Ehren Kruger, Cast: Naomi Watts, David Dorfman, Simon Baker, Elizabeth Perkins, Gary Cole, Sissy Spacek.

After the phenomenal success of The Ring, a sequel was inevitable. This time around, Hideo Nakata, the director of the original Japanese Ringu, was brought in. Naomi Watts and David Dorfman reprise their roles as Rachael and Aiden. This film was a true sequel in the sense that it does continue the story and not just repeat the same story again. Rachael took her son Aiden and moved from Seattle to start a new life in Astoria, Oregon. She now works as a reporter for a small newspaper there.

When she investigates the death of a local teenage boy, she soon finds out that the notorious video tape was involved. Her nightmare is about to begin again! She goes to the house where the boy was killed to retrieve the tape which she burns. That evil girl spirit Samara is not content being a ghost. She wants to have a physical body and a mommy so she takes possession of Aiden.

I felt this to be a decent follow up to the first film. While it doesn't capture the same creepiness and atmosphere of the first it does have its moments. Rainy, gloomy Astoria is a great location choice for such a film. I thought the scene in the restroom at the bazaar where Samara takes possession of Aiden was creepy. Also, the rather unique deer scene. Nakata and Kruger tried to give the audience a little more information on the background of Samara in this film, although it is all rather underdeveloped. In the previous, it was revealed that she was adopted. This time the identity of her real mother is revealed( played by the great actress Sissy Spacek) and why she gave her up. Although not as good as the original, this film does continue the story of Aiden and Rachael. Some of the effects from the first film such as the girl coming out of the t.v. just isn't as scary the second time around.

"The Ring Two" is the sequel of the horror movie The Ring and in this one we are six months after the incidents involving the previous one lethal videotape and now we have some evidence which make us believe that evil is not finish but it's hiding in the darkness for one more time.

I did not like this movie as much as I liked the first one which I think that it was magnificent. The interpretations of this movie were not good, the plot and the mystery was not there, the suspense and terror also missed, and this movie called horror, no I do not think so. In my opinion "The Ring Two" was a barker and nothing more than this.

Finally I have to say that if you have watched the first movie then just do not watch this one, you will not regret it.

review_title: A fun trip down the well!

review_detailed_main:
It's not better than the first. It's not worse than the first. It almost feels like the same movie at times actually. The Ring Two is The Ring chewed up and spit out by a different director, Hideo Nakata. Nakata directed the original Ringu, the film on which The Ring is based. You can see the different take the Japanese director has on the subject matter with this. Gore Verbinski, the director of The Ring, gave us suspense, atmosphere and some scares that haunted us. Nakata focuses more on the story than trying to get us to jump out of our seats.

Rachel (Naomi Watts) and Aiden (David Dorfman) have moved from Seattle in an attempt to start their lives over without the horror of the tape. But it appears that Samara has followed them when Rachel hears about the death of a teenage boy with a distorted face. In an attempt to put an end to it once and for all, she burns the tape and calls it a night. But no, no, no, it's not that simple. Samara is back and she wants something.

Samara, although no longer played by the same girl, is as terrifying as we remember. She looks waxy, dead and demonic no matter what she does. She has as crawling under our skin in the same gross and disturbing way that she crawls from place to place. What is it about the demon child that scares us so? Is it the thought that innocence shouldn't be that evil? Whatever the strange phenomena is, it is the heart and soul of The Ring Two. The girl is the only thing that gets shivers to crawl up your spine and that's because you never saw very much of her in the first film. Here she is almost the main character. That is the problem with the sequel to a horror film. All the shocks of the original are already out in the open. We have already seen the distorted face (who can ever forget the first time they saw that?), we have already been in the bottom of the well and we have already been to the Morgan's house There is nothing new to frighten us and that is maybe why Nakata chose to focus on developing parallels between Rachel and Samara's birth mom. He makes the story more of a mystery than a horrific film full of cheap tricks.

The score is beautiful and is reminiscent of the atmosphere felt in the first film. The atmosphere, although not lacking here, is different. There are a lot more calm mysterious shots than suspenseful, seat-grippers. The whole film has a slower pace and even the ending doesn't have the hectic feel that you would expect. If you're expecting to be scared, I don't recommend this but it's not a bad way to spend two hours if you don't mind something slower. ***/*****

review_title: Oh my ... what a terrible waste of time !
Um... What the hell was that??
Not as great as the first, but still good in it's own way
Perhaps the Most Disappointing Horror Sequel since The Exorcist 2!
review_detailed_main:
When I entered the large theater that was showing 'The Ring Two' I didn't know what to expect. Whenever one goes and sees a sequel, they have to expect the likelihood of it being not as good as it's predecessor. For me, the original 2002 movie 'The Ring' was a creepy, deeply-disturbing, and fun thrill ride that had me going from start to finish. I could only hope this long-awaited follow-up would be half as spellbinding as the first, since the movie trailers made it look spectacular. I was dead wrong. This bloated, over-written, over-acted, suspense-lacking hunk of movie crap was a big waste of a beautiful Saturday afternoon.

The most disappointing aspect of this film has to be the lack of terror. The original provided me with one of the most frightening movie experiences I've had in my life, and this film didn't even get me to jump. Well, maybe I jumped once, but that is pretty pathetic for a self-described horror flick. The film's storyline borrows from almost every other horror movie from the past thirty-five years. Whether it's 'The Exorcist' (the little weird-looking kid gets possessed by Samura - oooohhh), or 'The Village of the Damned' (the possessed brat gets a perky R.N. to inject herself with an air-filled syringe). The direction of the film goes downhill, since the director of 'The Ring' , Gore Verbinski, decided to pass on this installment of the series (good move, Gore!). Verbinski (who is probably best known for his direction of 2003's big blockbuster 'Pirates of the Caribbean') provided immensely better camera work and scene transitions than this time-around's Hideo Nakata (the director of the original Japanese version of the 'The Ring' entitled 'Ringu', which also was a bit of a snorer). The acting is dreadful almost all the way around except for a decent and impassioned performance by the great Aussie actress Naomi Watts (who is way above a film like this). There are three interesting cameos in 'The Ring Two'; one by Elizabeth Perkins as the perky R.N., the second by Office Space's Gary Cole as a Realtor trying to sell the Morgan House Farm (instead of telling interested buyers that the Morgans both committed suicide because of their deranged little girl, he tells them they bought a condo in Phoenix, Arizona - HAH!). The third cameo of the film is perhaps the most noteworthy and regrettable -- Sissy Spacek (in a two minute role) as Samura's birth mother who tried to drown her twisted daughter after she botched a kitchen table abortion (no wonder the little girl is P.O'd.) It's not that Spacek does a bad job, she actually does a good job, it's just this film is unbelievably underneath the star of 'The Coal Miner's Daughter' and 'In the Bedroom'. Although most of it is disappointing, 'The Ring Two' has some very good qualities. The film's cinematography is excellent and they kept the same eerie music score that makes your skin crawl.

All in all, 'The Ring Two' isn't worth the price of admission. It isn't even worth a video rental. Wait until HBO and you won't regret it. Now, let's just pray they don't make 'The Ring Three'. If they do, might I suggest 'The Ring Three: The Bathtub Ring'. Grade: C- (screened at AMC Deer Valley 30, Phoenix, Arizona, 3/19/05)

review_title: It's not the same and...It is the same
review_detailed_main:
I went to see this movie with a lot of people. It was Friday and we were lucky to get tickets. I just went with two friends really, but I knew many of the people that were inside the room. "The ring two" generated a lot of buzz because of the success its prequel had around the world.

It started well, with a lot of images from the sea and the mountains. They didn't want us to forget about the first movie, so...They tried to achieve a way to get Samara back; so we met two persons again, watching a tape. One of them died and the other one was traumatized. Of course, this is another city, and Rachel has moved there to "start a new life", but sadly she's the only one who knows what happens; and sooner or later Samara will encounter her: "I found you".

This time around she investigates a little bit more about Samara, because now the little girl is inside of Aidan, her son; the one who seems possessed as if the movie was "The exorcist", and calls his mother by her name: "Rachel". The romantic part was occupied this time by Simon Baker, who played Max, Rachel's co-worker. He doesn't believe the story, but as the same (I'm sorry, different) character in the prequel, he will; eventually. Remember the horse in the first movie? That Rachel started to look and it became violent? Well, here we get some deers. Strange looks and violence is the result.

The performances make the movie worth to watch. I don't know if Naomi Watts should have done this, after her Oscar nomination for "21 Grams" and her performance in the very interesting "I heart Huckabees", but she didn't disappoint me at all. Her performance was strong and convincing, with all the faces and screams. David Dorfman seems to be the expert in faces, in a creepy but revealing performance. The other ones (including Simon Baker, yes) are just there to help the plot, and can't do anything about it. Although I loved to see Sissy Spacek again. I saw her a few months ago in the great "A home at the end of the world", and remembered that sometimes I forget what an excellent actress she is. The director also did a very good work, because the movie was scary enough, and he put a lot of style into it; the same didn't happen with the script.

"The ring" was a good movie, and a scary one. "The ring two" could have achieved the same objectives (or at least the first of them), but it had to be different. It wasn't.

review_title: Aidan and Rachel Relocate to a new town...
A good film. Not The Ring's sequel...
Disappointing, but I'm still really hoping for The Ring Three
review_detailed_main: Okay, so it doesn't compare to the original. I'm sure I'll get booed for saying this, but they shouldn't have let Hideo Nakata direct. I've seen the original Japanese trilogy, and I really don't think the first two were good at all ("Ringu 0" was a pleasant surprise, but doesn't come close to "The Ring"). The original installment in the American trilogy (hopefully) is one of my favorite movies. How many horror movies creep you out with symbolism? "The Ring Two" can't hold a candle to it, I'll admit that now. But, there's a bit more delving into Samara's past, which I hope will be brought to light in a third film. I'm keeping the "Scream" trilogy in mind--when I saw "Scream 2," I thought it was awful. "Scream 3" brought everything together so well that I can enjoy "2" now. I'm keeping my fingers crossed that they can do the same. I agree with Sean that David Dorfman was better in the first, but he had kind of a hammy part. Naomi Watts, on the other hand, seems to have matured as an actor. She was terrific in the first, but I thought her performance in "2" was more refined. To see, or not to see? Depends on how much you liked "The Ring." The first 5 minutes or so are pretty bad. The rest of the first half is decent. The second half of the film is actually very good; it just doesn't answer any of the questions left unanswered at the end of the first, and raises a few more. Here's a toast to "The Ring Three."

review_title: Best scary movie of the decade begets laughable sequel

review_detailed_main:
Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts) and creepy son Aidan (David Dorfman) move after the events of the first movie. But creepy girl ghost Shamara follows them for revenge...

"The Ring" itself was a pretty good ghost story. It was muddled but creepy and worked. It didn't ask for a sequel but that never stopped Hollywood. For a sequel, it's OK. It looks good and has great performances by Watts, Dorfman and Sissy Spacek (in a small but crucial role). Also the ending was pretty scary on its own. But the direction was by the numbers, there were a number of annoying "false" scares and is way too long. Also Simon Baker, Elizabeth Perkins and Gary Cole are in it--all talented actors and given nothing to do!

Still, there are worse movies--it's a painless way to waste 2 hours. And, surprisingly, there's NO setup for a third! Just OK. I give it a 6.

Best line: "I'm not your f***ing mommy!"

review_title: Oh How The Mediocre Have Fallen

review_detailed_main: Though the storyline in this sequel is not as cohesive as in "The Ring", the visual aspects of this film are stellar, perhaps even more than in the original, and hold the viewer frozen in front of the screen. The same stunning images of the original cursed tape still work perfectly and the effects used in the sequel are great. Set in Astoria, Oregon it not only is a wonderfully spooky tale, but the backdrop of the Pacific northwest is perfect. But the highlight of this film is still the incredibly spooky little girl Samara, who may be the creepiest kid since the original Exorcist ! The supplemental material "Rings" contained on the DVD is a must see after watching the movie. A fun and worthwhile watch. Be sure to see it in the dark !

Well we all wanted more.

And Ring2 locks in with Ring as chapter two of Rachel and Aden's conflict/association with Samara. Samara is a crossover in horror /parranormal. Evil yet human in desire for a life that she never had and will do anything to get.

Ring 2 has good production values. It has same atmosphere and 'feel' as the 1st movie so that if watching both in sequence there is no discontinuity.

There are less novel ideas but that is understandable in a 'sequel'. Photography is still used but such as the fly in video and warped faces seen in the ring are played down. This in my opinion is a good thing. Don't flog the horse.

Simon Baker is a welcome addition and plays a nice part in the story.

If you liked the Ring. Then watch this. It's not quite as disturbing but well worth the time to watch an fills out the storyline nicely.

PS love that tune

Nic

review_title: A lion's fist in an iron glove
review_detailed_main:
Confused? Not as much as you will be while watching this movie. And it's not even confusing in a good way like Lost Highway or Mulholland Drive (also starring the lurvly Naomi Watts). The Ring was a passable thriller that had about as much logic as my review title. None! Still, Gore Verbinski took as much advantage as he could out of that logic-free world where you can't rely on the laws of nature and physics to protect you and delivered a few iconic images and some good scares.

The Ring 2 exploits and manipulates that world and gives us loads of utterly senseless plot developments that barely connect. You won't be as scared as you will be annoyed at the increasing stupidness of the film and it's sheer reluctance to make sense. Characters are not as important as confusion. Like David Lynch himself once said 'An audience would rather be confused than bored'. I mean what purpose did the character of Max serve? None! He might as well have not been in the film at all.

Also, the 'circle' imagery hardly makes an appearance in the film at all and we are left with not too subtle 'crescent-moon' images. However unsubtle the thin substance of The Ring 2 it will go completely unnoticed among the hundreds of 13-year-olds in the audience. Seriously, this is the kind of film that you go see early in the morning if you want quiet.

Still, no matter how disappointed I was with this film, it's still miles ahead of the appalling Grudge (Japanese AND American).

It's also worth noting that this has nothing to do with the Japanese sequel or Kôji Suzuki's literal sequel.

This movie was awesome. I don't understand how so many people dis-liked it. It was scary, suspenseful, and just an all around good movie. The ending with Samara and Rachel in the well was one of the best parts of any movie I have ever seen. I personally thought that this was just as good if not better than the first one. Sure, the ring one was definitely more original but this one is scarier and in my eyes more entertaining. Something else that i liked is that we saw more of Samara and i really liked the character of Evelyn, Samara's mother. Probably one of the greatest things about this movie was the aura and the overall feeling of the movie. It was so eerie and creepy. I don't know what's not to like in this movie. People getting pulled into TVs, deers ramming into cars, Namomi Watts getting drenched in water, this movie is great. The Ring TwO rules!

review_title: Good, but nowhere near the wit of the first.
review_detailed_main:
Naomi Watts returns as single mother Rachel Keller, six months after the events of "The Ring", and she and her son Aidan have just moved from Seattle to Astoria, Oregon, trying to start a new life after their horrible encounter with the young, cranky spirit of the murdered Samara. But all is not well, and a dead teen is found in Rachel's new town, lying in front of his television, wildly deformed. After examining his body, Rachel suspects Samara's involvement, and quickly speaks with the young boy's friend who was present at the time of death. And, much to her horror, she learns she was right, and Samara was indeed involved. This is an enjoyable film, yet sadly it does not live up to it's predecessor. The horror of the first film is mostly missing from this one (yet we start seeing the horror again towards the second half), and at first seems like a carbon copy of the original.

But, this is quickly shown not to be the case, as the plot for the second is very different from "The Ring", which involves little Aidan being possessed by Samara, Aidan being taken away from Rachel, and explores Samara's early past, plus the very scary idea that Rachel may have to drown her own son.

This film was directed by Hideo Nakata, who also directed "Ringu", the Japanese version of "The Ring". While he is responsible for "The Ring" ever being created, one can't help wondering if a film directed by Gore Verbinksi, the director of "The Ring", would have been better. But heck, it's better then most sequels. The CGI in the film is very realistic (truthfully I didn't realize parts of it were CGI until watching the special features), yet thankfully did not fall into the trap oh so many films fall into, where directors get lazy and make everything CGI, which looks fine at the time, but a year down the track you'll easily be able to pick it out (pay attention George, be careful with Indiana Jones IV!).

So, while it doesn't hold the terrifying atmosphere of the original, it's still a good film. The plot is very interesting, the characters all believable and does have it's very own moments of horror. The third film is being awaited with great anticipation. Let's hope it improves on this one's mistakes!

review_title: Fairly thin script and predictable ending
review_detailed_main: The Ring 2 was hardly as riveting as the first movie, which was able to keep audiences glued to their seats throughout. The concept of having a psychologically distressed child crawling out of a well and through your cable TV was quite something a few years back. Today however with scary movies hardly able to flex their muscle anymore, the director could have done far more with his aqua-based plot. The water imagery was refreshing and hardly scary. Throughout the movie the stunted character of Aidan failed to impress; what did impress was the sex appeal of Naomi Watts and her character. If it wasn't for her acting as the over zealous and protective mother that she was, the story would have fallen flat long before its predictable story-line did. All credit to the cast for trying to piece together a scenario which might evoke fear. The fact that the Ring 3 seems a likely possibility is all too apparent...
