The Ring Two is a supernatural horror movie directed by Hideo Nakata and stars Naomi Watts, Simon Baker, David Dorfman and Kelly Stables.

The movie is second part of The Ring Franchise.

After watching the first, honestly I was having lot's of expectations from the movie but it's been shattered.

It seems that the half baked plot was just created to make a sequel of it's critically successful first part. The movie is painfully slow and doesn't excites much. Acting is similar like the first part. Screenplay is slow and boring. The movie even doesn't haunt much.

A boring sequel.

review_title: Not too bad, not too good!
Get the Hobbits to Destroy This Ring.
Not as creepy as the first, but still makes the skin crawl.
review_detailed_main: The Ring II as a sequel is not bad in that the main characters and story line are really continuous from the first movie. I was anxious to see this film as I had heard so many negative comments when the film was in the theater I was apprehensive that this was another bad sequel. I was pleasantly surprised that this movie has a soul of its own that carries on the creepiness of the original without a basic repeat of the first movie. The cinematography, score and special effects are top notch and the odd use of jerky motion by the ghost Tamara in the film add to the creepiness. The film is a gray toned film from start to finish which creates a dark foreboding atmosphere. I especially like the score for one very simple reason. It is a real orchestral piece without the usual tricks of screaming violins or corny three note horror harmonies to give away the suspense. The film takes itself seriously throughout and I think gives the element of credibility to the story. I was a bit surprised and disappointed at the anti-climatic ending however, and felt that a scarier ending probably would have made more sense. This movie and its predecessor are the first time in a long time I have actually watched a horror thriller where I genuinely was left a bit spooked out after watching it. If any movie can do that to me, I give it hearty credit.

review_title: Ring 2 had all the horror of the original
review_detailed_main:
I saw Ring 1 on DVD and thought it was very scarier and it takes a lot to scare me.

An excellent script and riveting the whole way through. There story line was very solid and there was not much to pick at. So having just seen the sequel on the big screen, I was throughly scared.

As the story twists from one pinnacle to another, the drama builds and builds. The background music is very subtle but is more effective in building the tension.

It is not often a sequel can carry the same theme and stand alone but Ring 2 does and I thoroughly recommend Ring 1 enthusiasts to see it.

review_title: Thank Nakata for creating it. Thank Verbinski for perfecting it. Hate Nakata for nearly ruining it.
The Ring twO = The Ring bOred
review_detailed_main: This movie is boRING (pun intended) and cheesy. The acting is okay and the story felt broken. The pacing is pathetic like try to be a slow burner again but fail. I did watch the Unrated Version and it still suck with camera zooming in face. I like some ideas they use but it doesn't save the film and you know what that first film have that this one doesn't? A heart, a heart that makes you want to watch it more. I consider it a guilty pleasure because one some parts that make you want to laugh and it's cheesy. This ia my review on The Ring twO (2005), it could of done better

This sequel to the ring fails in every aspect where the first succeeded. From the first scene, which looks and plays like your generic teen horror slasher movie, you know that the sequel will not live up to its predecessor. Where the first ring captivated audiences with suspense, originality and a rich story line, this sequel struggles to maintain any kind of coherent plot and resorts to startle and gross out tactics that can bee seen a mile a way. Ring two doesn't try to have any story depth, throwing in references and symbols that had meaning in the first ring but are completely irrelevant in the second. The wonderful eerie suspense that was created in the first film is completely gone and what is left is a carelessly made movie that was written to do nothing but capitalize on the much deserved success of the first ring. ring ring ring, "The Ring Two will flop in seven days".

review_title: Not as good as first but still better than most
review_detailed_main: Although not as good as the first (and how many sequels could we say that about), this movie still held its own. Samara has figured a way back into the lives of Rachel (Naomi Watts) and her son Aiden (David Dorfman). This time she has possessed Aiden and wants Rachel to be her mommy. Besides that being just a wee bit eerie to begin with, Samara is also a killer, so Rachel has to figure out a way to get rid of her. This story is not as compelling as the first, but Samara still makes my skin crawl. This was a serviceable sequel, and they couldn't very well do the seven days bit again because Rachel already found out how to combat that. As far as scary movies go, "The Ring 2" was better than most.

Can someone please tell me why the people responsible for this film decided to make a completely different sequel, and just not remake the sequel that already exists? This film lacked the claustrophobic intensity that the original remake had. You were completely gripped from the beginning with the original and the director used the anticipation of fear to scare you, not the fear itself. With this film they just went for obvious and easy scares, people jumping out from nowhere and sudden reflections of evil etc.... I was bored whithin about 15 minutes of the film starting. The only good point of this film was the performance given by David Dorfman who plays the young boy Aidan. His delivery and reactions were excellent, I just hope he makes some better choices in future.

I've seen the movie today, the 2nd day of opening weekend, so i was not in a susceptible condition because of my respectable friends' more respectable comments , which i extremely hate about. Of course my entertainment joiner friends (according to them watching movie should give a pleasure like an orgasm or stg. like that) murmurs doesn't count :)

The very-first saying about the horror feast have to be this -->"If you haven't seen the Ring:The First, you better give your popcorn to a shinny baldy pal which will suffer lots of curses which is wholly reasonable in a silent horror movie"

The movie begins with Aidan and Rachel's moving to a small town. From the very beginning of the movie the tension of horror voltage is high which is fixated by Aidan's moves, looks, attitudes to his Rachel (not mommy!). Then The terror of Samara comes to town in a hurried way, This coming also gives some extra voltage to the movie. So on...

When we looked the movie like a flying-bird's distance; the first part put horror in you, the second part tells what that horror in you means, viz the second part is story-telling part. I think this technique of horror must see some respect. 'Cause it really works. You fear first, wait in a nervous, jumpy, and anxious position to solve, when you approach to the reason of whole you freak out, at last the movie ends in a calm way, and the cast comes.

David Dorfman (Aidan) is deserves some applause, his performance hit the top. On the other side Naomi Campell (Rachel) whom i closely oversee and trying to be fan is hit the bottom. Naomi, what is my sin to see you like that, what did i do wrong. Whatever...

The movie is good, the first is better but this explains some unexplained things. And last to say; is there any alternative to go for feeling some horror. Where is the old Elm streets man... If you want to see some, go and see. I gave 7/10 (the first Ring 8/10)

review_title: What the hell did I just watch?
It's not quite as good as the original but its worthy follow up
Why did they ever show Samara's face at all!?
A few moments of fright here and there, otherwise an overlong rather dull sequel.
review_detailed_main: Well it had to happen at some point, a film version of a Japanese horror movie that doesn't make me want to see the original version. Though I will probably still get it if it becomes available hoping its plot is a bit better than this movie's plot. Starts out promisingly enough, but about 15 minutes into it, it slows down a lot and it gets rather boring in areas. One of its problems is that it is to long. A long movie is great if it is an epic adventure or a horror of the Exorcist persuasion, but this movie just seemed to need a little more cut down. There is also way to much of the little boy from the first one in this one. He is the focal point here, and it gets rather tiresome here having to sit through his and his mother's conversations together. I don't want to give to much of the plot away, but it really doesn't seem to make a lot of sense considering the first movie where the girl is some sort of killing machine. This is where the original Japanese version of Ringu helps as it explains why the girl has the power to kill as she inherited power from her mother apparently. Here we don't know why she kills and we don't really know why she is tormenting the little boy, except that she wants a figure in her life that she has never had, but why does she want that in the first place? The evil video tape is all but gone from the plot in the first few minutes, which is a shame because that was the most interesting aspect of the first one. That movie also built up to a rather creepy conclusion, while this one's conclusion is not really all that scary at all. So if you saw the first one, you may want to check it out, if not you aren't missing a lot. I suggest if they make another one, dump Watts and the kid and move on to another person to focus the story on.

review_title: I registered - just to warn people not to see this movie
Ring one . . . good, but Ring Two . . . BAD!!!
review_detailed_main:
First I would like to say that I loved the first Ring movie and found its to be a very scary film that relied more on atmosphere and creepiness than gore and blood to provide chills, and scares.

When I heard that a second movie was in production I couldn't wait till It came out. I was there the opening day to see the movie and I had high expectations . . . that were not even closely met.

The biggest problem with The Ring Two is that they took out the creepiest thing about the first movie which was the video tape. They also took out Samara Morgan flashbacks of childhood which was also very creepy in the first movie. Replacing these elements with the grown up Samara trying to possess Aidan??? This child is not that important or great that she needs to go through him to get to our world, and I was very disappointed that this was the premise of the movie. I'm not sure precisely what the premise should have been but they could have come up with something else. They didn't have to follow the premise of the second Japanese movie which if i'm not mistaken wasn't as popular as the original over their either.

Sticking with he video premise they could have done plenty of creative things that would have made original enough to stand on its own. There were a few good scares like Somara skittering up the walls and stuff that made you cringe but for the most part I wasn't really scared much during the movie. I definitely didn't want this to be the review that I wrote for this movie but It is unfortunately.

I'm about Ringed out.

I've seen all three versions of the first film; Japanese, Korean and American, the Japanese sequel, and now the American sequel to the American remake which is not a remake of the Japanese sequel to the Japanese original. Are we following? Hideo Nakata, who helmed all three of the Ring films in Japan, has been brought aboard here. This is an impressive show of fealty to the source material not normally seen in studio production, and it utterly fails to pay off. This is my fourth Nakata film, and a pattern has emerged: the man clearly believes that there is something primally terrifying about water seepage. Film after film, scene after scene, we are shown water seeping through ceilings, down walls, under doors...and all I could think was, "Man, that's going to play hell on those hardwood floors." To be fair, the screenplay doesn't do Nakata any favors. In going further back into the origins of Samara, and adding another unnecessary layer of supernatural gobbledygook, it resembles nothing so much as the "Nightmare on Elm Street" sequels. There are also several echoes of "The Omen", a much better evil child film than this one. First, there is a random animal attack that comes out of nowhere and is never explained or justified. There's also the use of photography to illustrate the threat. Finally, there's the protagonist being faced with a morally repugnant solution to the problem. Unfortunately, she accepts it far too quickly and blindly to make it believable, particularly since it comes from a lunatic, and the story winds up lacking the spine to follow through on this premise anyway.

Naomi Watts does her best to make this work, despite having to deliver half her dialogue in a forced whisper. The child actor playing her son, who I thought was quite good in the first film, drops the ball here. It might have helped him if his few lines of dialogue weren't so fraught with portent that they read like a neon sign flashing "Foreshadowing Alert".

There is really only one bit of creepy imagery near the end, and it is attached to a sequence that makes no sense whatsoever. Nakata obviously has a gift for staging and visual composition that lend some atmosphere to his work. However, one has to wonder if a director with a complete grasp of English might have recognized the weaknesses in the script, and done better work with actors.

In the end, it's hard to think of this as a missed opportunity, since it was an entirely unnecessary follow-up anyway, and since the Japanese sequel really wasn't any better. It's still disappointing to see so much potential go completely to waste.

review_title: A disappointing but still OK sequel
Stay as far away as possible from this

review_detailed_main: I saw this movie the day after it opened, there was mixed media hype so i wasn't sure what to expect, however i had a feeling it would be good after the original. I wasn't wrong. I thought overall it was a great film which i enjoyed vastly. A funny witty comment from Racheal at the end topped of a great film in my view. I think the young lad who plays Aidan is an outstanding actor, and will be marvellous in time to come. I think today, people are criticising movies to easily, but i believe there is little to pick at in The Ring Two. Its a lengthy film which is unusual for the horror/thriller genre, we usually see them about an hour and 20mins, and i think this was around 2hours give or take 10mins.I think if your frightened, id be careful seeing this. when i came out the cinema i wasn't the only person saying "You may as well of payed £3 for your ticket because you only watched half the film" I still however recommend everyone see it, and lets wait and see what they do with Ring O.

review_title: When you let the dead get in, you gotta treat 'em the right way, or they can really stink up the place
review_detailed_main: There are a lot of stories that don't need, and, what's more, stand to be harmed by there being made, sequels to them. Of course, trying to explain that concept to a Hollywood executive, you'd get a hearty laugh and/or an expression of bewilderment on their face, followed by some energetic grunts, of which the only intelligible word you can make out is "money". I don't know if this is necessarily a bad film. Me and Asian horror, well, we're no longer on speaking terms, and not only because I don't understand a word of the languages. I am not criticizing the type, or anyone who is into them. Maybe the first in this Americanized series of the (in)famous movies was made Western-friendly, and that's part of why I liked it infinitely better. But darn it, it was amazing! It had incredible mood and atmosphere, built up masterfully... while this one goes for that as well(and kudos to them for sticking with that, absolutely the right choice), I'm sorry, the threat was just not that present, much of the time. The sense of urgency is gone. Shocks are still obtained with no blood or gore, however, this one has several areas where it tries too hard to terrify the audience, and it simply falls terribly flat(and I think they went with a couple of lame and cheap scares this time, think "cat leaps out of dark space at the characters" kind of thing). This has nice, creepy bits. There are things similar to the earlier entry that were powerful and effective that time around, that really don't work, here. The focus is also considerably less sharp here. A thing or two are written out completely, one with such an insulting and silly explanation that you have to wonder why they left it in there. After this was over, I honestly didn't feel like it went anywhere, certainly nowhere interesting. Answers provided lead to confusion and new questions. This takes so enormously different an approach, I don't entirely understand why they used that title. The effects tend to be great. When they're bad, they are so obvious that it may take you out of the moment(can it be widely agreed that the only way CGI should ever be used for anything living, existing and recognizable, there should be motion-capture or something involved?). The acting is all solid, the kid and Watts continue to deliver. This isn't necessarily poor, and there are quite possibly people who love this. I have no beef, or any other kind of food, meat product or otherwise, with them. What I will say is that if you liked Kelly's take on this, you may not care for this. There is no sexuality, one f-word and no actual violence. The DVD holds ten minutes of deleted/alternate scenes, a handful or so of brief featurettes, and a prologue short that is, in my opinion, far superior to this. All of it is well-done and worth the time. I recommend this to fans of those who made it, perhaps especially the director. 6/10

If you've been intelligent enough to not watch this movie; don't get any bright ideas that it would be good to check it out. It is a horrible film that is barely even fit for cable access. This movie is filled with absolutely nothing. I think that when they were writing the script they just threw in whatever they could think of. One of the worst films I have seen in years. I was expecting it to be bad, but it went beyond bad.

Whatever you do, do not see this film unless you want a good laugh at times. I have no idea how anyone could even think this movie is slightly good.

review_title: Lackluster sequel to the hit horror movie The Ring.
review_detailed_main:
Starring: Naomi Watts I've never really been a big fan of horror movies. I mean, what's the fun in scaring the crap out of yourself and making it so you have nightmares? Beats me man. Well, I was trying to find a way to occupy myself one evening, and I still had one of my AMA movie tickets left, so I went to the theater and bought a ticket for the only movie that was showing at the exact moment I walked in the door. It was either that or wait another hour for a decent movie. So I went to see The Ring Two.

Apparently horror movies don't have to have a plot that makes sense.

I'm sure this movie would have made more sense if I had seen the first one, but I hadn't. I might have to watch the first one now so that the second one makes a little bit more sense, but we'll see. If it's as lackluster as the second one, then I see no reason to give it a view.

So I guess that Rachel (Watts) and her son were involved in the events from the first Ring, with the stupid tape and all that crap. They moved away to try to start a new life, but that little girl from the video is after them again. More specifically, after her son Aiden. So you get all kinds of weird things happening like Aiden getting sucked into the T.V. by this crazy little girl who got drowned in a well or something like that. I don't know. The plot was so stupid that it was hard to try to keep a straight face as it was going through. I mean, good gravy people. This was just pathetic.

As far as scariness goes, I didn't really find this movie all that terrifying. There were a few creepy visuals, and a couple moments that catch you by surprise and make you jump a bit. Maybe even a few scenes where you get a bit of a chill running down your spine. But really, nothing especially noteworthy.

If I'm going to watch something that might have the potential to make me jump a little bit, I'll stick to Shyamalan's movies. They at least have a little bit more plot, intelligence, and depth behind them.

Bottom Line: 2.5 out of 4 (maybe if you liked the first one)

review_title: Don't watch this. DEATH TO CGI SAMARA!!!!!
review_detailed_main:
I really liked Ringu and Ringu 2. I really liked the Ring when it was remade. I thought these three films (I haven't seen Ringu 0 yet) were both sh*t scary and really good thriller stories. The Ring Two is half sh*t scary, in that its all sh*t.

Now i was semi-traumatised by the earlier films and was expecting the same again, especially with the increased amount of Samara. However her appearances are so predictable and fundamentally boring that it grows thin quickly. There is an awful large amount of largely awful CGI. CGI has been well used but it is close to pointless in horror, especially when it looks cheap. The much lauded deer scene is painful to watch for the crudeness of the models. CGI Samara is not very scary. The brilliant strained string music of the others is rarely present.

The first American ring was very successful in creating a well paced mystery, the video provided signposts and added well to the sense of dread. In this there is a paltry attempt to do the same again with generic 'visions'. These come too late to give any semblance of structure to a mess of a film.

This has pretty much lead me to conclude that Hideo Nataka is a one trick pony. All credit to the man, Ringu, Ringu 2 and Dark Water are all very scary but its the same thing over and OVER and OVER again. Water and dark hair is SOO last year.

All things being said there were a few good moments. Specifically the well scene at the end, which is stolen directly from Ringu 2 for those who haven't seen it, even this is ruined by the awful one-liner after they escape. 'I'm not your f*cking mommy!' I mean really, this presumably wasn't supposed to be a comedy horror, was it? I definitely felt is was watching a Ring spoof a couple of times.

I was massively disappointed with this film. Frankly if you want to be scared watch the originals again, or the Eye, or even Bogeyman had some genuinely spooky bits.

review_title: She's back...and this time they pressed rewind!
review_detailed_main:
Original Ring director Hideo Nakata takes it back to the small scale and understated jumpy-not-bloody roots of the Japanese Originals which were shown on television in the week of Ring Two USA's UK release.

The kid turns in another great performance, carrying the film and not as showy as Haley Joel Osment in The Sixth Sense although without the great twisting lines of the first American Ring, and really it just winds and winds up to the wisecracking end although some sentimentality is allowed to creep in with the dead. It's brought to a logical conclusion at the end although and frankly with some scenes reminiscent of the original there shouldn't have to be a third American film unless Dreamworks are desperate for money.

Complaints? Some may dislike the fact that it's slower, almost stagey, compared to Gore Verbinski's original which fully embraces traditionally faster Hollywood storytelling. It's all right, just don't go in there expecting either the original or Scream and it'll be all right. Otherwise, catch the Japanese originals and rent this. Plus on the print I watched there were pops on the soundtrack which made it hard to get into the film but that's just the crappy theatre I was in. Reasonable, although maybe it should have pushed up the ante with less inventive (yet more entertaining) deaths if there might not be another one.

review_title: A weak sequel to the decent remake.
review_detailed_main:
Rachel (Naomi Watts) and her son Aiden (David Dorfman) are attempting to build a new life for themselves in a quiet town when another copy of Samara's creepy video cassette crops up. Rachel locates and destroys the tape, but in doing so sets Samara free, enabling her to possess Aiden.

As much as I enjoyed The Ring (the US remake), a videotape has always seemed to me to be a very convoluted way for a malevolent spirit to keep her curse alive (I imagine Samara sat in front of a supernatural editing suite carefully piecing together her creepy masterpiece, getting just the right amount of graininess and flickering. It's all so silly).

The Ring Two has it's scary moments (Samara chasing Rachel up the wall of a well is a particularly well executed moment) but pushes credibility to breaking point, the story making not a lick of sense. The question I kept asking as I watched the film was 'Why?': Why does Samara have this fixation with Aiden? Why do stags suddenly attack Rachel and Aiden's car? Why does Aiden's bath-water float up to the ceiling? Why can't Samara hear Aiden and Rachel when they are asleep? And why did they give the green light for this sequel with such a logic-free script?

review_title: The Silliest 15 Remarks About This Movie !
review_detailed_main:
1 - The real horror of that movie is the horror of not having a plumber; as the whole sequence of the bathroom makes a great ad about needing one!

2 - It's nice indeed, but if it was produced in the 1950s!

3 - Thank God that the original Japanese director didn't direct the first American version!

4 - One of my friends told me that (The Ring - 2) is the most beautiful movie he has ever seen in his life. Anyway, he looked so good the last time I visited him at the insane asylum!

5 - It's the same old ring however with 3/4 of it as empty!

6 - When will we have (The Son Of Samara), (Samara vs. Saw), (Samara Begins) and (Samara Takes Hollywood)?! Well it's very soon indeed!

7 - I heard once that one doctor wrote this movie in some prescription for a sick man as a successful cure for insomnia. I couldn't believe that until I watched it!

8 - What is the scariest moment in this movie?! Of course when I remembered how much I paid to watch it!

9 - If only there is some kind of legislation to sue the production companies, so we could retrieve our money whenever the movie wouldn't make our day!

10 - He told me that the love scene was great, the chase sequence in the woods was spectacular, but nothing like the scene in which Samara said to (Naomi Watts): "I'm Your Father!".. Sorry, they were the very words of my poor friend again!

11 - I remember someone was setting behind me at the theater while watching this, and whenever (Watts) was having a critical moment, he just pray to God to see her loses and be killed. So I asked him why? And he replayed logically: "So we can all go home soon instead of watching THIS!". To tell you the truth, me as all my friends beside me, joined him in praying afterwards!

12 - It's not one of the worst sequels, or one of the worst sequels of a remake (don't start this headache please!), or even one of the worst horror movies, No.. it's all of that together and more: One of the best comedies ever made!

13 - Samara's victims this time made longer list as it had: the drama, the persuasion, our patience, our money..

14 - Actually this is my favorite comic note about (The Ring 2) and you can read it on the main page of it: This is a Horror / Thriller / Mystery movie.. HAHAHAA.. OH my God, it doesn't come funnier than that!!

15 - Yes, they're all so silly remarks, but not as silly as this movie!

review_title: It's a really good movie, i don't know why people seem to not like it

review_detailed_main:
I don't understand why all these people are writing bad things about this "good" movie.

I think this film follows on well from the last one and is in no way the same as the first one, apart from the fact that it is continuing the story, which lets be fair, is original and an original story is hard to find these days. I think "Ring Two" answers a lot of the questions that "The Ring" asked and it dose tie up all the loose ends. DO NOT SEE THIS FILM WITHOUT SEEING "THE RING" FIRST.

Last but not least this film is a "Horror film" which is different from a "Teen Slasher" in the sense that it's actually scary, and has a bit of depth. If you like "slasher" films then you might find this a bit dull. There's no blood or pathetic killers in cheaply made hallo ween costumes running around with knives that are obviously plastic. If you have a brain and you know how to use it you might actually like this film.

review_title: Pointless sequel, made purely to cash in on the smash success of the original.

review_detailed_main: I don't have much to say about this film except that I was a bit disappointed, though I am not surprised since the first 'Ring' is a very tough act to follow in my opinion. I found myself snickering at a few points that were meant to be scary or suspenseful, and I was not generally tense or anxious as I was throughout much of the first one. I liked how 'The Ring' seemed very gray throughout, but the color seemed unfortunately brighter in the sequel. All of this being said, it's still better than a lot of crap that's been made in the last few years, hence my 5 out of 10 and not worse. See it if you want, but I'd wait until DVD/video...I know I should have watched more opening-round March Madness instead.

review_title: Better to see the original first
Once again a scary movie thats not scary.....
review_detailed_main: Seeing the commercials of ring2,you thought hey this movie is going to be better than the first and even scarier,well the commercials lie...In order to understand the sequel you have to watch Scary Movie 3.The plot is the same between both movies,well a little anyways.The movie really wasn't scary,but some parts were a little strange in some cases bizarre or creepy.In this movie the blanks are learned from the first,and actually you learn a little bit more of what happens,but Iam not gonna say what.The graphics are somewhat cool.One part in the movie it looks like the grudge but Iam not telling what.The movie isn't suspenseful and it kinda reminds me of Jaws at parts.The plot is pretty good,and the actors very very excellent.The sound and music is very cool also.Other than that,the first is a lot better,the second is somewhat close.

It was okay. It wasn't as horror as the first movie. I liked the first movie a lot better. It could of been more scarier than putting more story into it. It was original. It wasn't the best. I wasn't satisfy. I didn't get the whole plot of the movie. It wasn't that good. I thought it couldn't been a lot better! The photographs was good. I loved the characters! I didn't like how the people died. It was kinda of weird.Yeah...basically I like the first better. It gave too much plot and not much horror. I almost fell asleep in the movies. The director could of been more clear in the plot and put more horror parts!!!!!! I practically like Boogeyman better! Never mind. The Ring Two had like no plot, not much horror parts, and keep the people interested.
While nearly every shock comes at predictable moments, there is genuine ingenuity behind many, and the movie is surprisingly fresh for one made by a guy on his third go-round with the same material.

review_title: Horribly Weak Sequel By My Standards
review_detailed_main:
Rache land Aiden move away from Seattle to start a new life after the horrible events from "The Ring". No more Samara, no more video tape, no more ring. But Samara doesn't give up that easily and the video tape finds its way to the new town, with Samara not far behind.

I do not have the time to write a full review right now, but I will say the acting is good as usual (Naomi Watts can do no wrong, she's almost the blonde Jennifer Connelly). The guest appearance by Sissy Spacek as a mental ward patient was an excellent nod to older horror (such as "Carrie", another young girl with powers). And even appearing in a very limited role is Mary Elizabeth Winstead as "Young Evelyn"... Winstead being the actress I dub the new face of teen horror.

The biggest problem with this film is the special effects. While the first one was really creepy (and I personally think the American "Ring" was creepier than "Ringu") with the girl coming out of the television, the effects here seem like they should be scary, but aren't. The girl in the television sequences are toned down (which is like denying the best part of the first one) and other scenes like the bathtub flooding scene are interesting but not terrifying.

The actor who played Aiden is just wrong. I hate to criticize someone for their looks, but this kid is just really goony looking and I couldn't take him seriously. Any time something was supposed to be scary, he made it just look dumb. There's a fine line between creepy little boys ("The Omen") and boys with mental retardation ("Ring Two"). Also ,the writer felt the need to have Rachel say "Aiden" and Aiden say "Rachel" as much as possible. Maybe it's just me, but I don't need to say a person's name in every sentence I address to them. (There's a good reason in the plot why they stressed this, but we don't all have attention deficit disorder and need to be reminded twelve thousand times.) I liked how the mythology was built on by returning to the horse stables (or however you wish to explain the house by the lighthouse). And by explaining more about Samara's mother. This was very well thought out, and I'm glad they did it. Although, in my opinion, after Samara was defeated in "The Ring", she should have just stayed dead and we could have closed the case on that one...

I'm sure someone else by now told you this was an awful film. I'll be the next person to tell you the same thing. It has some good scenes and Naomi Watts is wonderful, but something doesn't really add up in this one. And I also felt like I had to sit through this for an eternity even though it's only an hour and 37 minutes. That's not a good feeling. If you can't resist, rent this one... otherwise just save your curiosity for something else.

review_title: Not as good as the American Orginal
review_detailed_main: Disclosure I have not seen the asian version of the ring. If I say the original I'm referring to the american version. The ring 2 wasn't as interesting as the original. It basically was the original. I gave it a three for effort I liked the ending but throughout the whole movie nothing happens that you haven't seen in the first one. I would just avoid this completely and watch the first one if you want to be disappointed watched The Ring 2.

review_title: full of flaws, at times ridiculous, but still fun and at times pretty darn chilling
The good, the bad, and the ugly of The Ring Two
review_detailed_main:
The Good: The second film was scary and had a few more exciting thrills at unexpected places. The storyline was easier to follow mostly because the main plot was told during the first one. Actor David Dorfman (Aiden Keller) puts on an excellent performance with superb talent and an outstanding acting ability to be such a young actor. Naomi Watts (Rachel Keller) doesn't do too shabby herself and her acting ability still stands firm...although she was much better in the original film and her other films as well, such as Mulholland Drive, directed by David Lynch. Sissy Spacek (Evelyn) does an excellent job even with minimal lines as she does so well with her roles in all of her films. You will more than likely jump a little here and there while watching this film!

The Bad: This sequel was in many ways like many horror sequels, repetitive. Also, the very minor roles, such as the young couple at the beginning, very poor acting abilities and a few lines seemed to be inappropriate here and there (possibly just poor errors with the writer and script editors). Some of the plot, like the first film, makes you sit in deep suspense wondering if they are ever going to get to the point. The story of The Ring should end with this sequel and not be to shame with another film...we have been scared, so please don't overdo it!

The Ugly: Samara is scary, freaky, and definitely one UGLY looking little girl!

review_title: Not a Bad movie at all

review_detailed_main: It somehow could not bring the creepiness to the table. A Ghost crawling out of a TV Set is somehow a dumb idea. The execution matters. Although the special effects are fabulous. The movie overall does not give me what I was looking forward to. They could have made it much more magnificent

I don't know..it was good, but the first one was so good that it would be hard to top it, and this one definitely did not. The plot started to sound tired, and i got kind of bored. The parts with Samara were shocking enough, but the storyline is so full of holes I was rolling my eyes. I would see it again on DVD, but not in the theater again..I waited a long time for this sequel and maybe the problem was they brought in the original Ringu director from Japan. I would wait for the DVD to see it if I handy seen it yet. There was such a long delay for this to come out, and I wonder what the problem was. I cant believe they are making me type so much crap about this, 10 lines or I cant submit it??? What the heck is the problem??

By meditating upon this sound you will experience a moment of nonexistence, which the Hindus and Buddhists call Nirvana. "The Ring" was originally a Japanese movie, and, every solidly established tradition in the world knows these things. Are THEY trying to keep you in the dark? No! THEY are trying to keep you in blinding chaotic white light. The Lost Word brings you to a peaceful darkness from which you emerge with greater and greater wisdom and power. The resultant globally bent time space, which alchemists called a "quickened astral light" gives your mind the power to materialize your visualizations, more and more power. This too happens with opposite polarities allowed to cancel faster in a good conductive electrolyte, which was called a "shekinah" by the ancients. Association, quantum entanglement, with this gives you automatic mind power. But, can you control every thought? The name Samara means a guardian in Hebrew, but in Japanese it means Sa (apple), ma (horse), Ra (happy), Happy Apple Horse.    Since I first saw "The Ring" it has been my favorite movie. Among other things, I am kinesthetic, which is not considered a disease. In fact, many of the greatest geniuses like Leonardo Da Vinci, Sir Francis Bacon, Ben Franklin and Gheorghe Rakoczy were sunsets. Synesthesia is the mixing of the senses. The Ring tastes like licorice to me.

At First it was BORING but I started to like it as they got more more into the mystery of the tape.It did need little bit more but it was GREAT!

They Need more people and needed to MAke more and more of the tapes till it goes international and Racheal and Aiden has to stop it before everyone sees it.

I would say go see it if you like mystery that is not that Gory,Bloody Has lots of language, and Not that Scary. either see it by yourself or with a friend.

But it Was Great!

What a terrible waste of my time. No offense to Naomi, who was present at the screening in which I saw this, but I had to leave 50 minutes into the film.

I am a huge fan of Asian horror, and gave this a go with the hope that by enlisting the director of the original to direct the sequel, it might be pretty good.

Unfortunately, there was nothing good about this film. The child acting in this film is terrible, the CG was terrible, the script was I would go as far as to say , evil. the two lead roles were good, but this film is beyond salvageable.

I have to admit I am pretty disgusted that Hollywood are adapting so many Asian films. Are there no fresh ideas in Hollyood? the list of horror remakes, not only of the Asian variety, certainly would lead one to think so.

If you are after a scare or two, seek out the directors DARK WATER (not the Hollywood remake) or SHUTTER (thai film) or even the EYE.

avoid this at all costs.

I really felt like the ring two let me down. after watching the ring i wanted years in excitement for 2nd movie, always checking up on the internet about release dates and stuff. i sat down in the cinema thinking "i wounder if they will ever be a third, after watching the first scene i felt like the directer and screenplay(by Erhen Kruger) they let the whole audience down the movie did manage to pick up with scenes like Samara grabbing Rachel from the body bag i also like the part were Rachel got lost in the deadly videotape but it let us down when the goblin voice screamed "mommy" from the well and Rachel screamed "im not you're f***ing mommy!" what was that all about? over all i have to say the pest thing about the film was the great actors Naomi Watts did a great job as did David Dorfman if there is ever a ring three i suggest the directer they change the directer back to Gore Verbinski,who did the first movie.even though this Japanese directer invented the whole ring story, he dose not have an American way of thinking.By the end of the movie thought this was just a waste of everybody's time wasn't it!

review_title: This movie was not worth it.
review_detailed_main: First off, to comment on the cellar. Remember the agent also said the previous owners moved too...so he embellished a little...but the movie itself was not worth watching. I'd rather watch The Pacifier than watch The Ring 2. Ringu was better, and they couldn't even cover the fact they messed it up in the first one. The Ring 2 was disappointing. I want a refund. I'll say the first 30 minutes was interesting, but after that, too predictable. This movie should not have been made in the first place. I've seen scary movies before, this was almost like a comedy that isn't funny anymore. Seeing it for the first time, I already knew what was going to happen.

I saw this last night and I still don't know what to think. The Ring 2 (or twO I guess) was in no way scary or creepy. I mean, it was supposed to be a horror movie right? I don't know where the filmmakers were going for whenever Samara popped up..... were we supposed to jump out of our seats and yelp? I have already seen her in the original; I know what she looks like. We also know that people's faces are disfigured when Samara kills them, it was creepy in the first but I again have already been there done that.

But I am happy to report that I was glad to see this film not go down that all too familiar path of the unoriginal rehash most horror sequels tend to take. This movie has almost nothing to do with the killer videotape but takes on an all-new original plot centering on Samara and Aidan. Finally filmmakers who want to create something new and fresh.

The Ring 2 is a drama/suspense, and in no way should be even called a horror movie. Not even the pop-up scares did anything to me because they were always the same damn thing, the same character popping up to freak out our protagonist. But there were some good shots, I especially like the shot in the beginning, showing us what Samara sees when she is doing her TV thing.

The acting was right on with Naomi Watts as she carried this film. If she hadn't returned I strongly feel we wouldn't have the same movie. She played her part just like the original and delivered one of the best lines I have heard in recent memory. David Dorfman was also exceptional on how he traded off as Aidan and Samara. Simon Baker who played Max didn't really impress me that much, he was in a more gun-ho type of character, but didn't really run with it. And I hear is leading Land of the Dead? We might have some trouble. Oh and whoever cast Sissy Spacek should receive a reward, she was brilliant.

When I started to write this review, I really didn't know what to think of this sequel. As I continued to write it became clear to me that the filmmakers wanted to make a whole different movie and they should be congratulated. For it is not everyday we see a good horror become a good drama.

Save your money! Save your time! For the love of god, save yourself! Unless, of course, you like sterile and and bizarre digital effects sloppily attached to an anorexically contrived script and prozac induced directing and acting. Because if that's your thing, and it doesn't bother you to watch mass produced and mass consumed average fare, and eleven bucks doesn't mean anything to you, and neither does two hours of your life, then, and only then, can you truly think "I got my money's worth." There are some pretty colors in it -- it takes place in a Pacific coastal town in Oregon. Lots of blues and greens. The teals. The aquas. My favorite.

review_title: It's not perfectly drawn, but you can tell it's a circle.

review_detailed_main: not even half as good as the first (which wasn't all that good anyways) the only good thing about this movie was that Naomi watts was in it, she is a great actress. i can't fill up 10 lines talking about this really awful movie so i'm just going to tell you that it's no good so save your money on it and don't go. if you would really like to see it wait till it comes out on DVD and then get one of your friends to rent it. um there's not much more that i want to say about this movie because it was soo bad but i need to fill three more lines so i'm just telling you what i'm thinking...sorry bout this you can stop reading now cause i'm just going to go on rambling making no sense what so ever and not even coming remotely close to telling you anything esle about the ring two.

The Ring Two is just as good if not better than the original.

The acting was flawless on all parts especially on the part of Ayden and Rachel.

The Ring Two takes the horror of Samara even further, exploring the tragedy of her past and her intentions in the present. It ties this movie to the first one perfectly without seeming repetitive in any way.

There several simply incredible scenes which I won't talk of here simply because I don't want to ruin anything. The Ring 2 closes the story, in a good but not happy sort of way, a perfect end to a great story.

If you liked the Ring, I don't see how you could not love the Ring 2.

review_title: This sequel trips into every horror sequel pitfall possible
review_detailed_main: The Ring (2002) is one of my favorite horror movies of all time. Oh, how the mighty have fallen. The Ring Two trips into every horror sequel pitfall possible. Where to start? First of all, it isn't scary. Apparently Samara now has the power to control computer-generated deer, randomly appear in public restrooms, and make bathtubs less pleasant than normal. Plus, poor David Dorfman has long since passed the creepy insightful kid phase in this movie and has entered the creepy awkward teen phase. Even Samara looks like a grown woman in some scenes. This horrible sequel makes the first movie less scary.

review_title: Alternatively boring, repetitive and highly embarrassing
review_detailed_main:
Without a doubt the worst RING film yet – and that includes all the various remakes, sequels and rip-offs that followed in the wake of the Hideo Nakata shocker. The worst thing about this one is that Nakata himself directs, but seems to have forgotten all the subtlety and all the atmosphere that made the original RING such a chilling masterpiece. THE RING TWO shows the ghost girl in the very first scene – and if you remember you don't see her in the original Japanese film until the end – giving you some idea of just how diluted and over-obvious this movie is. A Hollywood film in the very worst sense.

Instead of remaking the Japanese RING 2, this one goes in a completely different – and soul-crushingly pointless – direction. We're introduced to Samara's mother, played by Sissy Spacek, in one entirely superfluous scene. Gary Cole pops up as a slimy realtor's. A kid gets possessed and Samara keeps on popping up in mirrors, bathtubs, you name it. Never for a moment is this film scary or indeed interesting, and as Naomi Watts flounders around in wide-eyed surprise you can't help but sympathise with her for appearing in something so yawn-inducing. Take, for instance, the attack by a herd of evil CGI deer. What powers that be could ever envisage this as something remotely spooky?

review_title: Lacks the punch and the genuine thrills and scares of the first but still acts as a creepy and unnerving entry into what is now a series.
review_detailed_main:
Ask nine out of ten people what they first think of upon mentioning the film 'The Ring' and chances are the first thing that comes to mind won't be a ring of some sort but in fact a videotape. Yes; if the original Japanese 'Ring' film's, and then what can now be seen as the obligatory American remake, aim was to take an inanimate and seemingly unspectacular everyday object and make it 'scary' in some way then these films succeed in creating pressure and tension wherever a videotape or television is on screen. And this is where The Ring Two comes dangerously close to destroying itself entirely, although in my opinion it does just enough to avoid doing so.

The reason for The Ring Two coming so close to being appalling lies in its use of its primary weapon and its primary source for scares. In the first of these Hollywood remakes as I'm led to believe it was in the Japanese original, you got the feeling that the film was building to that dramatic climax of that young girl coming out from the television to 'get' its prey  the unbreakable wall of the television screen was broken and what surely cannot harm you could do so. In The Ring Two that very same scene so full of horror, tension and originality occurs twice in the opening twenty minutes, the first of which is the opening scene of the whole film, crudely reminding us of why we're even watching and why this sequel was even made. Along with this, we get to see how drowned little girl Samara 'takes' her prey: the close up of the Japanese journalist's face in the original as it blurred away into static nothingness was haunting enough but in The Ring Two, a scene that borders on the comical sees Samara quite literally grab someone late on in the film and try to pull them into the television.

But The Ring Two is an exercise in suspense and it is a creepy film none-the-less. I suppose videotape is a relic, it's a forgotten piece of modernity resigned to staring out of the shop fronts of your local charity store, watching people go past in the ever increasing digital world we live in. DVDs have replaced videotapes; I haven't operated a VCR in almost half a decade and whatever videotapes I still have, have probably fallen down the back of a bookcase  lost. But this is one of the things that keeps The Ring Two on that level of creepiness; the feeling that inanimate objects can hurt you  televisions and video cassettes are luxuries designed to give to you pleasure and entertainment, not take from you, period. If a third or fourth 'Ring' film was to be made and these conventions kept, I am sure it would still retain some sort of un-canniness due to what we all know about these seemingly harmless objects.

So apart from opening up like 1995's Jumanji, is there anything else to The Ring Two besides a few jumps here and there and 'that' famous scene shot from a different perspective? Short answer is that no, there isn't. Naomi Watts is back as Rachael Keller who goes on another detective strand inspired story trying to work out how Samara is still around and what she wants this time. Thrown in with all this is some relatively weak theory revolving around motherly figures and a child's basic psychological development because of lack of. But a lot of the problems I had with The Ring Two stems from daft character logic and motivation. You know how infuriating it is when you see a horror film and people do exact things they shouldn't? Well a similar feeling creeps up on you in this film and by the end, it has stuck there only this time the events do not necessarily mean certain death.

Some of these occurrences happen early on at a carnival when Keller allows her son Aiden (once again played by David Dorfman) to aimlessly wander off, getting mixed up in the sideshows and people moving around as well as other such things like nasty incidences in public restrooms. Another incidence where daft logic has prevailed to merely spawn a 'scary' scene happens when Keller places Aiden in a bath full of water, despite the knowledge that Samara may be around and then leaves the house with him in the care of a male friend. But the best one is when we discover mental patients are allowed to use scissors in their cells.

I mentioned how audio-visual technology plays a large role in establishing potential scares in The Ring Two but for a film to feature so much audio-visual technology like tapes; TVs; cameras and the like and for absolutely no one to ever think of even filming some of the phenomenon's that happen is ludicrous. There is photographic evidence of Samara but it doesn't get out from the boundaries of the lead characters; a bathroom has its water attached to the ceiling but no one thinks to film it and how Rachael knew what she knew for the climax without having any reason to assume so is a little messy. But the film is a demonstration in horror; the sort of film you would've been proud to have made had it been your first and a film that probably would've scored high if entered on a formal education course. Not bad nor terrible but nowhere near great.

review_title: "The Grudge" , "Darkness" and "Boogyman" all rolled into one big piece of s**t
review_detailed_main:
Naomi Watts, Simon Baker, David Dorfman, Elizabeth Perkins, Gary Cole, Sissy Spacek, Ryan Merriman, Emily Vancamp and Kelly Overton. Directed by Hideo Nakata.

The sequel to the original Ring (directed by Gore Verbinski) is dull, boring, lame, not scary and quite possibly the worst horror movie ever made. Based on the original movie Ringu directed by Hideo Nakata that started the Ring crave along with crappy look-a likes (The Grudge, Darkness, Ring 2, Boogyman, Skeleton Key, Dark Water). Six months after Rachel Keller (Watts) and her son, Aidan (Dorfman, doing his best to imitate Dakota Fanning) escape their run-in with the evil video tape and the ghost girl Smara. Now they move to a small quiet town in Oregon looking to start anew. The movie tries to make you jump and scream but... My final rating 0/10.

review_title: Famous Japanese Horror director gets all the tools of Hollywood and we see a very scary sequel
review_detailed_main:
Hideo Nakata has been famous for creating that sense of dread using well place cameras, and just generally creates a sense of unease. And throughout the movie you will get the constant, recurring chills. One of the techniques I loved in 1998's "Ringu" is scaring you when you least expect it. While some of the scares you begin to expect in "Ring 2" quite a few come by surprise. For example, in the original, the mummified corpses were a big scare, well now there is an interesting twist to that fright. And without a single scene of violence, you will leave the theater with the supreme chills.

The acting is well done, and you will be able to sense secret motives, attitudes, everything comes out clear. However, one of the major flaws of this movie is the writing. The script feels very rushed, as though the writer just threw together whatever the could in a hurried deadline, so if your expecting the same quality script and well concluded story like "The Ring", you might be disappointed. A lot of the things don't really make sense and in some places the story contradicts what it brought in the original "Ring." So in the end a lot of the characters don't end up as well, and I really disliked the way Aidan's character was written as an adult. He rarely behaved like a kid. One more thing I'd like to note about the script is that this story has a decidedly different feel to it than the first movie. The first movie felt more like a mystery, building up suspense until a shocking end. Well in the second it doesn't really operate that way since the mystery has been solved. So naturally the scares are more recurring. So in conclusion, Nakata has done a wonderful job of creating a very scary movie but in the end the story doesn't bring the satisfying ending it did in the first.

review_title: I was laughing when I left the theater. This is a horror movie.
review_detailed_main:
This movie is a ball of confusing plot twists, twists that appear to have been placed in the movie in the same order they came to mind for the screenwriter.

Much like so many bad sketch comedy routines, there are good ideas here, but the execution is so poor you wish the ideas had been given to somebody else. The main characters, Rachel and Aidan, are battling the forces of darkness again, in the form of an angry little girl who was supposed to be dead.

This film, as you likely figured out from the posters and trailer, is about that little girl again. She's not finished. The whole "unfinished business" idea is of course what drives most horror movie sequels, and the use of that concept here is what kills the movie. Why? Because that's all there is - she's not finished. It's not really clear why. It's not clear what you can do to make her stop, either. No strange rule is created along the way to help the main characters get their normal lives back.

In absence of that, the viewer is taken on a bewildering journey through cinematic mistakes. You're left wondering all the while what you just saw, and how it could possibly relate to what's happening next. There are a few good scenes in this film, and those are what kept me from walking out of the theater for the first time in my life. Unfortunately, the director, writers, whoever helped bring this story together, toy with the viewer by giving them these few joyous moments when you think the movie is about to turn into something interesting, and they dash those hopes through dozens of minutes of confusing, meaningless emotion, and dialog that seems like the remnants of the first film.

Then there are the technical problems: Did anyone notice the well they used was completely different at the bottom from the one in the original? Did they do that to make it scarier by being smaller, or because they didn't want to rebuild the original set? Why would a house that recently had its contents put in the basement have a basement stairwell covered in cobwebs? Did the movers slide the furniture down the laundry chute? When things inevitably went wrong in the town the main characters now live in, why did the police only seem to care the first time? For that matter, why would a vehicle that appeared to have been in a series of serious collisions, having only one headlight, be allowed to cruise around town without being stopped by any police? Bear in mind these examples are being given because they won't spoil the film for you. There are pages of ones that would.

If you want to be horrified that a movie like this is being released across the country, this is the movie for you. If you want to be horrified by a well done story about fear, watch The Ring again, and stop the tape right when Rachel tells Aidan that it's over. That's the peak of this story line. Everything else is a disappointment.

I saw this film at a preview screening March 15. I was so glad to have left the theater at the end, and so amused by how stupid the story was, that I started laughing as I walked to my car. I haven't ever given something a 1 rating before, on my mental scale. This movie worked very hard to get it.

To be clear, I didn't see the original Oriental version of this film. I don't know what the original story was. My judgment is based on what I saw in the American adaptation, The Ring, and this terrible sequel.

review_title: Sequels are never as good as the first!
review_detailed_main:
I love Naomi watts (rent Mulholland Drive!), and she made the best out of a shady plot line in Ring Two. If i had directed it, i would not have repeated some of the needles points (another boyfriend, another death etc). the special effects were fantastic (water on the ceiling in bathroom). the other commenter was correct to say that Rachel had a 'motherly moment' with Samara in the first Ring movie in the well, just before the little girl disintegrated. give this movie a break. it's not the best, it's not the worst. if it bores you, turn it off. why stay tuned for 90+ mins so that you can whine about how bad it was? yes they are making a Ring 3; plot not determined. i wish there was more video copying/chasing in this movie too, but the director wanted to try something new.

if you really want a great movie that's creepy, but MAKES SENSE, watch Hide and Seek with Robert DeNiro and Dakota Fanning!

Otherwise, just enjoy this movie for ENTERTAINMENT.

The title of this review says it all. This was 100% the worst movie ever (except maybe the Blair Witch Project). Words can't describe the agony I went through watching it. There was hardly anything going on. 90% of the movie was just Naomi Watts either walking, driving, staring, crying, and looking terrified. For every 1 minute of dialog or plot development, there was 15 minutes of the aforementioned pointless walking/crying/staring/etc. There was really only one part (and by "part", I mean "split-second") that made me actually jump in shock. There was nothing going on in this movie. It did a horrible job of explaining what was even happening. They decided to steal an awesome scene from "Nightmare on Elm Street". You know that scene with all the blood flowing around the room and on the ceiling and whatnot, except they decided to go with bathwater instead of blood, so it sucked anyways. The effects weren't even that good. It's like they just decided to use crummy effects because they knew they would need all the profits they could get out of this.

Terrible movie. Don't let yourself have any part of it. Ever. Don't rent it, don't download it. Just put it out of your memory, and thank me for saving you the from the most agonizing 2 hours of your life.

review_title: A sequel better than the original.
review_detailed_main:
The Ring Two (2005) was a better film than the first one. The story wasn't all that hot but the directing by Japanese film maker Hideo Nakata pulls all of the rabbits out of his hat and uses every trick he knows to make a decent movie with sub-par materials. He some hows manages to make the kid act this time around (he was real bad in the first film). Naomi Watts pulls off a better performance this time around as well. The supporting actors were adequate as well. Too bad the director wasn't given free reins upon the project because he could have made a great film instead of a watchable one.

Let's hope that in the future Hollywood would give Mr. Nakata the chance to really shine! Compared to the other hacks who should be either directing local dinner theaters and community plays, he's actually quite good. The Ring Two is a prime example of what a brilliant director can do with shoddy materials. Make an imitation silk purse out of a sow's ear.

Recommended.

I loved the first re-make of "The Ring". Seeing that in the movie theater sent chills up my spine. I had never been so pleased to actually be moved by a horror film, as I had become very jaded by the horror genre and thought there was nothing that could move me to actually being scared. I also enjoyed the Japanese originals as well. Not as scary as the remake, but I appreciated the source material. Then we come to "The Ring Two" and I have to say...

It was a let down. Very contrived and self absorb ant relationship between the mother and child. The sequel might have been better if they explored what had happened up to the point where the movie actually began, I'm referring to the viral nature of that VHS cassette being passed among all those teenagers. I know there had been a short down but it could have been expanded. Instead, we got this dull, plodding mess!

review_title: Why even bother to make the sequel at all?
review_detailed_main:
Saw this one for free (thank goodness) at a local sneak preview/critics screening.

We find Rachel and Aidan have moved to the tiny, quiet town of Astoria, Oregon. A town better known for hosting "The Goonies".

Sometime after the original they have left Seattle and Samara behind. Rachel is now working for the local paper and Aidan is, well being weird. Which is what he is good at.

Life is turning out to be pretty dull but then the death of a local teen and a mysterious mute witness catch Rachel's attention. She is lead to conclude that Samara and the video have caught up with them. Before she knows what is happening though Aidan is losing body heat, waking up screaming in terror and covered in bruises.

Seems that all is not well and the past is not that easily left behind.

Soon Rachel is once again on a quest to save herself and her son from the awful fate that Samara has in store for them. She tries to discover more about Samara and her origins but all that really does is confuse the viewer and create huge plot holes.

Sissy Spacek is wasted in this awful follow up to a great horror flick. Naomi Watts is bored and boring. David Dorfman is well...weird.

Do yourself a favor, save your money and wait for the DVD. Or better yet, wait even longer to see it on HBO for free.

Attended a screening this evening [17/03/05] and I'm sorry to say that it's really no good at all.

All the regular elements are here, in somewhat forced scenes, and far from catchy and abstract, like they were in the first Ring. I can't help but thinking they put some scenes there just to make the occurrences make sense, which they eventually do not.

I must say I liked the first one better, mainly because of the stylish way of filming, which lacks in the sequel. Probably due to Nakata's Japanese, and thus very "naked" way of filming. So he refused to add some innovative visual approach to it. What he DID add was the regular Hollywood-trash we see in every so-called scary movie. Unexpected scares, hands, faces, all that jazz. Like I said, the abstract and floating threat from The Ring and certainly the Japanese original, is totally absent. In this sequel it's just good against evil, the ancient battle, with ancient means of portraying that. And it's boring.

I tend to think the producers bent Nakata's initial idea into mainstream chewed out horror.

There was nothing, actually, that kept me glued to the canvas. I just wanted to make sure I was right about the ending.

Very obsolete sequel. Might be good for the money though. I'm afraid they killed the goose now. Or jumped the shark. Whatever.

Skip this trash.

review_title: A horror movie that was just so-so
review_detailed_main: The Ring Two is the second in a series of movies of horrifying events that occur in connection with an unmarked two-minute videotape. Newspaper reporter Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts) and her son Aidan (David Dorfman) have moved to a small town, Astoria, Oregon, to get away from the terrifying events that happened to them in Seattle. Rachel now works for the local newspaper, The Astoria Gazette, when she hears on the police scanner that the police are investigating the mysterious death of a teenager. Rachel goes to the crime scene and discovers that Samara Morgan is back, starting a new cycle of death by taking her revenge on the people of Astoria. Aidan begins to lose body temperature, so Rachel takes him to the hospital. Hospital doctors find bruises on Aidan, and they believe Rachel has been abusing him. Rachel is barred from seeing Aidan until an investigation is completed. To stop what is happening to Aidan, Rachel goes back to the home of Samara Morgan in Seattle to find the truth. For a horror movie, it was just so-so. I did jump out of my seat a few times, but it wasn't that scary. Actually, the audience laughed at some of the scary scenes. You can wait to see this one, and the door is open for a third movie. (DreamWorks Pictures, Run time 1:51, Rated PG-13)(4/10)

review_title: Relatively well done sequel, when compared to other sequels
review_detailed_main: Many sequels really drag down after the initial film creates a buzz. Very few outshine or are on par with the original film. "Ring Two" falls somewhere in between. While it doesn't fall in the bowels of sequel "suck-dom", it definitely doesn't do the original justice. The direction by Hideo Nakato and Naomi Watt's acting definitely save it from sequel mediocrity. As for the storyline, I felt that it didn't flow evenly with the premise of the original. Although a link could be made, it is very brittle and prone to many logistical flaws, even when you get rid of the "suspension of disbelief" theory. The film has some intelligent moments to it, but these moments get spoiled when a character decides to explain the obvious. Overall, I would say I did enjoy the film, but I definitely wasn't overwhelmed by it.

review_title: Falls into the ever growing genre of sequel mis-fires
review_detailed_main: The movie itself has a good plot with decent movement of story-telling throughout the picture. Unfortunately, it fails to bring the thrills and suspense of the original. A decent story, but too similar to a sixth sense storyline where the entire movie is building up to a crescendo, but leaves you short of a great ending. The story needed introduction of new characters and character development. The only new main character is Max (Simon Baker) who is an editorial writer who is working with Rachel (Naomi Watts). However, the director and writers did not explain his relationship with Rachel well enough. Would a co-worker who you barely know really drop everything they are doing to help you in your problems? Probably not. Had the romantic interests between them be more developed, it would have made more sense. David Dorfman (Aiden), does a fantastic job as Aiden in this movie. His stares at Rachel sent chills up my spine many-a-times. The only real suspense of the movie occurs in the last 5 minutes. But I'll let you view that for yourself. If you loved The Ring like most people did, go see The Ring 2.

review_title: Not as Terrible as You Might Think
review_detailed_main:
"The Ring 2" has received a lot of heat from critics and audiences alike, and I think that has to do with the fact that ever since "The Grudge" (a terrible piece of schlock that unfairly grossed over 100 million at the US box office) there seems to be a new horror-thriller of that ilk released every other week. And they are all terrible. So here finally comes the sequel to the film that started this derivative "Sixth Sense" meets Japanese horror blend of schlocky US movie trend ("The Grudge" standing tall as the most successful of them, second only to the movie it ripped off--the original "Ring"), and everyone seems to hate it.

Yes, without artistic hack master supreme Gore Verbinski (the best for-hire director working these days, in my honest opinion) at the helm, "The Ring 2" is set adrift in watery dream imagery and non-sensical hugger-muggery. Granted, the first film didn't make much sense when you thought about it, but it did have a very sustainable level of atmospheric mystery and dread ratcheted up for maximum shock value. Here, we get a more psychologically taut look into the progressive madness of a mother driven to the brink of insanity. The "Ring 2" ends up not being a horror movie, but a postcard visit (lost of dreadfully pretty imagery again here, though not as artistically astute as the stuff Verbinski brought us in the original) into the mind of a woman who thinks she has to kill her son to save him from the evil in the world. This ends up becoming a two-person show: Naomi Watts, picture perfect again as a mad woman, and young David Dorfman doing some nice child acting ranging from borderline Autistic to split personality. All in all, for a sequel, this wasn't too bad, and unlike most recent horror movies, it's anchored (ala Nicole Kidman in "The Others") by a go-for-broke performance from an accomplished actress. In the end, it unfortunately was not sunk by its own faults, but by the drudge of sewage that it inspired in other lesser films.

review_title: 4 out of 10 (and I'm trying to be nice...)
review_detailed_main:
Long story short, if you liked the first Ring (first US version that is), you will be disappointed in this. And if you disliked the first Ring, don't waste your time.

I'm not one to leave reviews usually, but since I saw this at a screening I thought I could forewarn movie-goers when it's up and you actually have to pay for it.

Without giving anything away, the movie is just an additional, unnecessary movie. It's a rehashing of the first movie, and in that sense not surprising, good, or even scary. There were maybe 4 points which gave me a startling jump, but not a big one, just moments where in the silence something pops up or music sounds.

To further illustrate that it was not at all scary, the theater I was in had people LAUGHING at numerous points. I mean outright laughing, and not one or two people. Especially the Deer scene, the whole theater was laughing (maybe because in Western New York deer are nothing special). You'll see when you see the deer scene...

There's also one scene with something that's supposed to be "scary," Naomi Watts screaming, and loud music...and then right at the end there are 3 sharp claps. CLAPS? I turned to the person next to me and said "What's with the clapping? Is that supposed to be scary?"

Overall it felt like a waste, and I'd be surprised if it did well at the box office. When it got to the ending, I thought, oh...THAT'S all she needed to do to stop it?? I waited 2 hours for that?

I tried to be open minded, but I felt like my time was wasted...but at least not my money, since it was a free screening.

4 out of 10 stars.

review_title: I'm the person on earth that absolutely loves this sequel!
review_detailed_main: The sounds are a masterpiece, thrilling the way it was filmed, and still effectively scary even warms my heart when I watch The Ring films. Great to see Rachel and Aiden for sure even if others don't like other characters or aspects I love it all! Hideo Nadatka directed more of a horror experience where as Gore Verbinski had more genuine authenticity which I appreciate regardless. I even love the ending, I enjoy being the odd one out.

i went to see this movie because i had been waiting for it for a long time, since i heard about it anyway. When i saw the first one, i was in shock among other stuff (lets just say i embarrassed myself), anyway, i figured i might as well see it to make my own judgment since i heard both good and bad reviews about it, now I'm not gonna give any spoilers, so don't worry, but this movie was not scary, i mean, i did jump in 1 or 2 parts but i left the theater"dry", i payed 4.75 to see it and it was worth that much, i think i would have been more upset if i would have payed 8 bucks to see it.

overall, i think that unless you really have to, don't see this movie

This is the worst waste of a piece of film I have ever seen. I really enjoyed the first movie, but this one stinks up the theater. I hated almost every minute of this film, sighing at horror clichés and cracking up during thoroughly unbelievable parts of this movie. Namoi Watts is utterly horrible, disappointing all of her fans with this film. It looks as if she didn't even show up to work at all, merely mailing in a performance. The direction of this film is some of the worst I have ever seen. I have no idea what they were thinking when they shot this film. The scenes are jumpy and don't really make sense. The script is awful as well. All of the dialouge doesn't even seem to go together and the plot build is non-existent. It's as if they cut out huge chunks of the film and forgot to add anything back. I had such expectations for this movie and I don't even remember what they were. It didn't matter... that movie was terrible. That's all there is to say.

I consider myself to be a hardcore horror movie fanatic. A lot of people in my town went and seen the Ring Two because it took place here (Astoria, Oregon). This movie was not a horror, suspense, mystery, or thriller. This movie was nothing more than a simple attempt for the producer to make more money. There was not one part in this movie that made me jump. Several scenes of this movie had me saying, "What? Do they think we haven't seen the first one? That makes no sense". And even more parts of this movie had me laughing at the crumby graphics and lame attempts to make us jumps. In the sold out theater I never once heard anyone gasp. The only sounds I heard were snickers and laughs at a couple random jokes the characters made.

For all of you Ring fans, I'm sorry. This movie was a total let-down for me and I waited for three months just to waste my five dollars. Don't waste yours. If you are one of the few people that thought this movie was suspenseful or scary; I think that you're a simple person and I advise you to see more movies.

review_title: Samara wants a mother, and she does anything and everything to get one.
review_detailed_main:
It really wasn't that bad, and me and my friends have fun with saying quotes from the movie. I can't tell anyone why someone would call it horrible, and it really wasn't.

What else could you want with closing the plot? Sure, it wasn't as scary or suspenseful as the first one, but, it was a good way to end... of course, what do I know? I'm just some Samara-crazed 14-year old girl.

No, but really, I don't think you could call it bad, at all. Everyone in my family and all my friends who come over all want to see the movie again and again.

is horrible. If you expect this to be anything like the first then you will be thoroughly disappointed. What made the first one great, the mood the color, is not in this one. After i came out of the movies, I was stunned on how bad it was. Once back at my house i immediately came here to see who directed it and not to my surprise it wasn't Gore Verbinski, the director of the first. this movie wasn't even scary, let alone it had no atmosphere to it. Numerous points throughout the movie would the audience laugh...hint CGI...and i saw some leave before it ended. Please do yourself a favor and wait for this movie to come out on DVD before waisting your money at the movies.

review_title: Not as good as the first but still spooky and worth watching
