For me this one did not play as well as the first. The change in direction of the story worked reasonably well but seemed a little forced and patched together.

The young boy (Aidan) played by Davis Dorfman was extremely irritating and did interfere with the enjoyment of the film.

Despite these criticisms the film was still quite spooky in places and quite enjoyable.

Worth seeing, especially when alone, though I would say that rather than taking the story to the next level it presented itself as the trailing edge to The Ring

review_title: A really spooky film... in the land of NOT
review_detailed_main:
The Ring Two is an awful, awful flick. If The Ring Two went to school, it would definitely be riding the short bus. Here's a list of things that are scary in this movie:

1- An evil tree that grows on a wall

2- Rabid-evil-killer-computer-animated deer (all bucks because does aren't as freaky or sharp)

3- Nothing (See above)

Now, I really enjoyed the first Ring, and it's nice to see that they brought back Naomi Watts and the kid, but seriously, how did they sign back on for this piece of garbage? The acting is fine, the direction is pretty cool at times, but what holds this flick back is an absurd story and some gaping loop holes in its plot.

All in all, this movie has an AWESOME FACTOR of about 10 out of a hundred.

Please refrain from making a third Ring, Hollywood.

review_title: "She wants to live for real this time."

It tries to drag out the original premise...instead it presents a garbled incoherent storyline that is so forgettable that I can't even tell you what it's about. Do not waste time on this. Sucked.

review_title: I like the first movie of "The Ring" a lot, but this it is even better. by: SYLVIA HERAS

review_title: either the result of Hollywood's greed...
review_detailed_main:
or the running out of ideas - That must have been the only reason this awful sequel was made. I liked the first film, I thought it was creepy and the ending was great. But, this movie was terrible. First of all, the sequel breaks all the rules we learned from the first film. In order for Samara to kill you, you have to watch the tape. Well, they come up with this lame story of 2 kids watching the tape and it happens to be in the same town Rachel is living in. So, some how Samara tracked her down. review_title: A frightening horror movie that is filled with suspense and excitement
review_detailed_main:
The most suspense sequel this year makes a dramatic impact in cinemas this week as The Ring continues its frightening climax.

Acclaimed director, Hideo Nakata has created a nail-biting masterpiece designed for brave cinema fans as they embark on a journey of excitement and terror.

With a fairly unknown cast the story begins as Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts) and her son Aidan (David Dorfman) move to the community of Astoria, Oregon to start a new life.

As Rachel gets a job at the local newspaper office and Aidan starts at a new school, their lives seem to be getting back to normal.

However the haunted past they left behind soon catches up with them as Rachel learns of an apparent homicide, she immediately suspects involvement with Samara and the ghostly videotape. She destroys yet another copy of the tape, but that only makes Samara angrier.

Now, Rachel has to find a way to put Samara to rest once and for all, before it's too late. Will she rescue her disturbed son in time and will she find out what Samara really is? The film had a rather confusing plot that raised more questions than answers, Is Samara a demon, ghost or the devil and why is Aidan such a strange child? Although I must credit the actors for a convincing array of performances; Born in Shoreham, Naomi Watts (Mulholland Drive, 2001) played the part of Rachel with dignity and David Dorfman was also very promising as the little Aidan; I felt their acting was sheer brilliance for such difficult roles.

But my favourite actor was Simon Baker (L.A. Confidential, 1997) who played the minor part of Max Rourke; His role seemed to strengthen the rest of the small cast.

All in all, this movie is one of the best sequel's I have seen in a long time, its full of suspense, fear, excitement, anger, emotion and will most definitely make you jump out of your seat petrified. Just be warned this is horror at its most horrifying and may even be cursed!

review_title: The Anal Ring Two, cuz it reeks of sh**

review_detailed_main:
At first, when you watch the first five minutes, you know what's going to happen - which ruins the whole point in a scary movie. You know what you're getting into and where the plot line is going.

Although, the good thing about it is that you sit there thinking that you know what's going to happen, but you don't exactly know how or when.

This movie isn't exactly "terrifying" because since you have seen the first, you already know what's going on from the first one. The second doesn't really add to it... it kinda drags... It's sorta like making a sequel to the Texas Chainsaw Massacre. Which would be kinda stupid.

But, the terrifying thought of something coming out of your TV is STILL scary and the thought that they are going to keep coming back.

All in all, the predictable plot kinda ruins the whole scary part, but it's worth the wait to see the ending. The ending is the most memorable! Loved it!

This movie was no where near as good as the first. I mean the first actually scared me this one just seemed lame and boring. I mean the way they did the scary parts were just silly. They made everything look completely different and way less scary

Title: The Ring Two (2005)

Director: Hideo Nakata

Cast: Naomi Watts, David Dorfman, Simon Baker

Review:

After the phenomenal success that was the first film, it was only a matter of time before a second installment would appear in theaters. This time around they decided to let Hideo Nakata the director of the original Japanese version of The Ring (Ringu) helm this sequel. Would it be worth our while to see Samara terrorizing Naomi Watts and her son one more time?

Well if you remember correctly the story in the first flick revolved around a killer videotape. After you watched it you would die in seven days...unless you made a copy and passed it to someone else and that someone else actually watches it...then you are free of the curse. This time around the story doesn't focus so much on the killer video tape angle (actually I think its a smart move since VHS movies are a prehistoric creature from the dark ages) and focuses more on the little ghost girl Samara and her origins. She also has a deadly purpose with Rachel and her son.

There's a few things going against this picture right from the beginning. It has to go up against its predecessor and that right there is a tough thing to do. The first Ring film made a real impact on people...it managed to scare without relying on gore, or cheap scares. It was a movie that got into peoples heads and stayed there long after they left the movie theater. And that incredible success and impact that the first movie made is something hard to top. Case in point: this sequel didn't quite surpass the first one. It was good, but not good enough. Comparisons to the first one were going to be inevitable.

One thing that helps this movie is the fact that at least they had a strong cast headed by the great Naomi Watts who never ceases to surprise and amaze me. She is one of the greatest actresses of our time and she always manages to infuse her performances with great emotion and intensity. She does it again here, even though the script is filled with more plot holes then you can care for. David Dorfman who plays her son Aidan did a swell job, and even though people refer to his acting as wooden, I think he did a good job because his character required to be a chilly, calculating character. It was necessary for the story. Sisy Spacek pops up in a cameo as Samaras mom and does a fine job as well.

The movie has some nice moments going for it, like for example the scene in the bathtub which is really cool visually. That image of the water flowing to the ceiling of the bathroom is amazing. And kind of reminiscent of Nakatas other film Dark Water. People might also see the similarities between this movie and the American adaptation of Dark Water with Jennifer Connelly. Ghost girl looking for a mommy. So in originality points Ring Two went down a few notches.

And just when things are going nicely...in come the deer. If you remember correctly on the first ring movie we had a scene in which a horse goes nuts and hurls himself into the ocean. On this one they were trying to duplicate the animal threat element and defy logic at the same time by having some deer go crazy. Now normally I wouldn't decline to having a crazy sequence like that come out of nowhere and make no sense at all...but these deer were CGI deer. And there's nothing worse then computer animated animals. Remember the monkeys of Jumanji or the wolves in The Day After Tomorrow? Or hows about the wolf dog in Cursed? Now you can add another to that list: The Reindeer on The Ring Two. When will directors learn not to computer animate animals? It just doesn't work! A scene that could have worked great in the film had they used real animals turns into a laugh fest and completely takes you out of the movie cause you realize that you are watching a special effect.

Aside from that, the movie doesn't make much sense in many places. Samara being lost? All it takes to put Samara out of action is placing a lid on the well? Didn't Rachel do that already on the first film? There's more loopholes like this one that just get completely ignored. Why would Reindeer attack Rachel and Aidan? Can the animals detect evil or are they being controlled by Samara? Anyhows, all in all this movie didn't live up to the legacy left by its predecessor. Its not a bad film, it has beautiful visuals, good performances and moments. But it was just too low key, a little too mellow and failed to muster up the intensity and feeling of dread that we got from the first one.

Rating: 3 out of 5

review_title: One Of The Worst Sequels I've Ever Seen
review_detailed_main:
Didn't see it at the flicks to see it (thank god) and heard it wasn't up to the first film, but decided to give it a go anyway.

I didn't expect it to be as bad as it was. Atrocious plot, acting all round and a pity I won't be able to get back the two hours wasted watching it.

Was expecting so much better from Hideo Nakata after both versions of the Ring were like how all scary movies should be. The only part that made me jump was the deer scene.

Has to rank with some of the worst sequels ever made!!! Anyone else agree?

i think for people to say it was worse than the first film is a fair point but it really isn't the truth at all. the way this film carries itself is amazing due to the direction by Nakata you can actually believe this film a lot more than the first one. the ring, was such an over the top teen horror film with lack of intellect. the ring 2 displays a much more realistic psychological approach even though the entire concept is based on such a "childish interpretation of supernatural horror". nothing in the film is over the top or Hollywood or too scary it focuses much more on the break up in scare throughout the picture. you would see a scene where you think something is going to happen but it doesn't then it will calm down but you still have the tension lurking due to the great acting and then something will happen and the psycho's of the audience and the characters are played with a lot more and because of the psychological disturbance the film doesn't need to be over dramatised but is made more eerie and believable. even though it is predictable in some parts the journey of the film and the ending and certain parts are misleading which in turn is playing with the viewers as well the characters and leaves you feeling somewhat confused and uncertain of what you have seen. its a great film and i would recommend any one to see it. its not exactly Hollywood horror or screams, its more of a messed up psychological war of emotions and reactions and reality is played into an unreal script. well done hideo nakata, you can tell its directed by a Japanese director...

review_title: Movie to see, not to respect.
review_detailed_main:
I went tonight to see this movie with bad expectations due to the reviews that I read in the website and also taking in consideration the rating and the usual sequels disappointments. Being honest I liked, isn't as bad as most people have said, it explains a little bit more stuff about samara and why she have done all this trouble, it does have some scary parts, not as freaky as the 1st one..The performances are good, same as the special effects. If you liked the 1st one a lot and you're a fan of it, you should see this one, but don't expect it to be better as the 1st part.

Rodolfo G .Valdes R. Panama, Panama

review_title: This just wasn't a good film
review_detailed_main: I know it's hard for some facts to be excepted by die-hard fans, but in this case it needs to be excepted. This just wasn't a very good film, it was awful. It succeeded only in trashing the mythology of the original, which set so many standards for the new-age horror film. Why should we as fans enjoy this muck that takes a horrid u-turn in the plot and logic? Why? What the hell was Dreamworks thinking? Did Naomi except the script? Or was she forced to do this crap by the studio? This film is ludicrous. We find Rachel Keller and her son Aiden, running of to the nearest town that will probably protect them from the Seattle nightmare, but predictability catches up with the otherwise new story, and not only ruins the fun, but makes the film less novel. All this happens in the first 30 minutes or so. Next, we are taken through the most unexplainable events that writer cannot back up, and to build the stupidity even lower, the original mythology is reconstructed with the most lame explanation in the book! I will let you all find out what this is on your own, but you probably already know. The last reel is horribly laughable, with conformist dialogue and pathetic special effects that look like a play-station video-game. Please, heed the right warnings and stay away from this film, even the most dedicated of fans have been disgusted by this odious pile of illogical feces! 0/10, and I'm being generous!

The directing in this movie was the thing that ruined the movie for me it had a different mood than the first one . I can say that Gore Verbinski is a better director and he held the main piece of the success of the first one and it was much better than Ringu, I don't know why they changed the director the movie lost the sequel sense, felt flat without any sense of horror. I think anyone who have seen the first one must watch it but don't expect much.

review_title: Possibly the worst sequel I've seen!
review_detailed_main: I watched this film purely out of curiosity, to see if could be anywhere near as good as the 'The Ring'. I was so disappointed! The plot was weak, I didn't care what happened in the story, I just wanted the film to end so I could leave the cinema without disturbing the people sitting near me! The way the film was shot, the colours, camera angles, even the special effects were completely different to the first film. This may have been intentional, but for 'The Ring' the way the film was directed is one of the elements that make it so good. The characters have changed in 'Ring 2' also. Naomi Watts character is no-where near as convincing, nor is Aidan's character, although having seen their brilliant performances in the first film I think this is the fault of the weak screenplay and direction as opposed to the actors in question. The first film had a complex plot which drew me in and kept me interested, it was full of powerful imagery that confused and unnerved me, and it created tension from the start, creating a mood which remained consistent to the end. This sequel had none of this and I would suggest if you enjoyed 'The Ring', then you will be disappointed if you watch 'Ring 2'. I have seen 'The Ring' several times now and thoroughly enjoy it every time - even though I know how it ends! I will never bore myself by attempting to sit through 'Ring 2' again. Very poor!!

Actually, I know people who liked this one better than the first "Ring" and even if they are good friends of mine, I cannot follow their opinion. "Ring 2" was not bad and had its moments. It was well acted and some scares worked. The scene with the deer for example was a great one, but then again, so many other moments I was just bored. Maybe its my own fault, because the First "Ring" managed it to be in my personal All-time-favorites and so expectations were pretty high and though I tried to lower them, the presented sequel didn't even catch up with those.

"The Ring 2" is more a drama with suspense-elements, than a real horror-flick. The mother/son story was well presented, the camera was excellent, the music with its Japanese kitsch was annoying in some parts. Where they used the original score, it worked. Hideo Nakata should have watched his Japanese Colleagues remake of "The Grudge". This guy knew how to scare and create a creepy atmosphere.

Well: maybe if I see it again (on DVD) I will like it better, because then I know what to expect and I might see it different then. But right now, a day after the "Ring-Experience" I'm still disappointed and I wish I would have been patient enough to wait for the DVD-Release.

6 Stars out of 10 are okay, because it was not bad and maybe, but just maybe, I will love it if I see it again.

Before I start I have to say that the Ring was much better than the Ring 2. However, i had a feeling it would be that way. First off, you have to consider what made the first one so scary. The fact that you didn't know what was causing the deaths was what found the most frightening and the twist ending was great. When you know what's coming it's just not as scary. But in the Ring 2's defense it could have been a lot worse (As many sequels are). There were a few scary moments but what I found really killed the movie was how some of the scenes seemed rushed or unfinished (namely the scene in the basement where all the lights start going out). They could have done much more with some of the ideas they brought up and it was disappointing to see it fall short. So the Ring 2 wasn't great but could we really have expected much more from it?

I rarely give movies a 1, since most movies have some redeeming feature, but in this case, there really isn't any.

It's a follow up of the original Ring, sort of. The original Ring was part horror movie, part mystery. It was a about a mysterious tape which causes the viewer to die in 7 days, and the main character, Rachel (played by Naomi Watts) watched the tape, along with her ex (and later her kid). It worked well because the characterization of both her and her ex was quite good, the viewer liked the characters and so were concerned about them. And the mystery behind the tape was unraveled slowly but deliberately, giving the view just enough to be drawn in.

The sequel misses the mark in just about every fashion. It starts off like the original, we think, but it seems the rules have changed - a person watching the tape has to convince someone else to watch the day within 7 days or they die. But this premise is dropped almost immediately, and the story revolves around Rachel's son, Aidan, who mysteriously becomes ill with hypothermia.

The characterization in this movie is simply awful. None of the characters have any sort of personalities - they are as wooden as a Keanu Reeves puppet. There is no "deadline", so there is no feeling of impending doom for any of the characters. It tries to repeat the mystery aspect of the original, bur rather than slowly decoding subtle clues in the video, the mystery is solved by a simple visit to the basement of a house. The acting was pretty much lethargic, other than the very brief appearance by Garry Cole. At some times, you have to wonder who would fall asleep first, the actors or the audience...

The finale is completely predictable as well. Some bad movies are fun to laugh at (or with, in the case of campy movies). But this just is almost painful to watch.

This movie is the continuation of The Ring, picking up six months where the first story left off. Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts) and her son Aiden (David Dorfman) leave Seattle to live in a small rural town, away from all the horror. But, she hears that high school student Jake (Ryan Merriman) watched the tape and dies, leaving his girlfriend Emily (Emily VanCamp) to cope. Therefore, Rachel then realizes she once again has to save Aidan from the evil Samara (Kelly Stables).

Like the first movie, this film will grip your heart with fear and tug at your mind. This movie's scary images, from the horrible expressions of the victims' faces to the scenes of the evil videotape, will send chills down your spines. You will find answers to questions left unresolved from the first movie, making the entire story come full circle.

And, like the first film, this picture's overall gripping horror element will keep you both scared and entertained at the same time. Loads of fun.

Grade B

review_title: the unrated DVD is much better!! but still not enough...
review_detailed_main: the first two Japanese rings(which are directed by Hideo Nakata) were OK, the third one as i see it it was junk. Now, i believe Hideo Nakata after the Japanese rings, wanted to change the story. well it was disappointing. it didn't lead me anywhere important about the whole Samara thing. if although you are a maniac about "the Ring" then i would recommend it to you but if you liked the first ring which indeed was perfect and you just want to learn more about Samara i wouldn't recommend it to you. at the cinema would just a waste of time and money, at home... maybe you 'ill like it. i really hope there is a third one because then "The Ring Two" is just another horror junk film

review_title: Oh look its Exorcist 8, but without the puke

review_detailed_main:
The first movie was a real crowd pleaser.It had tons of scares and Naomi Watts did an excellent job at playing Rachel.Although she did a good job in the first Ring movie,she doesn't deliver much in 'the Ring Two.'First off,it's not scary.Not one bit.The director tried to scare audiences just like he did with his other horror movies,but doesn't succeed.I did like David Dorfman's character though.He did a good job in the first movie and another in this one.This time around,Samara,the scary villain from the first movie,is back to terrorize Rachel and her son.It's a good plot,but it doesn't help the movie.Don't get me wrong,I enjoyed this movie,but only a little bit.I found it entertaining,but not as the first.It's not bad,but it's certainly no classic.

6.4/10

By the time the giant stags start attacking the car, it's apparent that "The Ring Two" has no rules. By dispensing with even the meager narrative constraint that governed the first "Ring" (see a tape, die in a week unless someone else sees it), "The Ring Two" excuses itself from any unreasonable expectations of coherence and basic cause and effect. The deer are agitated by the possession of Rachel Keller's son Aidan by the vengeful spirit Samara, the dead little girl with a very bad hair day from the first film. Also because a car surrounded by a herd of threateningly serene ungulates is a vaguely creepy sight.

Having fled the big city stresses and soul-sucking demons of Seattle with her son, Rachel (Naomi Watts) is relieved to begin a new life as a small town reporter in Astoria, WA. Evil little Samara, though, is NOT cool with that, and follows them to the boondocks, where she quickly decides that she likes Aidan enough to stay awhile in his body. How does she manage all this? She shows up one night in their TV; being a malevolent spectre does involve some neat party tricks. Other things she can do, in addition to the aforementioned steer steering, include making trees erupt in flames, causing bathwater to rain up to the ceiling (an admittedly arresting visual), and impelling people to kill themselves just by looking at them. Although this seems a far more stimulating existence than most of us lead, Samara is determined to stick around in poor Aidan's body, presenting Rachel with a dilemma: under what name should she enroll her son in prep school? Arbitrary and nonsensical imagery is a favorite horror staple, but without even the sketchiest narrative framework within which to present it, we're left with a bewildering grab-bag of grotesquerie. "The Ring Two" is simply a series of Scary Ghost Tricks, connected by nothing we can grasp with which to make sense of them. Sissy Spacek does a cameo turn as Samara's scissor-wielding mental patient mother, the victim of a series of psychiatric facilities with the worst patient confidentiality records ever seen. "Listen to the voices," she tells Rachel, "be a good mother." Call me old fashioned, but any notion of motherhood that comes from disembodied voices seems to me a bit suspect. In the third act, when Rachel literally climbs into the deadly video to do battle - the video that keeps turning up on her TV even though the last existing tape of it has been destroyed -we've been bludgeoned into just letting the film get on with its absurd business. Strangely enough, "The Ring Two" ends with nary a twist nor opening for a future installment. It's a shame, really; that prospect would be the scariest thing this mess could muster.

review_title: missing why everyone loved the first one...
review_detailed_main:
What was so wrong about the original that they had to make it so different? It only had half the atmosphere of the first ring, and non of the style. The first one was smart and in a way bad-ass! This one played it safe and tried to hard to be like the grudge. The first one had such atmosphere and knew not to show too much of Samara so as not to make it look like a cheap horror instead of a smart horror/thriller. The surprise ending could have been better shown, and for some reason in this movie Samara is the same ugly brown color through the whole film, I like the whole black and white thing from the first movie.

Well enough with the negative, this movie does have its positives or els I wouldn't give it a 6/10. The story line was very interesting and Niome Watts was showing most of her talent- and she has a lot of talent. David Dorfman was alright but he seamed to be better in the first one. The drama was good too,I loved how Rachel Keller was again faced with a moral and complicated dilemma. The scene in the well was very suspenseful but the whole thing about Samara moving like kayako from the grudge wasn't well played, i think the fast motion was a little too fast and made Samara look like a spider. But again a very suspenseful scene.

This is for the director of the ring 3 which is rumored to come out in 08: please watch the first ring and follow in it's example don't make this even worse than the ring 2 witch has i think 2.2 less stars than it's predecessor.

Say goodbye to just about everything that made the original film so terrifying. Naomi Watts is back and still the lead, but her character is given much less to work with and the stakes seem, somehow, less extreme than they were before.

This time, Rachel and son Aiden have moved away from Seattle and discover that supernatural murderess Samara is still terrorizing people via a cursed video tape and, this time, she wants to come back into the real world by possessing Aiden.

A similar idea was explore in the 2nd Nightmare on Elm Street film with more fun results. The Ring Two takes its self too seriously to ever be much fun and there aren't any big scares that don't come across as laughable like a horde of CGI deer attacking Rachel and Aiden in their car.

review_title: Again, I'm in the Minority: I Liked It!
review_detailed_main:
While this work is a far cry from the original, it is such merely due to a preponderance of Samara's story, thereby negating the stylish mystique generated by the predecessor. Therefore, this work is more typical than a-typical of American horror movies, and as such, it plays more or less like what one might expect of an American horror sequel in that it breaks its own rules, omits information given the audience in the previous installment, and thus bears less credibility than The Ring.

However, in spite of the story variations, and other moderate problems, this sequel is still quite enjoyable. The performances contributed by David Dorfman and Naomi Watts were exemplary, and the story itself still bears a wonderful, darkling atmosphere. True, the atmosphere is not as serious or thick as the first, but it is still quite enjoyable.

If you like horror movies in general, and enjoyed the original, I would suggest a viewing, in spite of the naysayers. I, at least, liked it.

It rates a 7.6/10 from ...

the Fiend :.

I saw The Ring, and It is my favorite scary movie of the decade by far. It has an amazing , interesting plot, and ended flawlessly. It was excellent and the acting was uncomparable when it comes to scary flicks.

You can imagine how I felt when I heard about part two. Ultra excited. At the same time though, I promised myself not to get my hopes up, and I didn't.

The Ring 2 was actually extremely good. Not the best scary flick of the decade, wasn't even as scary as the first, but as a part two, it was very enlightening. You learn a lot about the story, and meet new characters that reveal interesting information about the plot.

If you saw part one, even if you hated it, you need to catch partt two. You won't regret it.

I heard from friends who went to the theaters to see this movie that it was really bad so I didn't buy the DVD. They were right. A friend who has Netflix let me watch this movie and I was so dissatisfied with it that I had to go to "imdb" to find out who is responsible for this 1hr 50 minute waste of time. "The Ring" is an American remake of a good Japanese horror flick just like "The Grudge". "The Ring Two" is unbearable until you get to the last few scenes. Movies lack the heart they had years ago. Now we have nothing but sequels to movies that weren't that good to begin with, and attempts to sum up TV shows with 2 hours of chaos. We're running out of ideas.

review_title: Sewn together from every other movie out there.
Bad sequel for the most impressive movie!
review_detailed_main:
"The Ring" is one of the most impressive movie I saw in 2002. Story is perfect. Script is good. This is the best Asia horror remake to American yet. But the sequel for this movie was not needed.

"The Ring Two" beginning idea was just like from the original, but later... it was not "The Ring" movie. Scenes, script and idea is good, but it will be perfect, if it was not named "The Ring Two".

Naomi Watts and David Dorfman are still good talents and acted the same, like in original, but the reincarnation of Aidan and girl was bad thing in this movie.

In "The Ring Two" I never heard the ring, who tells, that you have 7 days and the tape was watched, just 1 time in movie. So it's really not "The Ring" sequel... Rating is 5...

simply put, this is a hastily thrown together sequel trying to catch onto the end of the Asian horror trend inflicting America at the moment. It's not terrible by any means but a lack of shocks and tension simply turns it a little boring, and some of the decisions by the mother in this film are so unbelievable its unreal! Nevertheless, the finale is a highlight and picks up the movie a point or two. At first I was glad to hear that the ring two was an original script, but I left the theatre wishing they had just remade ringu 2 or not bothered at all.

My advice to anyone disappointed by this is to go to the real thing instead of these watered down knock offs. see ringu, ringu 2, ringu 0, the grudge, dark water (which this movie borrows plot points from!) I guarantee all on this list are creepier and simply better than the ring two

Gore: 1/5

Scares: 2/5

acting:3/5

Story:3/5

overall: 6/10

I can't put up with this utter tripe any longer it's mealy a soulless money making exercise. It has some reasonably impressive scenes with the dead girl well there are enough of them to fill a music video, I guess. It's amazing to me how terrible horror films have become in the great days of the 70's they had less money it looked like people cared for what they were doing or if it was corny they knew it but at least it was fun. I'm shore you will like this film if you like the current style of big horror movies and can't be bothered to delve in to the archives. Rather than to invest your time on this disgrace face it the people who make these movies don't care about your needs they care about your wallet and this SUCKS!

Please young person buy the changeling half these films seem to be ripping it off anyway! And if you have got it watch it again keep your money the sooner we stop paying to see these movies the sooner they will stop making them. I will never make the mistake of letting someone make me watch a film like this again.

review_title: This is more Bizarre than the first
Loved it then, Hate it now
review_detailed_main:
I loved the Ring 1, it was one of my favorite horror movie a long time ago. It had a good story, good plot, good people, and it was very scary. Left he on the edge of my living room couch. But the Ring 2 did not give me this feeling, and I was very angry that I wasted a good amount of money that could of been used for a greater good, and a waste of my time watching it.

The directors decided to get lazy with this movie I believe, and wanted to get more money off this sequel, which the whole idea of the movie is Samara going around and killing random, weird people. Whereas Thr Ring actually had a plot to it, and it's not just the girl doing random stuff. Thank god that they aren't making a 3rd one, to destroy the already destroyed movies.

It really does make me mad that directors always do this to really good movies, I could name a whole list of movies that have been ruined because of their sequels, this is one of them. Do not watch it, if you are thinking about watching this, watch the first one, but not the second one, or be ready for some terrible and big disappointment. This movie definitely deserves a 1 out of 10, at the best.

The Ring Two was a good sequel, but it didn't live up to the first film, 'The Ring'. The first hour of the film was relatively slow, and it took a while to entertain me. It did not link the scenes well, as it was one scary and strange thing after another.

One of the main problems of the film, i feel was the director 'Hideo Nakata'. Gore Verbinski, director of the first film made it absolutely superb, and you can see the difference now that he has gone.

Apart from that, the film was very good and i enjoyed it, and i recommend you watch it as soon as possible. You won't enjoy it as much, but you'll like it definitely. Overall, this is a pretty good sequel! Peace.

review_title: A Step Down From The First Movie
Completely Ruined a movie that shouldn't have a sequel

review_detailed_main: Why Watts, Dorfman and Chase chose to be in this poorly written and poorly directed debacle is beyond me. Unlike the original "Ring", which mixes mystery and suspense with horror, "Ring II" lacks all of the aforementioned elements - including a solid storyline. Though Kruger made the first movie shine with in-depth characters fighting their way through a riveting tale, "Ring II" has absolutely no dramatic or emotional hooks to invite the audience to care. The beginning setup of the movie takes far too long and many subsequent scenes are dragged out. Plus, some questions from the first film go unanswered. Besides a completely lame story, the CGI was subpar and, therefore, utterly distracting.

This movie was an hour and 50 minutes long and it is an hour and 50 minutes of my life that I will never have back. What a waste. It is a blatant attempt by movie studios to make money on the merit of the first movie. Nothing new is ever brought to the table, in fact most of the story makes no sense due to the guidelines of the first. I was utterly disappointed in this quote unquote "sequel". Thank goodness I didn't manage to get to the theater to see this one. I can't imagine having wasted that kind of money! I recommend that you save your money and pass on this dud! Take my advice. I wish someone else had posted such a warning to me.

Anything that made the original Ring a success, Ring 2 has less and everything that was a flaw is increasingly present. What your left with is a typical sequel which fails where its predecessor did better, and being a horror film it sinks even lower.

review_title: Could've been worse, could've been better.
review_detailed_main:
This movie is sort of so so. Mostly because the first one was so good so in comparison it doesn't come across that well. It has some very shady CGI in it.

There's just a problem with characters doing things that would never happen. The script wasn't very well done either.

review_title: Lets wait for The Grudge 2, and see if it's gonna be the same over and over again, like this movie is.
review_detailed_main:
The movie wasn't a disappointment, but when you watch the two movies right after each other - like I did, the second seems to be just the same over and over again. It's not as bad as it could be, but it could indeed be better. When you take a look at the actors - which by the way are played very good, no doubt - we only see 3 or 4 main characters, and to be honest, it gets a bit boring to look at them in almost two hours. BUT, I don't wanna seem too negative about the movie, 'cause overall, they got a good result. But please, don't make a third, that's just gonna kill US this time!

Vote: 5/10

review_title: Teeth-grindingly boring and completely devoid of terror sequel
review_detailed_main: THE RING 2 (2005) * Naomi Watts, David Dorfman, Kelly Stables, Daveigh Chase, Simon Baker, Elizabeth Perkins, Sissy Spacek, Gary Cole, Ryan Merriman, Emily VanCamp. Teeth-grindingly boring and completely devoid of terror sequel to the Japanese remake of the cult horror flick with journalist Watts (severely dumbed down inexplicably since the first film) and her spooky kid (Dorfman suggesting an exhumed Culkin) attempt to relocate but are literally haunted by the damn videotaped ghost-in-the-machine Samara (Chase and Stables doing double duty) who wants nothing but vengeance. A severe case of 'been-there-done-that' only underscores the infuriatingly ridiculous plot holes and consistently dopey screenplay by Ehren Kruger (who scribed the first one) and Hideo Nakata's pedestrian direction only suffers when it is realized he directed the original Japanese version to begin with! When the hell will they realize to simply go to DVD?!?!

Let me start off by saying that "The Ring" was a fantastic and disturbing film filled with a lot of suspenseful moments and an interesting back story. That's hardly the case with "The Ring Two." The beginning is basically a re-hash of the first film's beginning, with absolutely no suspense, and corny images. I actually laughed out loud at how corny some scenes were. The whole movie goes by and tries to make logic, while it completely throws out the logic of the first film, where the only way you were safe was to make a copy of the video. The deer scene looked completely fake, and didn't even make sense in the plot...even when you find deer horns in the basement. It never came together. Also, the whole second hour doesn't even TRY to scare the audience at all until the last few minutes, and even then it doesn't work. So, don't hold your breath in suspense. There's not even any false scares.

My theory is that the filmmakers rushed to write this movie after the success of the first one, just to throw it out and make more money, without taking the time to add any logic to the story. There was barely a plot. Also, Naomi Watts was in contract to do the sequel after the first one. That's the only way I see she would've made this movie after the script. At least she acts good and does her best with what she's given.

I will say that the water imagery and the cinematography were outstanding, creating a creepy atmosphere. But it never went anywhere. There were a few interesting parts where I thought the movie would turn into something really good, but that never happened. BOTTOM LINE: Even if you're a fan of the original (like me), you will hate this one.

The Ring was genuinely scary, and to this day I still don't like seeing the traumatized girl in the closet. I really hate doing this to Naomi Watts because she has done some excellent work, but this film should have never been put in the can. It is the typical sequel designed to monetarily capitalize on the success of the original. I have no idea whether it did well financially or not, but story-wise it is godawful. Skip it, especially if you are a fan of The Ring.

This movie is really awful and disrespectful to the first ring film from 2002 it's boring uninteresting pointless plot points not even scary

The only good scene in this movie is the opening since it's technically part of the short film rings which is better then this garbage film

It would have been a better film if they just made rings a full length feature film instead of this

review_title: One ring to rule them all, a second to unmake them
review_detailed_main:
The Ring Two is an inferior sequel to the brilliant original that was actually not original but an American remake of a Japanese horror film (Ringu) that practically started the j-horror sub-genre. The amusing thing is that the director of the original two Japanese Ringus directs the sequel to the American remake. Unfortunately, despite his decent but somewhat bland direction, the script fails at engaging the viewer. It's tedious and predictable where it should have been exciting and fresh. My favorite moment was the controversial wild animals attack. Some complained about their CGI roots, I thought they looked great. Nothing after that grabbed my attention as much. The lack of scares and shocks might be compensated by the stronger emphasis on mystery, mounting dread and atmosphere (usually prevalent in j-horror) but no such luck here. Naomi Watts, the lead reprising her role from the first film, is very good at conveying real emotion and delivers a fine subtle performance.

The character development arc for the son was supposed to be chilling and disturbing but it really wasn't so for me. The boy looked creepy enough from the start but I'm not sure he had the acting chops for the transition. To be fair, that was a difficult role and the script could also be blamed. They put more focus on the origin of the dark-haired girl from the first Ring than the killer videotape (a defensible choice) but beyond the novelty cameo by a famous actress, it wasn't that engrossing or surprising. The Ring Two is highly reminiscent of Dark Water (same genre and same original novel writer) in its themes and you would probably be better off renting that. Ring two is not horrible in itself, it's just so disappointing compared to the original because it feels that by trying to be different, focusing more heavily on characters than plot, they failed to capitalize on the strengths of the Ring except for Naomi Watts who would probably be great no matter what she was in.

Rating: 4.5 out of 10.

in my relatively short life, i've seen loads, tons of movies. i've seen plenty good ones, really good ones, so that i became interested in movies. i've seen many so-sos and a lot of bad ones. but there are very few flicks which left me so aghast like this did. to say it in the words of terry, owner of "central perk": >it's not that it was bad. it is that it was so bad i wanna push my finger through my eye into my brain and swirl it around.< i was going ballistic when i left the cinema. ehren kruger must have thought: hmm... the first one was one of the scariest films ever. celebration for me. let's see what happens if i barf into my pencil and send it to the ape-house. of course that never happened, 'cause apes don't write such ****ed up ****. nothing was scary in this movie. in fact it's like a friend of mine said: ring 2 is like the 60's batman-movies. you just don't buy any of the **** that happens. i cannot believe that nobody warned the people how ridiculously awful this movie would be. and the German press said that it would be better than part one. shame on them. shame on all of you who helped making this movie. above all, shame on ehren kruger. they should have let freddy kruger write the script instead. it would have been more fun. 0 out of 10 points

I am the Ring's biggest fan, but I was so disappointed with the sequel I almost wish I didn't go to see it. The first one had me so scared that I made my boyfriend stay home from work the next day so I didn't have to be alone. I even made him keep the door open when he went in the bathroom because I was so scared. I wanted this movie to be every bit as good as the first, but it pales in comparison. It is hard to believe it is even the same characters and writers. The acting was horrible as well (sorry Naomi) despite the fact they had a decent cast (including Sissy Spacek in a cameo appearance). They must have paid Naomi Watts a heap load of cash to get her to do this movie. She typically selects decent scripts and there is no way she could have read this and thought it was good.

During the movie people were actually laughing. Laughing at the parts that were supposed to be scary. Remember how scary seeing the face of the murder victims was in the first, well in this one, the audience laughed every time.

Plot wise, I was hoping to learn more about the secrets behind the Ring. Things that weren't answered in the first one-like if this all happened so long ago, than how did the movie go from 8mm to VHS and who thought of doing that? Who filmed all this stuff anyway? Why was Samara calling people on the phone right before she killed them? Where was she really from? What created her? What drove her to be evil? They introduce her mother in this one, but we still don't really know what she is or what drives her.

The first one was amazing and brilliant, but the second was just an excuse for the producers to make money off the success of the first one. All I can say is they should have called the Ring Two the Ring Boo! Hope they don't try to do a third one, they are ruining the memory of the first one.

The film continues directly to the successful first part. However, all other comparisons disappear here. There is no atmosphere here, no scary or creepy scenes. A few weird scenes that look bad and by the story don't fit into the movie (a scene with a deer or when we meet a mother). It's relatively boring, too, and that's a big minus for horror. My opinion is that they wanted to make money on the wave of success of the original even in this film. This is not a quality film.
This movie did not have to exist. Why does this movie exist??? Burn it.

review_title: The scare factor is not lost in this sequel!
review_detailed_main: Though Rachel Keller(Naomi Watts) lost her boyfriend in the first movie, she still have her son to take care of. And the scare factor in the sequel to "The Ring" is never lost, the details to know more about the fiendish Samara is ever growing. Knownig her real mother was the biggest shock of all. The parents in the first film were her adopters. The more the plot grew, the more the movie intensifies the viewer. The real changes in the movie is when they replaced the horses with deer. Now that's where the differences take place in the sequel. even though horror movies have no effect on me, "The Ring Two" is just as scary as the first, but in my opinion, I liked the first one better in one way, the sequel in another. The first one I liked the seeing the sexy side of Naomi Watts. The second one I liked the tough side of her. With Samara taken care of in the second one, is there a possibility of a third installment of "The Ring"? We shall see..... Rating 4 out of 5 stars.

review_title: Uncreative rehashing of the first movie
review_detailed_main:
I did not expect the sequel to live up to the first movie, especially since a different director was involved, but even with lowered expectations I was still disappointed that they weren't able to produce a better experience to honor the first movie.

The sequel doesn't really add anything to the story of the first and some parts of the plot are essentially copied and redone from the first movie (sadly, these are the better parts of the movie). It left me with the feeling that most of the sequel could have been included on the original movie's DVD as deleted scenes or alternate scenes. The new director takes away a lot of the frightening power of the Samara character by showing her so frequently throughout the movie that I was used to seeing her towards the end. The original director got a lot more out of the scary scenes of the first movie, but he also had a good story to work with.

I do not recommend this movie to anyone that enjoyed the first. More of the same with less execution just isn't very satisfying.

If I could find the bozo who made this film I'd kick his butt and get my money back! Do not waste your money!

The plot...what plot?

So-so special effects.

Boring story.

Bad acting but I don't think it was the actors fault...it was the script they had to work with that is to blame.

Loose ends were every where.

Again let me warn you (I have to fill up 10 lines). If you go see this movie after I warned you not to you have no one to blame but yourself.

review_title: Does Not Hold a Candle to the First
review_detailed_main:
I thought the first Ring movie was excellent, so I was really looking forward to the sequel. Here is a short list why this movie failed to hold a candle to the first: 1) The original Ring movie consists of well-thought out mystery "Rachel" attempts to unravel throughout the course of the movie. The writers of Ring II try to do the same thing, but nothing is ever discovered. She tries to find answers from the girls real mother and you keep thinking she is going to discover something, but nothing ever happens.

2) The scare element in this movie is all physical and not at all genuine as in the first. Nothing compares to the scene where the little girl crawls out of the television at the conclusion of the first ring. All the scares in this movie are "jump" scenes.

3) The only thing bigger and better in this movie are the special effects, but they are just that...effects, attempting to mask the poor script of this movie.

4) Most importantly the whole concept of this movie "the little girl wants to be the boy" goes against all the "rules" made in the first one. The whole time I'm watching it I'm thinking this is just like when Oliver was added on the Brady Bunch. Thats a pretty far fetched analogy, but if you've seen the movie you get it....they writers were just reaching. Too much time was put into special effects and too little was put into the plot. The Ring II is just a ploy to con Ring I fans out of their money...it worked on me. Way too Hollywood.

Final Thought--- I do not care if you do not agree with this review....when you hit the disagree button all you are telling me is this.... A) you enjoyed meet the fockers. B) You probably did not ever receive a formal education

review_title: What in God's name is going on here?

review_detailed_main:
I just got back from watching The Ring 2 and I have to say that I felt it was pretty middle of the road.

I didn't find anything about it particularly scary. The scenes which were supposed to be scary were more artsy then scary. There were a few of the required jump scenes but I felt that overall, it moved far to slowly. There was a lot of potential but for me it just fell a little short. I think it was because the first one slowly built up to a great ending where this one just never quite got there.

This was more of a drama than horror movie. I really wanted to like this as I loved the first one and I'm not going to say it was bad, because it isn't. It just wasn't to my taste.

review_title: An intelligent tension film that isn't wasted on cheap scares.
review_detailed_main: The Ring Two is one of those rare sequels that contains substance over scares, for all the right reasons, with all visual the inventiveness of 'The Ring'. Many have pondered over the films lack of scares, yet i don't believe it to be the films intent. It sets up some serious nauring tension that never gets released by a cheap scare, that is the beauty of this film. Watt seems more comfortable in role, bringing some superb maternal instincts to her character Rachel. Dorfman also shines as Rachels son Aiden providing us with a confused and sometimes disturbing character. The Brilliance of The Ring Two is in it's quality performances, compelling plot and inventive eye candy. It is a rare, relentless Friday night thrill ride that demands the viewers intelligence.

review_title: Terrible sequel with NOTHING to offer....hopefully this is the end to the franchise
review_detailed_main:
The Ring Two is a bad movie all around. I just hate it when studios and writers try so hard to stretch a movie past it's limits, the result could only be a bad one, and it's no different here. In the original, the tape was getting around killing people, and it so happened that the girl's mystery had to be solved; she was in effect haunting everyone who watched the tape. So be it... it was tolerable, but I was able to accept it. An okay little horror flick. With 'The Ring Two' now, it's no longer about the tape getting out and killing people. The makers needed SOMETHING to do in the sequel, so they decide to nullify all of the events of the original; essentially saying, 'oops we should've closed the well in part one; see now she's free to come after us....here's our sequel!!'. No longer bound to the tape, now the ghost girl wants a human body to occupy....sounds familiar? It quickly falls into the clichés of movies like Gothika, The Grudge and about every other ghost movie, quickly making it just another run-of-the-mill horror movie. The plot has many too many holes in it, because they just abandon everything established in the original for the sake of saying they have a franchise. The result is simply shameful. A terrible sequel, hopefully this'll be the end of these movies; though I highly doubt it.

*1/2 out of **** stars.

review_title: A horrible sequel to such a great film!
Not as bad as people say it is.
review_detailed_main:
The first The Ring is the only movie I've ever seen that honestly scared me. The atmosphere and pacing are perfect, and I love that movie. The Ring 2 has the original Japanese director of Ringu. His work on Japanese films are not bad at all, but I think he felt that if he was in America he should take a simple plot and make it over-the-top.

The Ring 2 is nowhere near as good as the first one, but it doesn't deserve the negative reviews it gets. The Ring 2 was quite scary at a few moments and very little cheese.

It does have its cheesy points, but they're not as major as people want to think. 80% of the movie is well made, and at some points better than the original. Yes, they should have stayed with Gore instead of getting a new director. Yes, this director has no idea how to create the suspense or atmosphere, as well as got some laughable actors. BUT the story itself is still awesome.

The bit of surrealism in the end sold me. The story is still good. It's worth a rental, at least, if you liked the first movie. Just because it's disappointingly worse than the original doesn't mean it's not better than the lame clichés that seem to be synonyms for modern horror.

4/10

Everybody is disappointed...Me??NO of course..It's much great..I think it's better than first movie..Because in this film there are more attractions(Action),more beautiful story,good acting,visual effects and finally musics(I don't know it's really strange but i liked very much musics)..All minutes i shocked to new things..Samara was really scary,i was frightened so much. I can't understand why everybody is disappointed..Because of Japan Director..There are a lot of Hollywood Directors... It's EXCELLENT,I loved it!!!I'll be going for second..You must see this film!!Congratulations Naomi Watts and Hideo Nakata!This's good job! p.s:Sorry about my worst English..

review_title: DON'T BUY THE DVD!!! Save your time and money!!!

review_detailed_main: Assuming that the original Ring film had integrity, this sequel ruined it. The cast, aside from the lead actress, was dull. If you're going to make a horror film, then get rid of these Hollywood looking people and get some that will look authentic. Anyway, what also disturbed me was the overuse of CGI. There are CGI deer. What the crap? Can you not find real deer anymore? Are they extinct? If you're a fan of plot plants that actually don't lead to anything, then this film is for you. The story hardly made sense because of so much useless crap in it. Oh, and the film isn't even remotely scary except for the one or two cheap pop-out-at-you moments that rely on automatic reactions. The Ring was a decently creepy movie, but the Ring Two is nothing more than a poor attempt at raking in more money b/c of its predecessor's success. It almost ruins the credibility of the first film.

review_title: Skip this one and watch the First
review_detailed_main:
The Ring Two is the sequel to The Ring which was a remake of the Japanese hit, Ringu. The Ring Two is not a remake of Ringu's sequel. The Ring Two suffers from Sequel Syndrome. A well made first film that can no longer carry the story of the 1st.

The fact is, the movie appears to have no plot development until after the first 1/2 hour, and the plot that does begin to materialize is not that entertaining. This film seems to go with more chills and jumps than story.

Another problem with this film is that it's side characters do not get developed. You sit their not caring about any of the supporting characters. Key performances in the film were by Gary Cole who has a bit part as a real estate agent and the two young actors in the beginning of the film.

There is too much David Dorfman(Aiden)on the screen. After awhile, you find yourself rooting for the spirit to kill Aiden, the young kid because he is that damn annoying.

In my opinion, save your money and wait for a better film to come around or go out and buy the first film. Don't give this film money so they make a third.

review_title: A straight up desecration of the cinema format.
review_detailed_main:
While I wasn't a big fan of the original Ring (or its Japanese original, Ringu), I did find the entire concept interesting and fairly original for modern horror. It was freaky, moody and didn't have to rely on big special effects to progress the plot. Hell, the acting wasn't even that bad.

So, what does Dreamworks do since it did so well? Push a half-baked sequel into production, bring back most of the original cast, bring in some new faces, let the Japanese film director who started it all direct the film, and hope for the best.

What happens? One of the worst sequels in awhile to come out of Hollywood.

The film is not scary, the atmosphere is almost completely MIA, and there is CGI galore. And not just any CGI, but some of the worst CGI to come out of Hollywood since the early days of special effects. They had an excuse back then, they have no excuse whatsoever now.

The scene with the attacking deer has got to be one of the most fake, and worst choreographed scenes in recent memory. I cringed, and hoped for the best. It never came. The scene went on for awhile, and just made my mind feel the need to implode.

The actors all try their best with the material given, even though most of the supporting cast is on and off the screen in less than 15 minutes.

And the Unrated footage just makes the film drag on longer than it needs to, and makes for consistent "What went wrong?" questions to be asked throughout.

The film's basic idea and how it is carried out is something different in itself, and makes the movie potentially watchable to teenagers and fans of the original, but the film is more or less, a could-have-been, but never-was.

3/10.

review_title: Poorly executed but "The Ring Two" is still visually haunting

review_detailed_main:
The Ring Two was really a great film.I think it was more exciting then the first one.But that one was scarier.

review_title: Funniest movie since the last ring!
review_detailed_main: I saw the first Ring and I thought it was okay until she climbed out of the TV. Then I thought it was pathetic. But anyway when I saw the Ring Two I had such a hard time trying to keep myself from laughing. It was so funny! When the deer were attacking the car I was falling on the ground. What happened to the horses? This time it is deer? And I think they were reusing sets! All the time I was like I think I have seen this room before. Oh yeah it was the Morgans living room! Some parts I was falling asleep. **This is a big spoiler so if you are going to see the movie do not read the next lines!** My favorite part will be when Racheal is climbing out of the well. In the theater you could hear everyone saying don't do that you f*** a** Then Saumaura says Mommy. Then Rachael say, "I'm not your f**** mommy." At that point I laughed and started clapping. Soon the whole theater joined in. I think Saumaura is not scary. Her voice made me laugh. Her appearance made me laugh. And also how do the people know that when she kills you you see the ring? BEcause all the people who have seen it are dead. But I guess that is Hollywood. This movie is like the exorcist but not as funny.

review_title: As much as I loved The Ring, I can't convince myself that this was a good horror movie by any means.
review_detailed_main:
If you liked The Ring, you most certainly will HATE this movie. Essentially, this movie actually has nothing new or fresh in it. We've seen it all before. When I heard that the director of Ringu was behind it, I was surprised and overly optimistic, but alas, it still blew. From the overuse of water to the random animal attacks, this movie is both disappointing and boring. It even recycles EXACT images from The Ring, such as the well and the falling off a cliff bit. That being said, this movie has SOME good things about it.

For one, Naiomi Watts looks gorgeous and she plays her part well. The little kid as also kinda creepy and Sissy Spacek has a wonderful cameo. Also, some of the images are trippy and cool. Best of all is Rachel's quote of 'I'm not your ****ing mommy!". This movie was actually a better movie on child abuse than it was about horror.

Overall, this movie was extremely disappointing and crappy follow-up to The Ring, which remains to this day the only film that has genuinely scared me.

review_title: My eyes hurt from rolling! Less is More!
Very good sequel to the ring. Possibly even better than the first one!
review_detailed_main:
The first ring is a lot scarier then the second ring. The reason why is because it is a lot darker and you don't really understand what was going on. The second one you know perfectly well what is going on. Some get confused by it, but I didn't. It is important that you see the 1st ring first though, or you will have a hard time getting it.

Just because the second ring isn't as scary doesn't mean it doesn't have scary parts. I loved this movie either more than the first ring or equal to th first ring. A must see in theaters.

Samarra doesn't seem as bad in this one, well she is, but I guess you get to see her loving side since she wants Racheal to be her mommy. taking over Aidans body in the process. Samarra kills anyone that gets in her way. You have to see this movie! I better quite typing so I don't blurt out the end.

review_title: Mix one part carbon-copy and four parts straight-to-video..
review_detailed_main:
..and you get this bizarre snorefest of a film.

Whilst I was a fan of the original Ring and thought that it did justice to the original Ringu, this seems like a quick cash-grab with a slapdash script. I can only boggle at the millions spent on creating it and the millions raked in from it.

The opening part of the movie simply repeats what we've seen before in Ring/Ringu. Then we get a couple of completely uninteresting 'scares'. For the rest of the film, we have a 'don't touch my BAYBEE' scenario which could've been pulled out of any made for TV horror movie.

Whilst I cannot bring myself to hate the movie, I can't dredge up any kind of feeling for it whatsoever. I returned it to the video shop sound in the knowledge that I'd never sit through it again.

4 out of 10 - the highest of my 'will never watch again' scores because of a few decent effects and some nice atmosphere. A real shame that atmosphere wasn't connected to a decent film.

Next time, at least TRY to write a film rather than cobble together a few odds and sods?

This sequel fulfilled my expectations because the story is developed with new ideas and there were many scary moments. The soundtrack was good and the picture had high quality. What I didn't like therefore was the performance of the little boy. I think he acted too passive and showed not enough emotional profile. Naomi Watts also didn't convince me as the mother of the little boy and I expected more from her. Then, as I am father of a little son I cannot add this one to my best-of-DVD-collection because it contains too many violent scenes. I simply don't want this horror movie gets in touch with my son. Final rating: 5,5/10.

If you liked it don't miss the first one. It works not only as a horror but also as a psycho-thriller movie.

review_title: Ring Around the Deer, Learn How to Steer
review_detailed_main: There are inevitable disappointing drawbacks to this sequel, taking place only a few months after the first Ring(02), tho the kid is obviously quite older. A level of dread is there from the very beginning but it never escalates. It sort of stays at the same beat throughout: Watts, back as Rachel, doesn't go on a journey of discovery here, uncovering further layers of horror. She already knows all about the tape and so do we. Yes, she does uncover further information about Samara, that now-tiresome spirit which doesn't go away and leave her and her son alone, but it's cliché. And then, midway, the only truly surprising sequence involves a sudden switch to the 'eco-terror' movies of the seventies, this time with killer deer. Say what? It's more hysterical than terrifying: the computer FX here don't work very well in sections of the sequence, as if rushed. And deer are the last animals I would pick to be scary; maybe that was the intent (the least expected animals) but it doesn't work for me. It was a central set piece and removing it probably wasn't an option. The rest of the pic, involving a form of possession, isn't anything new to horror and is even tedious. What's weird is after a saw this sequel, it suddenly occurred to me that the 'ring' may also refer to the phone ringing; but that may be because I watched the first Ring again.

I don't know what brought me to watch this movie, indeed if I know that Ring 2 will be that mediocre I rather stayed at home.

I agree to one of the users comment which declare his/her bizarre experience rather than scary one while watching this movie. From the beginning until the end, I can't really see the worthy plot as I'm expecting as a sequel from the first ring. Well, sure the big thing is that Aidan is being "haunted" by Samara. But, well... I can't see the point inside it. Maybe the plot is OK, but the accumulation of problem, conflicts and gory scenes is very unsatisfactory.

While the the first Ring able to scares your pants off, you won't probably in the second Ring. The gory scenes start to looks like other mediocre horror film that is so vague and cliché. The computer effects... well I can't tell more.. is devastatingly so futuristic that doesn't match to the "ring world".

I tought the ring is the only movie that has both concrete stories and worthy scary scenes, but I prove myself wrong.

Sorry.!!! 5 out of 10 !

review_title: Not Good - But Not All Bad
i loved it! more fun than the first one.
review_detailed_main: i don't know why everyone is dismissing the ring two. i thought it was excellent. strong performances, a plot line that left off perfectly from the ring and no disappointments with the suspense or the thrills. we're giving insight into Samara's background and meet her mother played flawlessly by sissy spaceck. Rachael is smarter, more instinctive, and willing to face down Samara with no fear or reservation. something that was lacking in her character in the ring. please do not listen to the negative posts. go see the movie with an open mind. i did not feel let down by this sequel as i have with others. the ring two delivers the answers we did not get in the first film, plays out under less confusing circumstances, and gives a much more satisfying climax than the ring. i am not one to be easy on sequels as the majority of them don't give justice to the film its continued from. rocky 2, Rambo 2, Friday the 13 part whatever, the lethal weapon sequels, and Hannibal one of the worst sequels ever made. the ring two delivers. end point.

Once every few years, when a figurative blue moon rises, a good horror film will come along and delight those brave enough to watch it. The Ring, an original, extremely well made film that terrified moviegoers in 2002 easily falls into this category as one of the best "scary" movies to hit the big screen since the turn of the century. Heck, it was so influential with its slick imagery and high-grossing box office results that it even spawned literally half a dozen "Japanese remakes" since its release (including such films as The Grudge, and Dark Water).

Unfortunately, because of The Ring's success, it was only a matter of time before Hollywood got greedy and pushed for a sequel to be fast-tracked into production. And even more unfortunately (mainly for audiences out there), yet not surprisingly, The Ring Two is nothing more than the "cliché sequel." It's redundant, it's boring, and only with the exception of the acting and directing, it's nothing more than a passable experience. The movie's tagline is "Fear comes full circle," but, in the end, it felt to me like the only things coming "full circle" were the films plot points and "shockers," as they were all used over, and over, and over again in a never ending circle, or, with a pun, a never ending ring of clichés and events.

"Why is this?" and unsuspecting fan of the first film may ask. Well, to answer that question, we can just look at the first film itself. It becomes obvious that the sequel, although dropping the whole "tape" idea very early on, follows almost the exact same sequence of events as it's predecessor. In short, both films follow Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts), a curious journalist, as she tries to figure out the story behind a young girl, Samara, who was murdered years ago by her mother. She goes about doing this, in both movies, by traveling to specific locales throughout Oregon and Washington, such as Samara's old home, a decrepit mental institution, and an all-too-familiar well.

The only difference between The Ring Two and its superior prequel is that in this film, Samara not only tries to kill former "tape watchers," but also tries to possess Rachel's son, Aiden (David Dorfman). As a result, he evolves from an already eerily mature boy into an extremely creepy boy. This character change, and this plot point should become the core of the movie, but, in reality, really only becomes a device to allow Rachel to go on her monotonous investigation. What results, to put it simply, is a boring take on a screenplay we've all seen way too many times before.

However, as terrible as the screenplay ends up being, the film does have its high points (they're just not very high). First of all, the acting in the film, especially that of Naomi Watts, is fantastic. Furthermore, the casting of new characters, such as Samara's birthmother (Sissy Spacek) is dead on (after all, having the one and only "carrie" play a deranged, institutionalized wacko is bloody brilliant). Also, the return of Hideo Nakata (who directed the original Japanese version of The Ring, called Ringu) adds a less colorful, and more suiting tone for the movie to follow.

Overall, although the return of Hideo Nakata, and above-par acting do benefit The Ring Two in many ways, they can't benefit it enough to save it from a dull, quite repetitive screenplay that drags the entire film into "sequel damnation." Unless you're a die-hard fan of the first film (and you like feeling disappointment), you should just wait for this movie to hit your local Blockbuster or Hollywood video. $9.50 is just too much money for something you've certainly seen before.

Rating = 2/5

I did see this movie a few years ago and not seen it since, i think i enjoyed it back then.

Now that I seen it again and found this movie to be very boring and dull from start to end.

This movie was not scary or creepy at all, no were near a good as the first movie or the Ringu 2 (That was just about decent it self). i am aware it not a remake of Ringu 2.

review_title: This story has run completely dry
review_detailed_main:
Something must be seriously wrong with the way filmmakers view the American audience when they decide to adapt such films. Or, maybe, there was never too much to it. However inferior the first film was to its Japanese predecessor, it was still worlds ahead of part 2.

The only two minutes that sparked remote interest in me were during the "creature action" by the very end. Nothing new, however.

Another note - I seem to have discovered the key to unsuccessful film-making! All the horror flicks of this year so far have been excessively dark (literally). None of them impressive. I suspect that if I see another one that has more than 5 minutes of consecutive darkness I might as well just walk out - nothing to see there! Take my advice, go see "The Pacifier" or something.

I thought The Ring (1) was fantastic! I haven't been that scared since watching The Blair Witch Project, so when I missed The Ring Two in the cinema I felt cheated by something great. When I finally got it on DVD I was well excited, but it didn't take very long for me to get really disappointed.

I mean, there are worse films than this one, but it wasn't as scary cause it didn't have the same element of surprise as the first one (obviously) and the script isn't quite as good either. The special effects are more prominent this time, but that should never be a carrying element in a film.

Naomi Watts is both beautiful and believable, but the focus on Aiden is a bit too much and reminds us too much of the great 'The Sixth Sense'. I'm sure we can expect a The Ring 3 and I hope they improve on their poor efforts in the second instalment.

This is the best scary movie that I have ever seen. This movie was much better than the first. I can't recommend it more than I already have. (I think I might go and see it again). The Ring was my all time favorite scary movie and The Ring 2 has now taken over the number 1 spot. I don't want to give anything away but how long has it been since a scene ended and the entire movie theater started to clap? You just don't see that anymore. With all the hype that the first one got, it's good to see a sequel that can live up to the attention that the first one received. If you don't believe me, pay the money and see it for yourself.

Let's face it, the critics were right. This film is NOT scarier than the first one. During the first Ring film, I was curled up in my cinema seat hiding behind my hands. I then bought the Japanese Trilogy because I enjoyed it that much (I enjoy being scared at films, call me crazy!). So I watched this film with high expectations. The (American)Ring was an exact replica of the Japanese version and it worked, hardly anyone in the western world had seen something so freaky. With Ring 2, they deviated from the series and turned it into an American teeny-bopper movie that no one under the age of 14 will find scary. This film is badly written with so inconsistencies. For example, Sissy Specek's infant told her to drown her to save her. And Aidan told Rachael to kill him to save him. Therefore, surely the spirit that possesses Aidan is not Samara if the infant said to do the same thing? Don't get me wrong, this film has some good points. ****SPOILER**** I love the way Samara crawls up the well at the end, with arms and legs all over the place. It was excellent visual work. As was the dead, green faces (excellent spec FX) and not forgetting the reindeer. But on the whole. This film is BAD (as in NOT GOOD). Anyone who's scared when Samara comes out of the TV screen after watching it so many times, will probably find this film scary. And, I just have to say, that line at the end "I'm not your ******* Mommy!" just cements its "cheesiness". Unfortunately, this is just another one of those movies that looks better in the trailer. Very disappointing!

B.L.

And I'm glad i'm not her mommy either, because i would have to spank her after i saw this awful film. Not only was there no need to make a sequel but there was also no need for there to even be one. It had barely anything to do with the tape in this one. It wasn't scary, fun, funny or anything. Only two people die. I could have wrote a better one.
