review_title: Wow.. As bad as it gets.

review_detailed_main:
This movie was completely retarded with the weakest plot I have ever seen since "Tough Guys." What exactly was the point of anything in this? How can Samara now fly around and pull people into televisions? Why is she showing up and harassing the pair? They already did their part and watched her weak-ass VHS indie flick and made copys, what else do they need to do? Plus, Samara somehow comes out of the videotape when Naomi burns it and gets inside the TV? I thought she would only make an appearance if someone actually watched the tape?? That being said, you could assume that the tape in the 2nd Ring has now become pointless and Samara will just simply become any old normal ghost that haunts people. Wow, good job sticking to the catch of the story...this movie was a waste of time and effort.

I really wonder why the hell Naomi and whatever the hell that kid's name is even decided to do this movie? Did they read the script, with the f'n stupid mad-deer-disease scene and all, and then say "Yeah, sounds good, I think it will do well." How much were they paid for this? Must've been a lot. Not like I really had an high expectations for this in the first place, thank god I did not see this in the theater.

review_title: The Ring Two Is The Best Sequel Ever!
review_detailed_main: I absolutely loved this movie! I saw it yesterday with a bunch of friends and we had the best time. The movie starts off where The Ring left off unlike other movies. It basically begins when a teenager knows that his time is up and the only way to live is to show the movie to another friend. He picks a lonely girl to watch it who is expecting a little more then a scary movie. He thinks that his plan is successful when he gets the girls to watch it but thinks twice when hes sees water leaking under his kitchen door. The beginning of the movie is great so you don't HAVE to see the first ring to even get the second one. Samara is creepier then ever and adding a few extra characters (Samara's mom, Evelen, and a new co worker friend)helps the movie out a lot. This movie is worth the 8 dollars I paid for it on Friday night and I think everyone else will agree!

review_title: the sequels rarely are as good or anywhere near
review_detailed_main: Kids ruin a lot of horror movies. This kid was too old for you to be concerned for his safety but also too young to be a decent actor. Aside from that the film lacks mystery. As in we get it. This already happened. This is a horror film that shouldn't be high on your need-to-see list.

review_title: It has no possible comparison with the first film.
review_detailed_main:
This film tells how a young journalist, a single mother of a gifted child is affected by the story of Samara and the video tape that kills those who see it in seven days. Directed by Hideo Nakata, the film is the sequel to "The Ring", has a Ehren Kruger script and Naomi Watts in the lead role.

We are facing a sequel to one of the most popular thrillers in the recent years. Despite that, this film is far from expectations. I believe that the change of director (Nakata is the producer of Japanese film in which "The Ring" was initially inspired) has been a key factor for this failure. The film does not bring almost anything new, except to give Samara a more fierce and cruel aspect of what was in the original, with its huge hair remember me "The Grudge". But the truth is that the film intrigues more than scares, leaves the audience more curious than uncomfortable.

The actors were at a good level. Naomi Watts is an experienced actress and was perfectly capable of handling her role. David Dorfman continues to do a great job as Aidan, and how the young man handed the role is a lesson for many child actors aspiring to a career in the seventh art. Visually appealing, the film has a deliberately dark picture, away from light and warm colors. The sun rarely appears, the fog and rain are almost a constant. Everything contributes to thicken the atmosphere. The soundtrack, created by Hans Zimmer, contributes decisively to the public's rare moments of discomfort. The problem of the film is, decidedly, the script and the absence of a director who understands the aspirations of a public hungry for emotions. The film does not have emotions, never heats or cools. Worse, there are certain elements of the story that almost collide against the original film, cutting its logical connection, necessary for the understanding of the story.

Well directed from a micro view with a few interesting moments, but poorly written, poorly constructed and generally ineffective sequel that by and large does not scare other than with the continual threat of death by boredom. Its actually two spliced together 1 hour shorts, the first is your traditional Friday the 13th Part XXIII type blop shown merely as tedious continuation, paint by numbers rehash of the first film, with virtually none of the first's ability to frighten. Naomi and her inscrutable Yoda of a son are on the lam from Samara, seeking a 'new life'. They stumble across (far too often) Part I type frights and happenings, one more ineffective the next, all in the supposed name of story development. The set-ups are so uninteresting and pointless that at one point I honestly almost turned it off to see what they were selling on QVC.

The second part of the film, admittedly has it merits as it turns, rather abruptly, from fun-house fright gags to more of a mystery/solution driven tale. We finally move forward instead of sideways and we begin to get some answers, albeit of the unconvincing and not particularly sound variety. As an example, sending Naomi once again to visit the Morgan horse farm and having her somehow stumble upon some vital new clues, is textbook inanity. Gary Cole I don't know why he would even take a role like this, Sissy Spacek as always is good, and really reaches back for a Carrie inspired tour de force if you can believe it. But its bad, with virtually no flow or even rational sense of continuity or mapping. The special effects are weak and unconvincing, especially the elk scene. The Hollywood ending, implausible and insulting. The main trouble of course is that Ring 2 is a horror movie...that doesn't scare you. And, if its possible, actually exorcised some of the lingering horror induced by the original. I would therefore seriously advise caution in watching this, its just not worth it for so many reasons.

review_title: Bloopers, and the funnest part of the whole movie!!

review_detailed_main:
First, decide why you're going to see this movie. If you saw the original "The Ring", you'll know that it's a thriller along the lines of the 1980 classic "The Changeling" - a whodunnit mystery to be solved in between screams. I went to see "The Ring Two" because I wanted to be scared - that's all I came for.

I was not disappointed. While the plot of this one isn't as strong as the plot of the first, it is still satisfying in that it resolves some questions left from the first. There are more creeps and scares in the sequel in the original, and, unbelievably, they are able to up the intensity to spine-tingling effect! If you like scary movies, give "The Ring Two" a try. Just make sure you see "The Ring" first, because they don't give you a summary to set the stage for what happens in the sequel. Remembering it while writing this review is giving me goosebumps even now, three weeks later! Enjoy!

review_title: This is why they shouldn't do sequels....

review_detailed_main:
"The Ring 2" is a horror film that gets so bogged down in the minutiae of its storytelling that it simply forgets to be scary. Naomi Watts and David Dreckman return as the mother and son who have recently fled to a remote section of Oregon in an attempt to escape the murderous clutches of Samara, the ghost of a young girl whom they encountered in the previous film. However, like any specter worth her salt, Samara has managed to track the pair down and quickly begins her scheme of possessing the boy as a way of returning to the land of the living.

This is an extraordinarily under-whelming thriller that is little more than a series of extremely mild shocks (if you even want to call them that) interrupted by long stretches of hopelessly dull exposition. The story itself makes very little sense, and the climax is so blasé and half-hearted that I couldn't be sure the movie had actually ended until the credits started rolling by. "The Ring 2" has a few impressive special effects up its sleeve, but not nearly enough to relieve the tedium that afflicts so much of the movie.

In a mere two installments, this series seems already to have run its course. If this "Ring" comes a-callin, don't answer!

I went to see Ring 2 just pro form, not expecting much from it. Even the first one wasn't that good IMO as it was a significant start of the pest called "let's make some money by remaking every single Asian horror movie we can get the rights to". The sole up side of Ring 2 would be a producers' decision not to go for another remake but instead the original script. However, that script proves to be weak, contrived and full of inconsistencies which makes it a tedious no-brainer. Naomi Watts and the kid are good but it's not nearly enough for a decent motion picture. The only ones who are really gonna love this film are teenagers whose mere purpose of going to the theater is to speak on their cell phones while "watching" a film and start a "i-can-scream-louder-than-you" competition. The Pg 13 rating tells you who they aimed it at. The Ring 2 is a huge step back for Hideo Nakata who lost a lot of my respect, specifically after I noticed he's behind a remake of "The Eye" as well ( that I know will suck big time ). Looks like Mr Nakata couldn't resist the $$$$$ call either..what a shame. If you want to see a real scary and well done horror with ghosts than try finding "Shutter" from Thailand and pray the vultures from Hollywood are not gonna ruin it with their lame remake.

"The Ring" was an eerie ghost story that centered around Samara, a girl not-quite-dead that is able to attack her victims via a videotape. What really beefed it up to make it such an interesting and delightfully scary movie was the great style Gore Verbinski added to it. When "The Ring Two" was announced, with no Gore, I foresaw the sequel not living up to the original.

And it hasn't. But it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be. Very early on in the trailer for "Ring Two" I could see that the visual style had been removed from the sequel: there was an eerie blue-green that pervaded the original "Ring" and it worked so well. I was disappointed by the removal of it, but it was probably a directing choice by Hideo Nakata, director of "Ring Two." As you may or may not know, Nakata directed the original "Ringu" and it's Japanese successor. Many regard Verbinski's "The Ring," though, as the ultimate telling of a story that has been remade at least two or three times in different countries.

One thing that's carried over from "The Ring" to it's sequel is Han Zimmer's excellent horror underscore. I appreciate this because I thought the original's score fit extremely well.

Nakata's influence is definitely here, and you can see a lot of Asian horror characteristics here. From my experience with Asian horror (especially "The Eye"), I've noticed that Asian directors are less likely to hold back on computer generated imagery, even if it looks fake, to tell a story the way they want it told. I bring this up because there is a point in the movie in which computer generated deer come into play. While it is a very fascinating scene, it is also hard to swallow since the deer look very computerized.

The story in this movie is intriguing and expands the myths of the videotape and Samara's origins. If you liked that whole part of the original, you'll definitely want to see "Ring Two" at least once. Unfortunately, the dialog is pretty bad and this movie suffers a case of "let's review the original for the people who never saw it," where a whole scene is dedicated to Naomi Watts retelling the story. Scenes like this make me cringe. Another scene that was incredibly cheesy was when Naomi Watts attempts to destroy the videotape early on in the movie using a fire... did she forget how the "system" of it works or something? You can't just destroy the videotape. Of course, the movie goes on to show her that. The videotape, as it's burning in the fire lets out a screech with a "mouth" it kind of grows... what the hell was that about?

This movie is not scary, though. Don't see this if you want to be scared. You'll be disappointed. This movie can surprise you, though. It has a few of those "trick" shots where the movie will unexpectedly cut to a horrific image, but all that atmospheric greatness from the original is gone.

When I was leaving the theater, I felt that the movie had a great core to it. But it ended up just too uneven. I think the three most obvious flaws are it's pacing, it's dialog and some unnecessary or peculiar scenes. It could've been better. I hear they're making a prequel... I hope Gore Verbinski will return for that. Nothing against Nakata, but it was jarring that he made a continuation of Gore Verbinski's stylized movie using his own style.

review_title: the movie continues w/ the woman and her son moving.they experience more problems w/ the evil girl
review_detailed_main: This movie was very disappointing. I thought that The Ring was pretty good so I looked forward to the sequel. I went to go see it the day that it came out. I am sad to say that I am angry that I wasted my money. I wasn't scared at all. There where times when the movie was funny to the point that everyone was laughing. It was too fast paced. However, the whole time I was waiting for the movie to end. The ending really made me angry because you are left questioning about so many different things. Things happened in the movie that did not add up. I guess this movie would be good for teens and younger viewers because of it's rating. But as an avid movie goer, I can say that this movie is a waste of money and time. If Ring 3 comes out, I am not going.

review_title: Fantastic sequel to a fantastic movie!
review_detailed_main:
Let me say that this movie surprised me. I didn't go into the movie thinking too highly about it, because it was a sequel, but it was fantastic. We got to learn a LOT more about the storyline and the origins of what happened in the first tape.

PROS: The story is great with lots of interesting things happening. It also doesn't rely on shock scares, but on a creepy atmosphere for the ENTIRE movie. The movie nicely ties into the first and answers most of the questions that we still have. There are lots of scary scenes that make us wanna see more.

CONS: The movie does move at a slower pace than the first one, and the middle section of the movie may not be as satisfying as the first one. Also, the movie does have more of a drama feel which is nice mostly, but at some points can drag some scenes out.

Overall, its a fantastic movie!

review_title: "The Ring 2" goes to the well one time too many.

review_detailed_main:
When the movie The Ring was released in 2002, it was regarded as one of the best horror movie in ages. Due to which we saw so many fan-boy websites and discussion boards sprung over to explore the minuscule details and theories of that movie.

And now after three years we see the sequel which shows how foolish the makers are to be able to spoil such a global franchise. The audience found themselves asking each other that whether it was the sequel of The Ring or Scary Movie 3. By the way there is no need for anything from the scary movie franchise for this one because The Ring Two makes fool of it and its loyal fan base.

The movie starts with the murder of a teenage boy by Samara in front of his girlfriend or no the girl was about to become a scapegoat for that boy as he was trying to show her the tape before his time is up which is only five minutes away but the girl is a nerd or smart, she puts on the tape and closes her eyes. And Rachel who now works for a paper in the very small town where that incident happened gets to know about it and when she sees the body of the boy she realizes that the curse is spreading and has reached too close for her comfort. So she steals the tape from the boy's house and burns it so that the curse thus not spread. But because of her doing that or some emotional need for a mother Samara possesses Aidan Rachel's son and the most disastrous sequel of the decade begins.

After the possession the movie takes a detour into evil spirit territory, which leaves the audience cracking themselves up over the movies proceeding. We see CGI deer's attacking Rachel's car, after this nadir one would expect the director could not go any lower. But we are wrong and we witness one cringe worthy sequence after another, which halts the movies proceeding during its first half. At the beginning of the second half the movie ups the tempo with the suspense about Samara's mother, but at each step the reasoning of the unfolding events shows clear disconnect to logic that put the final nail in the coffin for the most promising horror franchise of this decade.

This was an unexpected and disappointing shock for its fan base with the suspense leaving much to desire, the movie even fails to conjure a note worth scary moment. The makers try to lift the movie's sagging energy by putting Samara on steroids as moves and climb up the well with pace & extreme flexibility with hilarious effect.

Finally, if you are wondering why the herd of deer may have attacked Rachel's car then there is something you will find in the basement of the Morgan's; who were supposed to be horse breeders if I can recall!

For more reviews visit http://cinemadose.blogspot.com/
Ok. So it is not easy to make a scary movie. I thought this was better than the first movie. That is until the ending. I found it too drawn out. Maybe it was just a matter of taste.

i really liked this film, after reading all the reviews i thought it was going to be crap and a waste of money but i was surprised, it had a good storyline and the acting was good, i actually think this met up its standards to the first film, it was intense and creepy, with more scary bits than the first, the first you're working out what the mystery is and what happened to Samara, but in this one its just creepy all the way through, where Samara returns more determined than ever. she looks a lot more creepy in this one, in the first film she was made from special effects but they actually used make-up on this one to make her look more creepy. i don't know why everyone hates it and is bashing it, i thought it was a damn good movie, it had me on the edge of my seat and it gave me chills. i think this is a movie you should see!

review_title: Disappointing... No creepiness where it was in the first
review_detailed_main:
The movie "The Ring" was very tense, creepy, and brilliantly directed. Naomi Watts put her whole heart in her performance and Rachel Keller was more believable in the first. Now, Dreamworks has brought in the director of the original Ringu movies, and the style has been completely redone. It's obvious how much work the crew and actors put into this sequel, trying to make it creepier, more intense and terrifyingly weirder than the first supernatural thriller. But this movie fails shockingly and miserably on every category.

The Ring Two takes Rachel and her son Aidan to Oregon, recovering from escaping a horrible death after watching the scary cursed tape in Seattle and racing against time to discover Samara, who was drowned by her mother. I knew I was sorely disappointed by this movie when it opened with an attempted scare scene involving the tape like in the first, but just incredibly missing the creepy tone. Rachel hears about the death and connects it to the tape... then she is sent on another journey, uncovering secrets from Samara's past while her son is being possessed by her spirit.

The movie has amazing effects and apparent well planned cinematography. The camera-work here though is much different from the simple style that made the first scary. It's more in the fashion of the work done on "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre". And Naomi Watts is blatantly just reprising the role for her contract. There is no interest in her eyes... she isn't delivering the emotional role that made us care for her in the first. That's the problem- this dragged out movie that is as dragged out as this review, keeps pushing your attention away as it drones on and on about horrifying images and death.

The Ring Two is overshadowed by the first and is easy to miss. Samara comes out of the television a little too many times, and the movie has worn her creepy presence out. She should just stay in the well from now on.

review_title: It's a monster flick, don't try to read too much into it.
review_detailed_main: I have to admit....I didn't see "The Ring" until the night before I went to see "The Ring Two". This made everything about the original very clear in my mind. In order to prepare myself for both flicks, I read a lot of reviews about both movies. I was pleasantly surprised. I expected the sequel to be a downer, a complete disappointment lacking suspense and interest. I certainly did find some points repetitive and by the time Naomi's character, Rachel, finds the fifth or so person with the "scared to death" look on their face, I'm actually surprised she still screams and doesn't instead spew some profanity that she hasn't been able to stop Samaria yet again. All in all, this movie is not a bad sequel. If you read too many reviews and analyze it to death then you'll find the plot holes and the parts that don't make sense. (I'm still not sure what that whole deer scene was about). But if you approach it for what it is...a monster flick, (I mean come on, do you really believe someone could come out of your TV and kill you?!), well then it's a fun ride.

review_title: It's okay to view once or twice.
More meandering and cheap than the first *spoilers*
How has this not scored much higher?
review_detailed_main:
The Ring was a novel concept, with surprisingly more depth than many horrors or thrillers, which at the time(IMHO) only sought to provide gore and scare with little thought. The Ring 2 however, as corroborated by WindDancer 1971, provides a continual energy and uneasy theme which leaves you feeling rarely "safe". (I thought the original similar to Jaws, which was edgy on/around water but gave a rest when clearly away).

Not only this, but the style and back story are 100% improved (on an already good movie) to provide more depth and context.

I really don't like or generally enjoy horrors/scary movies, but this was just a great movie, that happened to have these thrilling/chilling elements in its core.

Strange because I've generally found IMDb scores to appreciate the more thoughtful movies, and to reflect such themes as I've seen them. I thought Cloverfield deserved a better score but this really was a surprise.

review_title: The Ring 2: How can something so right be so wrong..?
Tries to hard to be scary and... fails... big time
review_detailed_main:
I saw this with 10 other friends. We were all terrified in the first one. By the end of this movie we were laughing. It's pathetic. The Ring 2 tries hard not to be like the first and turns into just a silly sequel.

I saw Sissy Spacek was on the cast and thought it could actually be good but it turns out that she isn't scary unless she is covered in blood (Carrie). I thought that the special FX are okay such as the deer, the water from the bath tub. The point of a horror is not special FX. Many horrors can be scary with just sounds and scary images. Some say that there are scary/frightening images in the Ring 2, but i can't remember any! The faces of the dead bodies in the first gave me nightmares but in this one I was laughing out loud. Everything in this movie is predictable there are no twists to it which is one thing it could have used. I was also disappointed to not hear the phone ring and the voice: 7 days... because thats got to be my favorite part of the first one. If you were scared in the first movie you may not be scared in this one.

If you weren't scared in the first, this one will not be scaring ya either.

review_title: what in the heck was with the deer?!?

review_detailed_main:
hello i watched the ring two and i really loved it , being a big fan of the original i was impressed with no2 i think people are becoming a bit disappointed that there is not a scary part quite as good as ring 1 when Samara comes out the TV . but Samara still scared me , acting was great ,story was great ,

but i am a big fan of the ring films including the Japanese versions i actually preferred ringu two to ringu

the movie is interesting but only if your a fan of the ring and only if you have seen the ring 1

10/10

review_title: Add this suspense bunny to the Sequel Graveyard

review_detailed_main:
Production Values: Has a B movie look, not as good as the original.

Character Development: Not much, but what did you expect?

Character Appeal: Naomi Watts had a lot to do with the success of the first movie. She's not as appealing in Ring Two, but she is still the best thing about the movie.

Scariness: Mild, I don't think I heard a single scream in a crowded theater.

Gore: None, a couple of people are scared to death. That's it.

Special Effects: There are relatively few special effects and they are unimpressive.

Logic: The premise of first movie didn't make a whole lot of sense. After all, how can watching a video tape kill people? But the first Ring was really creepy and a lot of fun. Ring Two is even more illogical but has few redeeming qualities.

My Take: Despite being a big fan of the original movie, I can't say that I was expecting much from the sequel because the trailer looked terrible. Sometimes you get a bad trailer for a good movie, but not this time. Naomi Watts is fine, but she can't save the movie. The worst problem is that this "scary" movie is not scary at all. I would even go further; it's boring. The Grudge is the real successor to The Ring. The Ring Two pales in comparison.

review_title: Just doesn't live up to the first Ring movie

review_detailed_main:
Problem child Samara is back and up to no good again. After killing a teenager in a small Washington town, she, for some reason, decides to go after old enemy Watts and son Dorfman. Ring Two is nothing to do with the superior Japanese film, though original director Hideo Nakata replaces Gore Verbinski at the film's helm.

The Ring Two has its moments, but is shockingly uneven. The use of CGI doesn't fit with this type of film and some scenes are particularly laughable (watch out for the flying water). With a lack of real scares, Ring Two relies on horror at a psychological level, but is not inventive and most of the horror is re-hashed from either the first film or "The Exorcist".

The acting is generally of a good standard. Watts provides a solid, if slightly underplayed performance as Rachel. The brightest star if the film is youngster David Dorfman who is particularly good as Aidan. Elizabeth Perkins is, as usual, believable as the psychologist. Sissy Spacek is disappointingly mellow as Samara's mother, but is satisfactory.

The Ring Two is a poor attempt at a horror sequel which has lost all surprise and menace. If you have seen and enjoyed the American Ring film, then you may get something from this but I doubt it. If you are a fan of the Japanese originals, steer clear as you will be disappointed. This remake has none of the originality that made the Japanese sequels so fresh and is merely a poke at the teen-horror box office pie.

4/10 - Below Average

review_title: A horror movie?! More like a horrible movie...
review_detailed_main:
I saw the first one when it came out on DVD and I loved it! It was so good that when the second came out, I was expecting something just as good, if not better. Boy was I wrong...

"The Ring 2" carries on forever! Most of the scenes are completely irrelevant. There was not one single part in the movie that even came close to being even a little bit scary. Max, the little boy in the movie was just so annoying I couldn't stand it! However, I do think that Naomi Watts did a pretty good job.

OK so maybe it's not *quite* as bad as I'm making it seem...but if you are a huge fan of horror movies like I am, and you haven't already seen this movie, trust me...Don't! I made the huge mistake of not seeing it in theaters, and buying it when it came out on DVD. I thought it would be so good that I didn't even bother renting it. well, now I own it...and it just sits on my shelf collecting dust. I doubt I'll watch it again anytime soon. 3/10.

review_title: The Ring Two, gets a big "BOO!"
Don't bother with this one. Confusing waste of time.
review_detailed_main:
3/10

1. The Ring 1 was decent but this was a sequel slapped together just to make some bucks off the first good effort. Confusing, stupid, unbelievable, boring. 2. The ideas in Ring 1 were unique although somewhat contrived. This is a sequel without any new, original ideas so it becomes too incredible even for those of us with a good imagination. 3. The movie is not scary and is really boring through the middle. 4. I love a good horror movie and sometimes I think I could make better than this with $1000 and a camcorder. These awful sequels are a tremendous waste of money. 5. The only good thing about the movie is Naomi Watts, who is extremely fine, but not fine enough to save this train wreck.

I'm not sure why the distribution company made such a big fuss over this version being unrated..but I gotta tell you this is a fairly tame movie. Especially if you compare it to the first movie. There is no real gore, nudity, or violence.

The best thing about this movie is the Cameos and not much else. Elizabeth Perkins plays a shrink, Gary Cole has a minor role as a real estate agent, and Sissy Spacek plays Sarama's birth mother. Good cameos, but unfortunately, thats all they are. No character is developed in any way - not even the ghost.

I didn't think it was worth the money to spend - its slow and boring. I just wanted to see the history of Sarama, but the movie just breezes thru who she is and why she's haunting Naomi Watts' character Rachel.

Overall, this movie does not meet my expectation for scary / horror. It just doesn't have the fear factor in it of the original. However, if you get the DVD and watch the little mini-film called "Rings", you'll be scared half out of your mind!

I was sorry at not having seen the original "The Ring" in theaters, so I certainly didn't want to miss a chance at seeing Samara a second time on the big screen. As a sign of how the original has caught on, there were an abundance of teenagers in the theater, albeit few seemed to understand movie-theater etiquette. Anyone with any lick of sense knows that few can/will write a review of a sequel that applauds it as good as the original. With that said, I will do my best to describe the film knowing you already expect to be at somewhat disappointed.

"The Ring Two" picks up pretty much where the first left off. Rachel (still played by Naomi Watts) and Aidan (David Dorfman) decide to leave the big city for small-town life in order to get away from the terrors they experienced there. But it appears Samara is still in "circulation" when a copy of the horrific and lethal tape turns up in town and kills a teenager. Rachel discovers the body to be afflicted by the same frozen scream-like expression that acts as Samara's calling card. It is at this moment that Samara finds where Rachel and Aidan have moved to. But rather than continue to torment society with her morbid video-tape, Samara set her sights on a real life again through Aidan.

This film dances around trying to develop the complex and bizarre story of the original, but only offers small substance in its attempt. We still don't really understand why Aidan calls his mother Rachel. In fact, rather than offer an explanation, it tries to use that enigma to aid the plot. I thought the same thing this time around as I did during the first, "odd". As to the visual effects, suspense, and general mind job that was given in the first, expect less in "The Ring Two". There are a few good scenes that will make you jump, especially one involving CG deer. But even the deer scene leaves some unanswered questions, one of which is how does Volkwagen make such a strong car? And the ending is a bit of let down in how easy our heroes succeed. But did they really succeed...? Kudos to Naomi Watts and David Dorfman for a great job acting. 4/10 P.S.: Don't worry about sleeping with the lights off after this one.

The ring two is better than rings dont listen to the haters and the critics they didn't watch the new version of that movie. The old versions was not good but the new version was very much better then theatrical version

So you won't be disappointed that much. I mean, does this movie even know what it aims for? Which genre it should be? Yes it is nice to see a horror movie once in awhile that tries to break conventions and tries to come up with new things. The key word being "tries" here and sadly that's all it does!

Because the horror element, doesn't come through here. What works in Japanese movies, doesn't necessarily translate into an American movie as wee see here. But even the original director can't make those things work! There are a few scenes here that make you cringe, but not enough to get you through the movie, that is best described with one word: Dull! If you like horror dramas, you might get a few (more) kicks out of the movie, then others, but other than that, stir away from this!

review_title: Boy, Was I Duped Last Night!
review_detailed_main:
I would like to be able to replace the word 'duped' with 'drunk,' because that would've been so much more enjoyable, but nooooooooooooo! (Channeling John Belushi here.) I had to go out and rent movies to play catch-up. So I got THE RING 2 along with HIDE AND SEEK, hoping that between the two of them, there was a really good scary movie in there somewhere.

Thanks to the producers of both flicks, I now have complete verification of the main thing that has been troubling me about movies these days.

It ISN'T just me. Movies really do suck now! The sequel to last year's horror hit has only two things going for it: a capable cast, and the cachet brought to the production by the fact that Hideo Nakata, the original director of the J-Horror versions that started it all has come on board. To his credit, Hideo knows creepy. Hideo knows water. Hideo knows his way around a great method of blocking scenes.

Hideo by this time, however, probably wishes he'd never met Ehren Kruger, and I (and the many people who lost two bits and two hours on this piece of crap), would wholeheartedly agree.

Naomi Watts is back as Rachel Keller, who, blahblahblah...why bother? You've probably already read this a trillion times throughout the last few reviews you read before this one.

A sign of laziness on my part, friends? Or is that just how disgusted I was with the whole deal? Let me put it to you this way...halfway through, I found myself idly wishing that Samara would come through my TV set, strangle me and put me out of my misery, so I wouldn't have to watch the rest of it! That's how bad it was.

Wanna save yourself from my cruel fate? Go rent MONSTER-IN-LAW. Yes, I did just advise you to rent a Jennifer Lopez movie. At least if the acting is horrible, you get unintentional laughs along with it. The only one laughing here, folks, are the people who will have your money after you spend it on this, and can't get a refund.

review_title: Actually it was better than the first one... One of the bests!
review_detailed_main: I watched the first one and it was okay. Then saw the rates for this one here, I started watching Two with really low expectations. I'm quite surprised. I don't know why it is so low in rate but it was more scary than the 1st one! More intense. Better scenario, better use of music. Better in general. IMO, it is one of the best horrors!

review_title: A step down from the original horror
"Ring 2 Got Run Over By a Reindeer...."
Not my kind of horror movie... not my kind of movie period!

review_detailed_main:
It's impossible these days to talk about horror films without mentioning other horror films, particularly the recent rash of the obnoxiously-labeled "J-horror" films. Remake fever and sequelitis have condemned beautifully-crafted Japanese films The Grudge, the original Ring and the upcoming Dark Water, all of which have a serious pedigree that go back several decades, to the dreaded Hollywood revamp. Fifty years of films like masterpieces like Onibaba and Kwaidan - it's not something you can tart up with a fresh coat of paint and the actors from Scooby-Doo.

Then again, even Japanese horror has its stinkers. Ring 2 (Japanese version), the second and weakest of a three-film franchise, was like a Nightmare On Elm St sequel - silly, noisy and ultimately pointless. Hollywood Ring screenwriter Ehren Kruger thankfully jettisoned Ringu 2's rehash and mishmash and came up with some original ideas for the follow-up. Well, original for Hollywood. Hopefully attempts to turn The Ring's ghost-child Samara into a Freddy Krueger for the SMS Generation will fall flat, and Tinseltown can move on from its J-centric obsession.

Naomi Watts returns as Rachel Keller, as does David Dorfman as her creepy son Aidan. Now in secluded Astoria, Oregon, the curse of the video tape has followed them - in Ring 2's Scream-like opener a teen thrill-seeker is found with the familiar open-jawed look of abject terror. Rachel destroys the tape, but it appears Samara wants Aidan ("I see dead fishes") to be her host, and she's looking for a new Mommy. Aidan's soon freezing to the touch and has hand-shaped bruises on his back; even reindeer hate him. A sanitarium visit to Samara's biological mother Evelyn (a show-stopping performance from Carrie herself, Sissy Spacek, still in her Loretta Lynn fright wig) convinces Rachel that Samara wants back into the dating game, and David is her return ticket.

Even with the original Japanese director Hideo Nakata at the helm - a ploy used by The Grudge with depressingly similar results - these American remakes simply don't work. The Japanese versions are simultaneously silly and creepy; American ones are just plain silly. Japanese films have a tendency to downplay the drama to amplify their shocks, which American productions crudely attempt to ape. American actors thus appear to sleepwalk through their roles. The Grudge's casting trump card was a soporific Sarah Michelle Gellar; in Ring 2 it's The Guardian's heavy-lidded Simon Baker. An interesting casting choice, pitting two former Aussie soap stars against each other; Watts is certainly a long way from Summer Bay. I for one look forward to Harold Bishop's successful relocation to Hollywood.

Ring 2 has an interesting dynamic that Nakata has explored before in his film Dark Water, the child's disconnection from its parent (Aidan calls his mother Rachel, and authorities believe Rachel is beating her child). A much creepier film would have been Naomi Watts trying to destroy her son in order to save him - without the supernatural element. Call me sadistic, but I think it would work. Dark Water also features an orphaned ghost looking for a living mother, and Samara's staccato spider-walk up the well recalls The Grudge (itself an attempt to out-do Ringu, on which Nakata was technical adviser), as well as Linda Blair's restored upside-down stroll in The Exorcist: Director's Cut. All familiar elements which resonate with Nakata's Japanese work, but with less than spectacular results.

The film emerges from its slumber when Nakata goes to work hammer and tongs on two quite preposterous set-pieces. First, an entire herd of CGI reindeer hammer Rachel's car into scrap metal. Its meaning? Reindeer are sacred in Japan, says Nakata. Maybe they don't like working with child actors. Second is a bathtub sequence (the old J-horror standby) where the water forms a vortex around Aidan and floods the ceiling. It's both a triumph for special effects, and a vain attempt to breathe life into a drowned beast.

A final word to the Hollywood producers of the Oldboy remake: Judd Nelson in the title role. Think about it and give me a call.

review_title: A disappointing, boring sequel that is predictable and dull!
review_detailed_main:
I walked in to the Cinema with high hopes, even after reading bad reviews. I had the adverts in my head, and I thought it looked scary - boy was I wrong. When the film started, it had a promising-on-the-whole vibe, but then it just turned unrealistic. Some good acting from Naomi Watts, and even David Dorfman, surprisingly - but that's all there is to comment on... (good, anyway!) Jumpy in parts, but, they show most of them in the adverts. The only good part is the final couple of scenes, which is proceeded by the credits!

If you liked the first one, you will be VERY disappointed. If you didn't like the first one, you won't like this one...

* *

review_title: This Give The Bad Name To The Ring
review_detailed_main:
The Ring is one of the horror films I really like, but somehow I didn't like The Ring 2 that much. It didn't have the same feeling like the first installment.

Brief: 6th month after the incident, Rachel and her son move to the small town seeking for new beginning.

The Ring Two was more of the business reason that they making it. Cause I don't really see the resemblance between the two. It lost all of its charm and sophistication and turn to some thrilling spooky movie.

Maybe because of the change of the director and the writers that causes such a big change. The location is also dull and very uninteresting. And the worst of all, the things (story) in Rings Two don't really rhyme with the first movie. E.g.: if she left the lid open how could it be the called "Ring".

Recommendation: My Advice Is, Just Forget The Ring Two and Let It End Mysteriously Gracefully With The First Movie.

Rating: 5/10 (Grade: C-)

review_title: Not even close to the first one...
review_detailed_main: When "The Ring" came out a few years ago, it single-handedly dethroned every horror movie I had ever seen. It had a good story line, good acting, and very disturbing imagery. Not only did the movie make me jump, it was just creepy all together. I knew it would be difficult for the 2nd one to top this 1st. I was very very disappointed when I found out Gore Verbinski was not available to do the second one. I could not believe that the Ringu director would be doing this one. Japanese people make the WORST horror movies on the planet. This guy wasn't even the 2nd pick, they went to him as a last resort because nobody else was available. Their movies are very very cheesy, use horrible special effects that should have never been used in the first place, and use really lame tactics to try to scare people. The Grudge was a perfect example of this. American film makers make the best horror films on the planet. Gore took Ringu and completely turned it around. The first thing I noticed about The Ring 2 was the absence of the dark, gloomy Tim Burtonish atmosphere that Gore used in the first one. Every element in this movie was typical in Japanese style horror movies. Not a single scene made me jump or gave me the creeps. Samara was a total joke, she looked exactly like the girl from The Grudge, bright black hair streamed over the face with very fast and tacky movements. Certain imagery from the first one was used to strengthen this movie but it failed to match the first one. I also hated the way the story revolved around Aidan. That just made the story even more pathetic. From this day on I refuse to watch any horror movie made by a Japanese person in theaters. I'll just rent it. For those that loved the first one, this is not even close in my opinion. This to me is what Terminator 3 was to Terminator 2. My biggest complaints about this movie is bad scare tactics, weak story line,and excessive use of cheesy effects.

review_title: Excellent! just as good as the Japanese Ring films
review_detailed_main:
The American Ring Two made by Hideo Nakata of the original Ring and Ring 2 has brought yet again another chilling tale. I've seen so many horror films and all the ring films have given me goosebumps. In the Japanese films the girl in the well SADAKO/Samara scares the hell out of me.

I enjoyed the American ring but had high expectations of the new film by Jap legend Hideo Nakata. The special effects used are brilliant and have some weird, scary scenes.

The only critical part of the film is when Naomi Watts gets attacked by red deer's in the car. The deer's look really fake. Apart from that a brilliant horror film.

I had to watch this after Furnace to see Kelly Stables as the Evil Samara. Hideo Nakata (Ringu, Ringu 2) directed Naomi Watts (King Kong, 21 Grams) and Simon Baker ("The Guardian", The Devil Wears Prada) in this thriller as a mother tries to solve the riddle of what is possessing her baby.

Despite support from Sissy Spacek (Coal Miner's Daughter, Carrie) and Elizabeth Perkins ("Weeds"), it was largely unsatisfying and strange, but not scary at all.

And, the "Unrated" rating? There is nothing in the film that would cause a rating above PG. What a crock!

Fresh from seeing The Ring Two, I can say that I was disappointed. This time, the problem has very little to do with the spooky tape seen in the first installment. A lot of what it did have to do with seemed pretty random and just thrown in to scare you. That's all well and good for a horror flick, but if everything was tied in together to somehow make sense in coordination with the first film, this movie would have been better. It also would have helped if what did tie in with the first film didn't ruin what was initially creepy, for instance, the issue of Samara's parentage. A lot of the dialogue was odd or awkward, especially Rachel's bit of advice for Aidan in the beginning. There was very little gradual understanding; the characters just lay it out for you. I won't spoil the ending, but I personally didn't like it. The special effects were excellent, but I've always been more for plot that shiny visuals.

Overall, I won't say that The Ring Two was bad, but it didn't live up to its predecessor. I'd recommend seeing it at the matinée price, or just waiting to rent it.

review_title: Dull, yep you heard me right, dull.
review_detailed_main:
To escape the memories of Samara, Rachael and her son leave Seattle to start a new life in a small Oregon town, so she can more time with Aiden. Though, those plans are turned upside down when a mysterious death happens in the town and all the evidences turns to unmarked videotape that Rachael finds at the crime scene, but that's the least of her problems. She soon discovers that Samara is after her son and eventually possesses him. So now it's up to Rachael to find out a way to finally rid herself and Aidan from the curse of Samara that won't let them go.

What a disappointment! After being surprised by "The Ring" remake, which was atmospherically gripping, but "The Ring Two" was the exact opposite. Rather bland and uneventful comes to mind jeez, it was a snooze fest! One of the problems was the dire story and but also the lazy script, which took the cake. Even though writer Ethan Kruger (The Ring, Arlington Road) goes for a different approach than actually rehashing what happen in the first, which is great, but still nothing of any real interest happens and there were too many flat spots, nor do you really care for the characters, as they aren't fleshed out this time around. Instead of the cursed videotape it's more a throwback to the possession films that filled the 70's and there's even a sub-plot involving child abuse against Rachael, but really it just felt tired and contrived. The investigation that we watch Rachael go through isn't as intriguing like in the first film and that's because they try to over explain the curse. In that case it's hard to get creep out when you know too much and when they are trying to make you feel sorry for the spirit. This is why I enjoy the Japanese versions more, which they don't try over killing the back-story of the curse and that's what makes it more ominous. But the film's major sin was that it wasn't particularly frightening, or atmospheric. Sure there was some great imagery on show, but hey its got to have some unnerving touch to be effective, which it sorely lacked in my eyes. What made it even more disappointing was that Japanese director Hideo Nakata who took over the helm from Gore Verbinski, couldn't translate the blend of thrills and discomfort of his earlier and far better films "Ringu" and "Ringu 2" into this Hollywood sequel. Sure, he brings his own brand of direction and eye for detail to film, but still it far from entertaining. The acting was rather one note. Naomi Watts looks like she was going through the emotions. David Dorfman was incredibly annoying this time around. Simon Baker had a thankless role and Sissy Spacek had an amusing, but all to short cameo. No one really did any favours to help lurch this film from the bottom of the barrel. The overall production just felt rushed and incomplete, making it feel like it was made for only commercial reasons.

Again, all I can do is just express my disenchantment in this lacklustre effort.

Instead check out the DVD extras, which has a short film called "Rings" it's far creepier and fairly riveting in its execution. It also relates back to the opening sequence of "The Ring Two".

UN film quo yous Fiat detester Le cinema Apr's yous Avior Fiat Rover.
