review_title: Now I know why their faces look like that...
review_detailed_main: How can Dreamworks go from The Ring (a very creepy and unnerving film) to The Ring Two (a complete failure on every level) without even blinking? It's astounding how bad this movie is compared to the Japanese version or a matter of fact, any other Ring-related movie. Even though Naomi Watts and David Dorfman return from the original film, they end up trapped in a flick featuring a boring script and uninspired directing from Hideo Nakata, who should know better. After all, he himself directed Ringu 1 & 2. It's shocking how the quality has dropped in his translation to American horror movies. They couldn't even get the same girl back to play the evil Samara, so Kelly Stables has replaced Daveigh Chase as the villain of the film. That should be a sign that certain sequels just shouldn't be made. The first film stood alone as a great scary movie to watch alone or with friends on a dark Saturday night. This second movie in the series is so disappointing that it cheapens the effect of the first one just knowing that this one is around. You'd do better to check out the Japanese originals for the Ring and Ring 2 or just watch the American version of The Ring again. All three are much more entertaining than this piece of studio mediocrity. The Ring Two is not even worthy as a rental. It's boring, slow-paced, badly written and very uninspired even for a sequel. Move along, there's nothing to see here folks.

To me this was an excellent film, not a second serving of the first, and not something totally different. If you did not understand the first film, you will not understand this one. Also, avoid bringing along people who haven't seen the first one since it'll be confusing to them.

I would like to point out that David Dorfman hits a new level of child acting (in my humble opinion), he got under my skin the most out of every character in the film. Sissey Spacek is a very good actress, but seemed very limited in her small role. Watts also does an OK job (and it could be just me) but her acting was weak. Ah well, it's a good film anyways.

Well acted, directed, and written, but the CG effects just felt like they were too overdone, something which the original American Ring did a good job of avoiding. The beginning and ending, after looking back, aren't the best parts, but all I can say is that you won't waste your money seeing this film, if you saw the original.

review_title: A big disappointment for me personally.
review_detailed_main:
Well....the excitement i had for this film was very high, as most people who loved The Ring would probably have the same excitement as I did, and for those people will probably have the same amount of disappointment as i did.

The film was terrible from the beginning to end. There was many of pointless parts in the film that just didn't need to be there. All the way through the film was clues, but as you later realise the clues lead to you to nothing, and have no significance in the film.

All the way through the film I expected something to happen that would make this film as good as the first but as much as I hoped nothing happened.

For me this film was a great disappointment, but some might say it was good so I'm not going to say don't see, everyone has there opinion and you should see it for yourself and make your own mind up.

I give it a 6 because that's only what the movie deserves. For me, it's near an 8 or a 9.

The beauty of The Ring Two is that having been a fan of the Japanese franchise, and learning this would be a completely new film, I had no idea where they were going to take it. The trailers were very interesting but again, offered no clues as to where the film was going.

There's a reason for that.

You see, the filmmakers and I had something in common. I had no idea where they were going to go with this film, and neither did they. The film is a confused mess with barely a plot thread stringing it together, certainly a hallmark low for hack writer Ehren Kruger.

But that's the charm of it, I guess. It's so confused, and wants to show you all kinds of cool stuff, that the movie itself has been lost. It's no more a clone of the original film than of any of the other films in the Ring canon.

But it IS entertaining, and charmingly bereft of a real plot. On the one hand, it's disappointing - the concept of the original is rife with possibilities for a sequel - but on the other, it's sort of grand in its utter inability to capitalize on anything.

It's a curiosity of a film that should be seen, if anything, for its utter confusion.

I loved it.

review_title: maybe a thriller but not a horror film..
review_detailed_main:
after watching the first movie everyone has started to wait for best horror movie,the ring2.because of its original scenario and editing all of us couldn't avoid from the ring1's effects..but the second movie is completely isn't a horror film.maybe a thriller but absolutely not a horror film.

more cliché were used and Samara's face was shown much in the ring 2.i think hideo nakata made this film for just finish the story.instead of hideo nakata if gore verbinski direct this film we could watch better movie.because of these reasons the ring2 is a disappointing film for the ring fans..

review_title: "...not in quite some time has a horror sequel failed so miserably..."
review_detailed_main:
Not in quite some time has a horror sequel been so ambitious. Simultaneously, not in quite some time has a horror sequel failed so miserably, as to not only embarrass its cast and denounce its predecessor, but to sink to the depths of the plot-holed, empty-hearted abyss of horror disgraces currently occupied by "The Grudge" and "Boogeyman."

Unlike most of my peers, I was and still am a fan of "The Ring." I believe "Ring" sported one of the most original and effective televised marketing ploys ever. Before the previews, before the hype and before any word got out about the film, if you were to watch a television program after 11PM, and stuck around for the commercials, every now and then the television would fizz out after a couple commercials. Then the actual creepy videotape would play out in its entirety, followed by an additional fizz out, followed by the next commercial. You wouldn't know what you just watched, but you'd feel crept out. Extremely crept out. This type of originality and innovation fueled the hype of the original, and added to the trepidation of the videotape itself.

As far as originality goes in the sequel, the only innovative aspect was the connected story. In the first, Aidan (Dorfman) was Rachel's (Watts) ominous son whose sole purpose seemed to be warning Rachel about Samara (Stables). Like innumerable other horror films, he appeared to be the generic freak son who only spooks, but doesn't enhance nor progress. However, in the follow-up Aidan is clearly not only an important character, but also a mandatory one as Samara's entire motive revolves around the fact that he's Rachel's child.

Short of the ambitious attempt to create a film that answers the questions left behind in the first, "Ring 2" basically fails on every other conceivable level. Every scare is as obvious as the horrendously unappealing and insulting CGI. Early on, Rachel and Aidan are attacked by a mob of angry elk (Funny as that may sound) so conspicuously computerized, that it's very possible that they were the forgotten reject reindeer's of "Santa Clause 2."

Whereas in the original, a bustling city harbored the slow-paced terror of Samara, the second takes place in Suburbia, USA and ironically moves a lot faster, draining Samara of her initial dread. "Ring" set an atmosphere, mainly due to Gore Verbinski, which is absolutely omitted in the second. Samara just is not scary in Hideo Nakata's hands.

While the concept of Samara wanting to inhibit Aidan might sound creative (Which I think does), the actual way screenwriter Ehren Kruger went about it is ludicrous and laughable. What originally started as an "out-to-get-ya" horror series, ends up being a stupid "I-want-my-momma" dramady.

If the translucent story doesn't persuade one of a lack of resolutions, perhaps the fact that Samara is now telekinetic, can talk and possess, will. Without explanation, Samara can drag people into televisions, make others stab themselves in the neck with hypodermic needles and is only oblivious to what people are saying when they're asleep. Yet it strikes me as strange that an all-hearing, all-powerful ghost can still eat a peanut butter and jelly sandwich without noticing that it's packed to the brim with crushed sleeping pills.

"Ring 2" contains absolutely none of its predecessor's entrancement, and is hardly worth a single viewing even if "Ring" is amongst your favorite horror films. As opposed to the original's attempts to at least explain and foreshadow impractical events, the only foreshadowing here is Verbinski's disassociation. Completely depleted of scares, intelligible storytelling, and meaningful characters, the only thing that should "come full circle" is my nine bucks.

review_title: Boring, predictable, lacking in about everything that makes a good story.
Another example why sequels don't work out to well....
review_detailed_main:
A couple friends and I watched "The Ring" before we went to see "The Ring Two" but I can't believe how dull this movie became.

The movie continue's from the first one, but the movies loses so much suspense from the first one. For starters, it wasn't dark like the first one. Second, there were no scares that made me jump from my seat or in my mind. Third, the plot did not make sense and the worst of all it doesn't leave you guessing like the first one. It was very predictable and I think they should of gave this one a little more thought before they filmed it. The only thing that made this movie from really becoming ridiculous was the performance by Niomi Watts, she was the only thing that kept this movie from becoming really stupid.

To anybody who wants to see this movie, I suggest buying or renting something that better for your money than this.

Six months after Rachel Keller (Naomi Watts) and her son Aidan (David Dorfman) were terrorized by the mysterious video tape and its spiritual inhabitant Samara Morgan, they've moved to a new town where the terror begins anew when Rachel finds an unmarked videotape at the crime scene.

The plot doesn't particularly sound exciting considering it sounds exactly like the original. However, The Ring was a very good film so I had high hopes for the sequel. Maybe I should have lowered them a bit as this film isn't very good. It starts off promising before taking a turn for the worst. The first 30 minutes or so were pretty good. Then, the film starts focusing on the subplot of Samara trying to take over Aidan and that's when the film becomes dull.

The Ring 2 had some scares and had some moments of creativity. However, for the most part the film was nothing special and just not something you would expect from The Ring franchise. It could have been a good movie though. The atmosphere was right and most of the characters were back. The opening scene was also pretty good and the new characters were fairly interesting. However, there were a few moments in the film when I was thinking " why would you do that?" or "don't you remember what happened before, that wouldn't be a good idea" They seemed to have made the characters more stupid and they were acting like they would in a slasher film. That's something I would expect from that type of film but not from a more serious horror film.

The acting was pretty good all around. Naomi Watts gives a good performance as Rachel and I can't wait to see her in King Kong. David Dorfman is really good at playing a scary kid and gives an effective performance as Aidan. The supporting roles are also strong and they are played by Sissy Spacek and Elizabeth Perkins.

It would make sense for Hideo Nakatato to direct this film since he directed the Japanese version and all. However, Gore Verbinski is a pretty good director and he did a pretty good job with the original. So, I wouldn't have minded if he was directing. Many people are complaining that the deer scene ruined the film. I thought that it was pretty scary and unexpected. Sure, the deer may have looked really fake but that didn't ruin the scene too much. Besides for the actors, this film isn't really worth watching. It may make a decent rental but that's not a guarantee and if you do end up watching it then you should get the unrated version. In the end, The Ring 2 is a disappointing and dull sequel, approach with caution. Rating 5/10

review_title: Really good film, better than the first
review_detailed_main: Before I saw this film, my mind was telling me that I would probably be disappointed, as I usually am with sequels. But, after watching it my opinion has totally changed. The cast are brilliant and the storyline is EXCEPTIONALLY well linked to the first movie, with some of the ideas from the first movie, explained and uncovered in this sequel. The film is not so much a "scary" film, but more tense. However there are some very jumpy bits, and parts which are not for the faint hearted. Overall this is a brilliant film which I would highly recommend to any fans of "The Ring" Prequel - you will not be disappointed!! I just hope they don't make a third film, because it feels like they have taken the story far enough.

review_title: Cheap Addition to a once great Film
Not the same high standards like the first film.But none the less is was a solid horror flick

review_detailed_main: Complaining about this movie would be pointless. It is to be expected that the sequel to a good horror movie would be nowhere near as magnanimous as its predecessor. The Ring Two is no exception. What the sequel creates is a real stretch to what the original created, Many aspects of the film just reach too far for it to be completely enjoyable. The Ring is within my top five favorite horror flicks of all time, so a sequel is expected to fail. I found the only good aspect was the acting of the son. While watching I thought it was mediocre but I realized that everything he did was scripted and well executed. So if you see this movie with low expectations, you will most likely not regret it.

review_title: What a waste of a Saturday night
Better then any other horror movie to have come out...
review_detailed_main:
In the past five to ten years. At last a horror movie that had a story line. This adds more story to the first one and is just as good...no it's even better.

The Pros:

1) One great story line. It adds to the story. That's what a movie should do. 2) Good acting I believed the characters were who they were playing. Naomi Watts did a very good job in this movie. 3) Good Cinematography just like the first one. 4) No cheap scary scenes. If that's all you wanted then you don't know much about what makes a movie a movie.

Cons:

1) It ended.

review_title: It's not scary, but works more as a psychological thriller.....
review_detailed_main:
I think the main fact that this sequel isn't as scary or as thrilling as the first is because you already know Samara is an evil out of this world being which you slowly discovered in the first. That is what made the first one suspenseful and builds up to the climatic TV scene. However, in the second one, all you mainly get is some water scenes in a bathtub, possession of the young Aidan and some badly done CGI deer attacking their car.

This uses cheap thrills rather than playing on your mind, and really doesn't leave room for much imagination. However, I did find the whole mother son relationship quite interesting, though it seems to go down this whole path of child abuse and questionable parenting themes in the second half. Naomi Watts is once again, brilliant, but doesn't have much to work with here.

What I liked a lot about the first Ring was that it used great atmospheric cinematography to create the mood of gloominess, mystery and the feeling of leading to unpending doom. In this one, it doesn't use that as much, but it can be forgiven considering this movie is more about getting on with life instead of chasing the past the first one dealt with. Simon Baker's character could have been used more - they didn't go into the whole love interest thing, which can be refreshing for once, though I felt he wasn't really utilised well.

So it works on some levels, but on others it falls flat. Hideo Nakata who directed the original Ringu uses too much style I think and the water effects don't work well here. I think it's because well.....simply it doesn't seem scary and fits more with the Japanese culture and terror. For westerners, water is more like a problem of bad plumbing.

Also, what makes Asian horror films scary is that it doesn't rely on fast shots or fast story telling - it slowly builds it up and you go along with it slowly and then you discover the horrors on the way. That's where the first American Ring succeeded - in this one Samara feels more like a girl who got lost somewhere on the street and is out to find her Mum again - oooh very scary.

This is not a bad film, but it's not a great one. Don't expect to be jumping out of your seat, but if you enjoy psychological thrillers, this one will probably just satisfy you.

Well, After seeing the movie, there's still one thing I can't figure out. Which is more confusing, the fact that the movie un-winded the way that it did, or the fact that anyone on this planet could of found the movie totally scary?.. there both really quite mind boggling.

Truth be told, I think the Ring 2 could of been a lot worse though. They attempted to put more story behind it then a bunch of kids passing around a video tape and getting killed one by one in typical horror fashion. Although the story itself grew increasingly stupid and confusing right up towards the end, it played out a lot differently then I thought it would when i first seen that they were doing the sequel.

The acting was terrible, but I still don't believe that should be a factor in a horror movie, cmon we wanna be scarred and just like any horror movies as of late, the ring 2 just couldn't deliver. But if you saw the first one and enjoyed it, your best bet is probably to go rent this one when it comes out, its nothing worth rushing into your theater too see.

NOT SCARY! I think that what had made "ringu" scarier is that they've used a real person to play Samara and used little technology to do the special effects- it just looks realer!!! The fake Samara in the ring 2 is too unreal! The so-called scary moments(like when Rachel opens Max's car door and sees his face) are too predictable- I just knew everything that was going to happen- and not only from the trailer (who, by the way, revealed all the "scary" parts). More to it, I couldn't understand the connections between too many things- like, what's the deal with the deer? And Samara's mom? And why the hell Samara suddenly needs Rachel to be her mom? This film sucks!! The first one is so much better!!!

I hate being disappointed by sequels. I tell myself that sequels are usually bad and that I should expect mediocrity. Yet after the tantalizing preview for Ring 2 I had high hopes. Man I'm dumb. This movie is inconsistent with the original Ring and makes little sense in the scheme of the story. It provides very cheap thrills with long, drawn out dialogue and little suspense. I did enjoy one scene in the film that involves elaborate water CGI but that was hardly worth the price of a full admission. Sissey Spacek provides a cool cameo but what she says doesn't make a lot of sense. Then there is the child actor! He attempts to be 'Six Sense' creepy but just ends up being a bad kid actor. His scenes aren't scary, they're laughable. I suppose if you're a fan of the first 'Ring' you will feel obligated to see this movie. Don't be sucked in though - I'd say you can definitely wait for the DVD.

review_title: Exploitative sequel tries hard to scare, but relies on cheap tricks and lacks story
review_detailed_main:
The producers released The Ring 2 three years after the first film, perhaps because, at that time, film corporations didn't make films as an industrial production line. However, The Ring 2 seems like a cheap manufacturing product.

With the moderate hype of The Ring 4, I decided to rewatch the American franchise. I remembered the first film well, but the second not that much, perhaps because the second film in the franchise was considerably weak compared to the first? We shall see.

At this point, the franchise has clearly deviated from Koji Suzuki's book series, and overall, that kind of creative freedom is valid. I don't mind it at all.

The Ring 2 starts out hilariously and that's unacceptable. The opening scene succeeds in raising so many questions about how someone else got their hands on the cursed tape, increasing expectations, but the end of the scene is comical, the quality of the visual effects low, marked by the death of a 2005-emo-punk stereotype.

The plot holes in The Ring 2 are what destroy the film. Because of the opening scene, we know that the cursed tape has spread somehow. The ending of the first film makes it clear that Rachel and Aidan chose to save themselves, implying that they condemned someone. That's an important fact but buckle up: the film ignores that. The story in general does not gratifyingly explain facts, focusing only on the collection of unnecessary jumpscares.

Upon reaching the third act, we realize that not much happened. In general, Rachel is just drooling around the corners as the film introduces and removes subplots as quickly as Samara seems to gain inexplicable superpowers.

In the middle of it all, we have one of the candidates to the title of most useless side character in a story: Max. In Rachel and Aidan's arc, his function is just to exist. Removing Max from the story wouldn't alter any of the significant events, which, by the way, are minimal.

At the end of the day, The Ring 2 feels like just exploitation, a leech movie that tries to exploit the success of its predecessor. I recommend this movie only if you plan to watch all the movies in the franchise.

review_title: They should stop Ring American series after this one.
review_detailed_main:
More lurking Samara in a different style, i can't say i didn't enjoyed this movie, i love The Ring as for Japan and American versions, but i think they ruined the series with this one. The sound effects were awesome, the scene when Samara crawls up from the well was amazing too, there was just 1 scene from the bathtub that was really disappointing, like a very bad produced computer image of Samara, there was no real scare factor at all, the music was the same, they should have changed the music, it sounded the same and this was boring in my opinion. The storyline was one of the most awful to follow up, the acting was terrible, the scenery was awful too. But it was good enough for making me buy the DVD when it comes out. Anyway i hope they stop making more American Ring as i think the series are ruined. That's all for now.

Rating 6/10 derived from the following:

Storyline 2 Sound effects 8 Scare factor 6 Music 3 Scenery 5

...you can't really blame director Hideo Nakata for it. I think he has a very different style that simply does not resonate with the majority of American viewers, particularly those who are fans of Gore Verbinski's original American remake. That said, this was not a very good movie. There was no plot to speak of, the mystique of Samara was completely killed, the ending made no sense, and there was no real mood. Whereas in the original (American) movie Samara was simultaneously a pitiful little girl and a truly disturbing monster, in this movie she's simply annoying. And no offense to the girl who played Samara here, but she didn't really work for me. Characters came and went and were never spoken of again. The character Max served no real purpose. The same with Emily. Lapses in logic (such as Aidan and Rachel going to Rachel's office in the middle of the night only to find all her coworkers there as well, or Aidan simply trotting out of the hospital and no search mounted for him)insult the viewer's intelligence. The only scene that worked for me was the one where they are at the fair. Nakata does a nice job of portraying a scene of odd surrealistic unease. Other than that, this movie is a pretty poor effort.

review_title: The tape failed to kill me, but boredom succeced
review_detailed_main:
Oh god this movie.

I watched the original Ringu before the remake and i like it, i think it's great even though it didn't scare me at all. Then a few years later i watch the remake, i think it's not as great as the original, but i think the remake is scarier. After i watch the remake, i watch the sequel of the remake. My expectation were HUGEEEEEE, and... Yeah, boredom kills me. Okay, i'm not a film critic, so i don't know what makes this movie boring, but ONE reason it's suck is that Samara is on screen TOO MUCH, like TOO MUCH. Instead actually create suspenseful, creepy moment, this movie goes with jumpscare, jumpscare, and jumpscare. Samara appears every 8 minutes is an effing crime. Yes, there's cool scene like when the water rising from the bathub, and actually suspenseful scene like the well sequence in the climax, but there's also many, MANY generic scares. Like come on.

First, I have to say that I was a huge Ring 1 fan. I was overly excited about the 2nd movie. All three Ring movies were a hit in their native Asian country. Therefore, I was hoping that each were possibly as good as #1. Plus, the creator of The Ring was going to direct #2, this also made me hope that it might be another great sequel. As you can imagine, I was horribly disappointed. Ring 2 is looks more like a movie making fun of all the stupid things about Ring 1.

The main problem is that the movie isn't really about anything. In Ring 1 things were discovered, although many things remained ambiguous. The idea of having no idea what this creepy girl could do, or why she was doing it is what made one so great. Here, the people got smarter and now know exactly what she wants. Also, the main plot of one is completely abandoned. The whole "die after a week" thing is scrapped in favor of a stupid "water control" thing. Then there's the angry deer and the digital photos stuffnot creepy. Plus, not even one "she's coming out of the TV" shot. Just think if when they made the Indiana Jones sequels, the decided to not use anything that made the first one a hit. That's what this isa disastrous disappointment.

The Rng was such a hit, i loved it but this... failed to make the cut. Naomi Watts is such an amazing actress- and sure she was good in this one but the film and the rest of the cast was just pointless. Sissy Spacek is also another amazing actress, but her screen time was so short and her performance a little dull. The whole film was a bit effed up if you get what i mean. It was boring and that damn tape, the first installment was enough bu a second round and maybe a third???? There were too many dreams and nightmares that you couldn't work out if the film was serious or not. I would expect more from it, the first was amazing and enough, a second clearly wasn't needed and whats supposed to happen in the third???????

I just wanted to say that I think The Ring 2 is a wonderful movie. One of the things that make it so good is the cast. They are the ones who really make everything real and they just all do such a great job. I especially like David Dorfman (Aiden Keller) and Niomi Watts (Rachel Keller) they both did a great job and seeing as though David is only a kid- that makes it even better! Another thing I really enjoyed in the ring 2 was the whole story line. A lot of people said it was hard to follow/understand and that it really made no sense, well if you just pay a lot of attention and follow what there doing, its pretty understandable. Its a good movie and maybe its not like the first one, but its still good and I think it was totally worth seeing. GOOD JOB!

review_title: Is Max still in his truck?
review_detailed_main: I wasn't expecting it to be as good as the first and of course it wasn't There were some confusing parts. If Evelyn's baby was the evil Samara then why would she want her mother to kill her? Wouldn't she want to live and spread her evil everywhere? Also, why didn't anyone come after Aiden for killing the doctor? Finally, What happened to Max? did they just leave him out there in his truck? I think that the scene with the deer was ridiculous! what the hell were they thinking! hey, shouldn't they have used horses. It would have tied in better with the first movie. The creepiest scene by far was Samara chasing Rachel up the wall of the well. Yes, that is what I paid $10.- for.

In a curious twist, the American studio DreamWorks handed the reins of "The Ring Two" back to Hideo Nakata, the director of the original Japanese film. While this might seem like a logical choice, it's precisely where the film falters. Nakata, even in his native Japan, is a director of middling talent, and his sensibilities simply don't mesh with the American production.

Despite the valiant efforts of Naomi Watts, David Dorfman, Simon Baker, Elizabeth Perkins, and the legendary Sissy Spacek, the film succumbs to a downward spiral. The localization efforts of Ehren Kruger, layered upon the original screenplay by Kôji Suzuki (the author of the source material) and Hiroshi Takahashi, result in a narrative that feels disjointed and patched together.

Another misstep by the studio is the choice of cinematographer Gabriel Beristain, whose work on "Dolores Claiborne" (1995) was exceptional, but his experience is primarily in television. Beristain struggles to capture the atmospheric essence of "The Ring," attempting to elevate the visuals to another level but ultimately falling short.

The third film in the series is best left unmentioned, so I recommend this film only to those who, like me, will watch anything with Naomi Watts in it. Her performance is a bright spot in an otherwise underwhelming sequel. Watts brings a depth and emotional intensity to her role as Rachel Keller, the journalist haunted by Samara's curse. Her desperation to protect her son Aidan (David Dorfman) is palpable, and her interactions with the other characters are imbued with a sense of urgency and dread.

However, even Watts's talent can't salvage the film's convoluted plot and inconsistent tone. The scares are less effective, the pacing is uneven, and the overall impact is significantly diminished compared to the original American remake.

In conclusion, "The Ring Two" is a disappointing sequel that fails to capture the magic of its predecessor. Despite a talented cast and a promising premise, the film is ultimately undone by its misguided direction and a script that lacks the coherence and chilling atmosphere of the original.

And that's not an easy thing to say, as "The Ring" was an insult the the Japanese "Ringu".

This one manages to get everything wrong.

Pure snoozefest with cheap CGI, idiotic plot, bad acting, a somewhat of an uninspired pseudo-artistic photography.

When I first saw this movie in the theaters I enjoyed it a lot but thought it was definitely worse than The Ring 1. On the 2nd time around, I realized I was too comfortable watching it and there was none of the suspense or disturbing imagery that made the first movie a favorite of mine.

On the 3rd viewing I hated it. I was originally gonna show The Ring and The Ring Two in chronological order at my party but decided The Ring 2 would ruin the impact that The Ring 1 had.

It's like they forgot about the tape. It's nonsensical and stupid. Samara coming out of the hospital bag? WTF? Oh and they made her talk too damn much. The only scene that kind of scared me was the "Cimbing out of the well" scene. That was pretty good and pretty well shot.

Overall, if they mess up on the rumored Ring 3 I will give up on this series.

Truly shocking sequel, and not in the way it should be.

Naomi Watts is Rachel (Hardly likely to forget that character name in a hurry; doubt I've ever heard any movie character called to by name as many times as is evident in The Ring Two), mother to Aidan (Though it sounded more like Hayden to me) , that creepy little boy from the first film which ended with him watching *that* video, if I recall accurately.

Well the two of them have moved home and Rachel's landed an easy job with a local newspaper as opposed to the big heavy city rag she was formerly with. They have abandoned their old lives as a result of the evil Samara and hope they have escaped her and can move on. However, when a local homicide particularly reports of a kid who died with some kind of 'face', Rachel gets on the scene to find that it seems Samara's back and up to her old tricks again.

The rest of the movie sees all 3 of them in a kind of head to head with Samara possessing Aidan and threatening to stay around for good.

OK, that would be a fair synopsis. Now for the the review: .....*drumroll*.....

This is bad. Really, really, really bad.

Now I'll tell you why.

What "The Ring" got right was that it was pretty faithful to the original Japanese movie which was such a smash hit in the first place. By not messing too much with the previous formula and avoiding 'Hollywoodising' the story to the usual popcorn extent, the remake was reasonably effective as a psychological chiller.

The problem with the sequel is it has *nothing* to do with the original Japanese franchise; it's an all new side-branch story. While in itself there's nothing wrong with this as it stands, it becomes an issue when Hollywood overblows it with, for example, ridiculously overplayed background music, and comedic interludes, some intentional, some not so.

The Ring Two has taken a great premise and turned it into an average Yank horror. There's nothing new here, apart from one singularly smart scene which works well (And it's not scary, merely impressive), and the great strength of the whole Ring 'empire' is the sheer originality of it. Ring was simply stunningly seminal horror, Ring 2 recaptured a lot of the original magic with some shiny technophobery, Ring 0 was a great tale, and the remake managed to translate a lot of the aspects from all 3 into a pretty decent and workable film for the western market.

This crude effort lacks any of the punch of *any* of the other 4. There are no good scares, boringly slow direction, overly dark cinematography, and pointless cameos from Sissy Spacek, Gary Cole and Elizabeth Perkins.

The Ring Two was a real disappointment, albeit a predictable one. Uninspired from the off, it didn't even look like the actors could be bothered with it, lamely delivering their lines like they were on half pay that day.

Avoid.

review_title: surprisingly, the movie is an intelligent remark about the myth of motherhood
review_detailed_main: true, not very scary, but i was astonished to watch the audience cheers at a sight of a mother, who's about to drawn her baby in the bath. that alone was worth it! in that sense, the movie deals with some unspoken common fears that have to do with kinship and parenthood. the movie is quite dark, and even brave, in the way it deals with the motherhood myth of endless love and sacrifice. relating directly to "rosmary's baby" it has some inspiring (and even outrageous) moments in re-considering that myth - and the price mothers (and kids) paid while worship it. mostly intelligent (except the "happy end"), ring two was a pleasant surprise!!!

review_title: The marketing was more clever than the movie.
I Just Watched It and I Can Remember Nothing
review_detailed_main: The end credits are playing right now, but I had to struggle for a moment to remember whatever it was I just watched. This while movie is so useless and boring that I was seriously forgetting every scene that happened as it was happening. It was that uninvolving. The tub sequence was kinda cool, though, but that's about it. Completely unmemorable and a total waste of time. It was so forgettable, in fact, that I had comoletely forgotten that I had even seen before when it came out. Gee, what a coincidence.

review_title: Has its moments, but is generally disappointing.
review_detailed_main:
This is one of those movies that rides through to box-office success based on the hype generated by the previous installment. The Ring was a good movie. It was visually stunning and very unsettling. The Ring Two felt like it was trying to be as good as The Ring, but the end result is only an okay movie.

First -- it wasn't scary. I'm not scared easily by movies, but the first scared me more than any movie ever has. I was maybe slightly on edge for about 5 minutes of this movie, total. And not even 5 consecutive minutes. The problem could be that it uses the exact same scare tactics as the first, and they're only scary the first time. The one scene that I found to be somewhat unsettling -- the "deer scene" for those who have seen the movie -- was stretched entirely too long, until it became slightly ridiculous and even laughable.

I did not like the use of CGI in this film. Part of the beauty of the first film was that CGI was used sparingly to enhance the realism of the scene, not to act on its own as something that should scare the viewer. For me, it simply wasn't believable enough to be scary. The first one was scary because everything felt real. In a less realistic movie, such as a science fiction or fantasy film, CGI's less-than-real appearance can be overlooked since none of it looks very real to begin with, but in a film like this, realism is very important, and a little too much CGI is used for it to feel real enough.

If you're very easily scared and want a mellow horror movie, this is a "safe" movie for you. But if you loved the first for it's beautiful cinematography and realistic, frightening atmosphere, you'll be disappointed by this sequel.

After reading the comments already published about this film i do not feel you are giving it the credit it deserves, this film is incredibly well structured and i feel left us worrying than more than 'how did it fit in with the 1st one'. i also feel that moving away from the whole 'video' idea was very good and therefore did not have us watching the same stuff over again. I felt the use of the camera linked in well with the boys fathers death and reminded us what had happened at the end. Overall i was pleased with this film, and when i returned home and ran the bath i could just imagine the high pitched screams from the 1st one mixed with the images of the dead girl. This film deserves a lot more than what it has been given, well done 8/10 :D

review_title: Pee first. Then walk out of the theater.
review_detailed_main:
I was extremely disappointed by this, and for the first time, I avoided all reviews and advertisements so I could see the movie as it was meant to be seen. But seriously, don't bother. If you loved the first one, watch the first one again.

The first "Ring" had an air of unsettled, skin-crawling creepiness about it, not to mention a strong sense of urgency that made it fun to watch and anticipate. The sequel ditched all that, or recycled it, or put it in the freezer and thawed it only partially. There's a similar "jigsaw puzzle" element to it, but not nearly as mysterious as the first, so you just don't care as much. Rachel (Naomi Watts) basically just keeps missing the point throughout the movie so the plot can be spread thinner than a crepe. So there I was, watching this movie, waiting for something to happen, in the meantime, all that water is really making me have to pee, but I'm holding out hope for something to actually occur.

This wasn't the best way to make a sequel for this movie. It seemed like they had only wanted to make one to drive popularity, and that's it. The story seemed pretty offset from the original plot of the first movie. It almost seemed as if they tried to make it closer to something like "The Exorcist." A kid gets possessed and that should automatically make it appealing as a horror movie. I think I was scared more from the commercials and previews than from the movie itself. I was very bored watching it and I don't want to watch it again. The story was twisted around so much that it just seemed like it didn't belong as a sequel. This movie shouldn't have been made. :-(

What a horrible movie experience. I mean, how could a film crash so badly? I've always been a fan of the first remake, but, I don't see why I didn't just turn the thing off half way through. Everything in this movie was done horribly wrong. The thing that made the original Ring so appealing was it's use of subtle horror. Everything was constructed so well that the final product left you unsettled but satisfied. Plus, The Ring just looked downright amazing. The visual style of that film stands out as one of the best in recent American releases. The use of blues, blacks, and grays, gave the film a really washed out feeling. You didn't see a bright, solid color until the very end. See, Samara didn't really show herself until the very end of the movie when she attacked Noah. The film didn't rely on cheep scares to entertain the audience, but created a constant state of tension. I never thought of The Ring as a ghost story, but the blending of a few genres. Perhaps that's The Ring II's biggest flaw. It's a slasher film at heart.

If anyone picked up the collector's edition earlier this year with The Ring and Rings, then you already know the backstory to the sequel. I personally loved Rings, both for it's entertainment value and it's interesting visual style. Oh, just the premise alone of that short film would have created a much better sequel. Much better. The story of Aidan and Rachel was over. You didn't need to elaborate it on anymore. I'm in full support of one or two sequels to The Ring, as long as you do it right. There's a very large and interesting environment to explore. Yet, we continue to focus on Aidan and Rachel. They've just moved in to their new home, and not soon after, Rachel discovers that there's been a mysterious death in the home town.

"Oh gawd, it's something aboot his face!" So, Rachel's got trouble. Of course, in the first ten minutes or so of the film, we have a conversation between Rachel and Samara. Ridiculous. I don't like this Samara. I don't like the Samara that goes around the world searching for people so she can have a new mommy. I like the Samara that has the ability to create a tape...and not much more. The Ring centered around the tape, not Samara. Samara's "Decayed" body was never scary to me. It looked good in the original, but now, it just looks like a bad costume and makeup job. Especially in the final scene when she comes out of the television. Ick. Personally, Samara was at her best when you saw the tape of her in the hospital. Creepy. The film doesn't even show the 'new' tape, and there is a new tape. It was released on the Internet a few weeks before the release. Clearly Samara had the time to create a new one, but didn't realize that DVD-Rs were the way to go for recording.

Then, the film just...dies. It offers absolutely nothing, and just gets worse as it goes on. I just hate the entire concept. Samara is just out trying to kill things. But, you're not scared of Samara. You're just...uninterested. She's not interesting because the film makes her out to be the new Freddy. The film completely does away with anything that the first tried to establish. I just can't believe this film was made. Wait, yes I can. Of course it was made. The Ring did well at the box office, so a sequel should follow. It's the perfect formula! Who cares if the sequel is horrible? People will still go see it. It's sad, but it's true. This film does away with the visual style that made the original so attractive, which is sad. If they were going to make a movie with a horrible plot, at least give me something to look at.

Oh, and the CGI Deer. Wow. When the one came flying into the front of the car, I busted out laughing uncontrollably. There's no reason to this. None. Well, in the tape released on the Internet in promotion of the film, had a picture of a deer on the wall. So, I guess that explains it. Oh, wait. No it doesn't.

review_title: IMDB reviews are so dumb, I was watching this waiting for it to get super bad but it only got better.
review_detailed_main: This is just as fun as part 1, there are very little dumb scenes or dumb decisions made. It's solid, and beautiful! What a bunch of idiots who shame this movie just because it's not a rehash of part 1...I loved this story! The water scenes are so cold and gloomy... This is coming from a guy who watches Exploitation films like The last house on the left, I spit on your grave, or The Beast In Heat. Those are sick twisted films, while this film is a haunting dream!

review_title: A Stain on The Ring Franchise
review_detailed_main:
I saw this last night at the local theater and was completely disappointed. What a borefest this was. This one picks up where the original, which I loved, left off and starts with a couple of teens with the tape. It seems that tape has really gotten around since the last movie and eventually it makes its way to the small town where Watts and her creepy kid retired to. (As you remember, anyone watching the tape has to make a copy for someone else to watch or they'll get killed by Samara.) This movie was extremely slow paced and only had a few scares in it. One totally ridiculous scene had our heroes attacked by a bunch of obviously CGI deer. Real stupid and not at all scary. The deer have nothing to do with this movie except as a lame attempt at being scary. I fell asleep for 15 minutes in the middle of this flick, woke up, and realized I hadn't missed anything. A friend said it was like watching paint dry.

The plot is so stretched out that they could have easily made this a 30 minute episode of the Ring on TV and not cut anything out. The best scenes were with Lumburg from Office Space and Sissy Spacek.

I loved the first Ring and just can't understand how the sequel could be such a dud.

The Ring Two was a completely waste of my time and many others. I've always known that sequels aren't as good as the original, but i needed to see it, since the Ring was so good. I was so disappointed, what i can say in it's favor is that it had good special effects, that's something i can't complain, like the bathroom scene. On this film they just try to put an explanation for everything that was left as a mystery on the fist part, while mystery was what makes The Ring so good. Also the fact that they put flashes of Samara every 5 minutes, with the intention to make the movie scary, very bad attempt i most say. Probably they already knew the movie was not scary. The audience was even laughing in the theater. To me they just try to make more money, but they couldn't figure out how to make the sequel.

review_title: Samara hunts down Aiden looking for a mother. Rachel then goes to the screen and climbs up the well.
review_detailed_main: I think the movie probably would have been good except people were screaming at random times. I recommend going to a showing that there won't be a lot of people screaming at stupid times. If you are one of these people please be considerate and don't keep screaming after the scary part is done because it makes people like me want to go slap you and tell you to shut up. I didn't of course because I was too scared. The movie did turn out better than I expected though. I haven't slept in my bed alone since I saw it. I went with a lot of friends and one of them explained the things that were happening cause I kept my eyes closed about 3/4 of the time. I'm a big wimp though so yeah you should go and see it.

i still don't understand how i actually sat through this whole movie.

i watched the first one and actually thought it was decent and slightly well written, but...

this movie... i'm still shaking my head. i just can't wrap my head around how bad it was.

i'm very laid back about movies, but this one insulted my intelligence almost as much as the latest hannibal movie.

the acting was just as good as it was in the first movie -- which doesn't mean much -- but the storyline was as if it was written in a 4th grade writing workshop by the kid with ADD.

i feel dumber after watching this movie. i don't recommend it at all.

I don't believe it when someone rates a movie 1/10 or 10/10. This should be reserved for the worst of the worst and best of the best. Truthfully, i thought this movie would blow compared to part 1. It was OK, predictable horror scenes, a lot of CGI rather than building suspense. The movie takes a twist, deviating from the VHS storyline of part 1. It had to, but what makes it poor, is how painfully slow it is. Story 7/10 - better than VHS Story explaining more of Samara 4/10 - tries to hard to use that reflection imagery of part 1 (bunch a non sensible images that barley relate to the story except for the fact they are in a hallway or on the floor..etc..) Acting 5/10 (as expected nothing special) Overall flow and what i call Audience Chemistry Effect (ACE) 2/10

Just doesn't keep the watchers interest long enough to get into it. To much like "THEY, DARKNESS FALLS, BOOGEYMEN" (look them up...probably the same rating)

review_title: Not as good as the original, but decent (CONTAINS SPOILERS)
do not waste your time or money
review_detailed_main:
I saw this movie expecting it would be worth a scare or two. Or at least have a plot twist like the first one. I was greatly disappointed. There was nothing original here and I found sitting through the entire movie quite painful.

The acting was bad, the very few "scares" were predictable, dialogue was non-existent and that kid was incredibly annoying. If I hear his voice whine "Rachel" again my ears may bleed. The only thing about this that gives me nightmares is all the money it is making. Do yourself a favor and see a different movie. Just don't donate your money to his crap or they might make another one.

After reading many of the comments by film critics, I was hesitant to pay to see this movie in the theaters. It was only by chance that I ended up in a theater with two and a half hours to kill, and where The Ring 2 was the only film with a soon-enough starting time that I had any interest in seeing. I went into the film expecting it to be horrible.

I ended up being surprised.

The Ring 2 is a completely different movie from the first one. The first Ring film was a psychological thriller about a mysterious video tape that seemed to kill whoever saw it. Despite the fact that it left a number of key plot points unresolved - for example, how a little girl was able to transmit her thoughts into a VCR-ready tape in the first place is never explained - the first one became a huge success because the horror was from an unexpected source. How does someone who knows they only have seven days to live unless they solve a bizarre mystery is an interesting take on the survival horror genre.

I only write so much about the first film because it is necessary for a proper explanation as to why people may have disliked the second film.

The Ring 2, despite any reports you may hear, is indeed a true sequel. There are a number of plot points that someone who had not seen the first one would not clearly understand. In fact, without seeing the first film, the second would probably seem so bizarre that viewers would be bound to dislike it.

While The Ring 2 is indeed a true sequel, it is not done in the same style as the first film, and I believe that turned critics who were expecting more of the same away. The horror this time is not in beating a time limit to stave off some unforeseen consequences. As many of the reviewers have hinted, the horror this time around is in the possibility that Naomi Watts' son is somehow causing the trouble. One could say that, if anything, this would be a mother's worst fear.

Most of the scares come from Watts' struggle to figure out what is going on around her, and why her son has suddenly developed a cold that lowers his body temperature. Again, very different from the first movie, but still effective.

Furthermore, while this would likely enrage horror film purists, the filmmakers do add a little bit of depth to the story. Themes of domestic abuse, the connection between a child and their need for a mother, and the power of love are all explored to some degree during the course of the film.

I do not pretend that The Ring 2 is better than, or even as good as, the first one. It's not. There are too many loose ends that get conveniently tied up, some of the events even after being explained still seem unclear, and there are a number of ways the ending could have been more powerful. Overall, however, The Ring 2 was an enjoyable experience. It was different from the first one, yes, but different is not always bad. If anything, it should come out on DVD soon, so at least give it a rent. You might be surprised.
